ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches across the lowland forests south of the Central Cordillera of Indonesian Irian Jaya and Papua New Guinea.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5d6b81ba-a3cb-45ac-920e-90a3b174fd09/155 Southern New Guinea lowland rain forests - 710928003 Flickr.jpg

ecoregions.title: Southern New Guinea Freshwater Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion consists of a large extent in south-central New Guinea and a smaller, disjunct patch along the southern coast of the Vogelkop Peninsula in West Papua.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/fc6f82df-a0ab-41d1-b757-74d8be7d987a/154 Southern New Guinea freshwater swamp forests - John Morrison.jpg

ecoregions.title: Southeastern Papuan Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This lowland and montane ecoregion is made up of the Owen Stanley Range and surrounding lowland and coastal areas.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/cf9f45b8-bf78-4e61-9e5b-8edac815b685/153 Southeast Papuan rain forests - Arthur Chapman.jpg

ecoregions.title: Northern New Guinea Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is comprised of the Van Rees, Gauttier, Cyclops, Denake, Bewani, Torricelli, Prince Alexander, and Adelbert Ranges.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/ede1cf4d-dd17-48dc-a1d0-a8b403a89da3/149 Northern New Guinea montane rain forests - Rhett Butler.jpg

ecoregions.title: Northern New Guinea Lowland Rain and Freshwater Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: The lowlands of northern New Guinea are a maze of freshwater and peat swamps that interlace tall lowland forests and tall-grass savannas.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5e09b1f0-e789-4315-968a-1cac7916c4c3/148 Northern New Guinea lowland rain and freshwater swamp forests - Rocky Roe.JPG

ecoregions.title: New Britain-New Ireland Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: Mossy cloud forests covered in epiphytes top the high mountains of New Britain and New Ireland.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/90edf25e-197e-4fae-b7ae-3513e8292f33/145 New Britain-New Ireland montane rain forests - Ethan B Linck.jpeg

ecoregions.title: New Britain-New Ireland Lowland Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: The Bismarck Archipelago is dominated by New Britain and New Ireland, though St. Matthias Islands, New Hanover, and many associated islands are also part of the archipelago.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b7814ddf-6abe-4492-a0c9-f9982aaaf32a/144 New Britain-New Ireland lowland rain forests - Ethan B Linck.jpeg

ecoregions.title: Louisiade Archipelago Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: Located far to the east of the island of New Guinea, the idyllic Louisiade Archipelago supports rain forests with many endemic plants and animals.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/dcc56cd1-53a4-4a79-ac2e-a914da8de79b/143 Louisiade Archipelago rain forests - John Leslie Dowe Australian Tropical Herbarium Cairns Qld Australia.jpg

ecoregions.title: Huon Peninsula Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: The climate of this ecoregion is tropical wet, which is characteristic of this part of Melanesia, located in the western Pacific Ocean north of Australia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/422bd4b8-86e7-4478-9d9e-1b387df07b35/141 Huon Peninsula montane rain forests - Ryan Hawk ryanhawk.com.jpg

ecoregions.title: Central Range Papuan Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the mountain spine of the island of New Guinea.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/9fcb9494-8b72-4505-9f31-9587ce7bc1be/139 Central Range Papuan montane rain forests - John Morrison.jpg

ecoregions.title: Biak-Numfoor Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers Biak and Numfoor islands that stand guard at the entrance of Cenderawasih Bay constricting the western part of Papua New Guinea to form Bird’s Head Peninsula.

ecoregions.title: Admiralty Islands Lowland Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This group of remote oceanic islands that comprise the ecoregion are volcanic in origin, dating back to the late Miocene 8 to 10 million years ago.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/92244d0b-6418-4bf8-b5e1-91e86c9606b6/135 Admiralty Islands lowland rain forests - Valter Weijola.jpg

children.name: Vanuatu Islands (AU11)
children.content:
The Vanuatu Islands bioregion, located in the Australasia realm, is an archipelago of over 80 islands just to the east of New Caledonia and the Coral Sea, marking the beginning of the South Pacific Ocean and the southern grouping of islands in Melanesia. These islands, totaling more than 1 million hectares of land, are dominated by one ecoregion – Vanuatu Rainforests [1] – which are the product of one of the world’s most prolific seed dispersers, the flying fox. The area is rich with marine life, including 4000 species of marine mollusks.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Australasia. Visit the Project Marketplace​ ​to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the ​Vanuatu Islands ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Vanuatu Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion consists of tropical lowland and montane forests in the island nation of Vanuatu (formerly New Hebrides), with the addition of the Santa Cruz Group, or Temotu Province of the Solomon Islands.

children.name: Coral Sea & New Caledonia Islands (AU10)
children.content:
The Coral Sea bioregion, located in the Australasia realm, extends from the Great Barrier Reef to the New Caledonia Islands, encompassing most of the Coral Sea and sharing much of the reef’s rich biodiversity. The New Caledonia islands are mostly covered in tropical rainforest, with dry forests along the main island’s west coast. The bioregion has two ecoregions – New Caledonia Dry Forests [1], New Caledonia Rain Forests [2] – with a total land area of nearly 2 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Australasia. Visit the Project Marketplace​ ​to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the ​Coral Sea & New Caledonia Islands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: New Caledonia Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The dry forests of New Caledonia contain a unique assemblage of plants with 59 endemic species.

ecoregions.title: New Caledonia Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: The long isolation of this group of South Pacific islands―an errant chunk of ancient Gondwanaland consisting of New Caledonia and Loyalty Islands―has driven the evolution of a biota that is globally distinctive.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/86fa59da-cb81-484a-8333-45f4be4c8f2b/146 New Caledonia rain forests - David Mark.jpg

children.name: Solomon Islands (AU12)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/45022217-1a02-476e-beb0-f314742766bc/152 Solomon Islands Rain Forests RH D 22.jpeg

children.content:
The Solomon Islands bioregion, located in the Australasia realm, is an archipelago of six major islands and hundreds of minor islands and islets in the Solomon Sea, just above the Coral Sea. It is the central grouping of islands in Melanesia. These islands, totaling approximately 3.5 million hectares of land, are dominated by one ecoregion – Solomon Islands Rain Forests [1] – and are known for a diversity of plant life, including more than 230 species of orchid. This bioregion contains several active volcanoes.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Australasia. Visit the Project Marketplace​ ​to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the ​Solomon Islands ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Solomon Islands Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: The Solomon Islands are an arc of high oceanic islands clothed in rain forests and surrounded by blue coral-filled seas.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/82e142d8-1cb4-4202-9330-a2f821417a76/152 Solomon Islands rain forests - Ethan B Linck.jpg

children.name: Queensland Tropical Rainforests & Savannas (AU9)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/35bec551-2857-42ff-97b3-29018656ace4/183 Cape York Peninsula Tropical Savanna Jim Bendon.jpg

children.content:
The Queensland Tropical bioregion, located in the Australia subrealm, covers the northeast coast of Australia, including Cape York in the north, running along the coastline of the Coral Sea. This bioregion includes the Great Barrier Reef just off the coast of Queensland, the world’s largest reef system, and one of the seven natural wonders of the world. These reefs support an extraordinary diversity of wildlife, including 400 corals, 30 cetacean species, over 1500 species of fish, and 400 corals. On land, the bioregion consists mostly of tropical savannas with pockets of coastal rainforest. It contains three ecoregions—Queensland Tropical Rain Forests [150], Brigalow Tropical Savanna [182], Cape York Peninsula Tropical Savanna [183]—with a total land area of nearly 57 million hectares.

Learn more about each of the ​Queensland Tropical Rainforests & Savannas ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Cape York Peninsula Tropical Savanna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion's location and diverse habitats make for a rich biota representing one quarter of Australia’s frogs, one quarter of its reptiles, a third of all mammals, and half of its birds represented.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5c0f5ef3-c3f9-4a19-97a4-9a0379e3e452/183 Cape York Peninsula tropical savanna - Roisterer.jpg

ecoregions.title: Queensland Tropical Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: Northeast Australia’s relict tropical rainforests are notable for ancient lineages of plants and animals and strong affinities with the tropical forests of New Guinea to the north.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/6bfd6818-9c48-4ea5-a2e8-ee2de524ea6e/150 Queensland tropical rain forests - Ivo Gut.jpg

ecoregions.title: Brigalow Tropical Savanna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a transition from wetter coastal forests of eastern Australia to the drier semi-arid and arid zones of the continent’s center.

children.name: North Australian Tropical Savannas (AU8)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/3be6e738-3cb7-4f02-bbee-253af9313ecf/181 Arnhem Land Tropical Savanna Dietmar Rabich cc.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/dbd52f13-0f2c-4b91-b9e8-fc4518aab00b/187 Mitchell Grass Downs John Robert McPherson cc.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/70213c9b-b59f-4b6e-98ca-a1d82af88159/184 Carpentaria Tropical Savanna James Fitzgerald cc.jpg

children.content:
The North Australian Tropical bioregion, located in the Australasia realm, consists entirely of tropical savannas covering the north of the continent, excluding Cape York in the north of Queensland. The bioregion contains six ecoregions – Kimberly Tropical Savanna [1], Victoria Plains Tropical Savanna [2], Arnhem Land Tropical Savanna [3], Carpentaria Tropical Savanna [4], Mitchell Grass Downs [5], Einasleigh Upland Savanna [6] – and adjacent marine areas in the Timor Sea and Gulf of Carpentaria. It has a total land area of more than 168 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Australasia. Visit the Project Marketplace​ ​to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the ​North Australian Tropical Savannas ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Victoria Plains Tropical Savanna
ecoregions.dek: The Victoria Plains are a transition zone between the monsoonal rain environments of northern Australia and the dry arid interior of the continent.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/cffd98ad-abd3-4107-81ec-d9c53c3ea664/189 Victoria Plains tropical savanna - Nichollos Harrison.jpg

ecoregions.title: Mitchell Grass Downs
ecoregions.dek: Mitchell grasses dominate vast treeless, rolling plains that stretch from central west Queensland into the Barkly Tableland on the northeast fringe of Australia’s central deserts.

ecoregions.title: Kimberly Tropical Savanna
ecoregions.dek: The deep gorges and steep cliffs of the rugged central ranges of the Kimberly have long functioned as climate microrefugia for many moisture-loving species.

ecoregions.title: Einasleigh Upland Savanna
ecoregions.dek: Moving inland and upwards from the coastal Queensland rainforests, the drier Einasleigh Upland Savanna supports ironbark woodlands, wetlands, and drier rainforests.

ecoregions.title: Carpentaria Tropical Savanna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses a long arc of depositional plains along the southern Gulf of Carpentaria.

ecoregions.title: Arnhem Land Tropical Savanna
ecoregions.dek: Arnhem Land is notable for its vast relatively natural landscapes, mosaics of floodplains, woodlands, wetlands, sedgelands, mangroves, and pockets of vine-filled monsoonal rainforest.

children.name: Greater Australian Interior Desert & Shrublands (AU7)
children.content:
The Greater Australian Interior bioregion, located in the Australia subrealm, represents a huge expanse of desert and dry shrublands with the famous Uluru, or Ayers Rock, in the center of the continent, a site that is sacred to its Indigenous people. The bioregion contains eight distinct ecoregions—Central Ranges Xeric Scrub [208], Gibson Desert [209], Great Sandy-Tanami Desert [210], Great Victoria Desert [211], Nullarbor Plains Xeric   Shrublands [212], Simpson Desert [214], Tirari-Stuart Stony Desert [215], Western Australian Mulga Shrublands [216]—with a total area of more than 325 million hectares.

Learn more about each of the ​Greater Australian Interior Desert & Shrublands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Western Australian Mulga Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is mostly covered by mulga trees, a type of acacia adapted to hot and arid climate through long tap roots that access water.

ecoregions.title: Tirari-Stuart Stony Desert
ecoregions.dek: Ancient gibber pebble plains, sand dunes, ephemeral gilgal lakes, salt lakes, and xeric grasslands cover the Tirari-Sturt stony desert, one of the driest areas of Australia.

ecoregions.title: Simpson Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion has low relief characterized by flood and alluvial plains, ephemeral lakes and claypans.

ecoregions.title: Nullarbor Plains Xeric Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: The Nullarbor Plain is flat, featureless, and treeless, riddled with caves and sinkholes in this uplifted ancient seabed—the world’s largest limestone plain.

ecoregions.title: Great Victoria Desert
ecoregions.dek: The Great Victoria Desert is a global hotspot for reptile diversity, with the colourful thorny devil being one of the most spectacular.

ecoregions.title: Great Sandy-Tanami Desert
ecoregions.dek: This expansive ecoregion encompasses the Little Sandy Desert, Great Sandy Desert, and Tanami Desert Interim Biogeographic Regionalization for Australia (IBRA) regions.

ecoregions.title: Gibson Desert
ecoregions.dek: The broad gravel and red sand plains and dunes of the Gibson Desert are home to one to the world’s most diverse communities of reptiles.

ecoregions.title: Central Ranges Xeric Scrub
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes red-soils of mulga (Acacia aneura) shrubland and grasslands of the Central Ranges at the heart of Australia.

children.name: West Australian Dry Coastal Shrublands (AU6)
children.content:
The West Australian bioregion, located in the Australia subrealm, includes the dry shrublands on the continent’s west coast, from Shark Bay to the beginning of Eighty Mile Beach in the northwest. It contains two ecoregions—Carnarvon Xeric Shrublands [207], Pilbara Shrublands [213]—and adjacent marine areas in the Indian Ocean. The total land area of this bioregion is more than 26 million hectares.

Learn more about each of the ​West Australian Dry Coastal Shrublands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Pilbara Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion displays unusually high levels of endemism derived, in part, from its ancient landscapes, complex habitats, and relative isolation.

ecoregions.title: Carnarvon Xeric Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes the dry shrublands of this remote region in western Australia.

children.name: South Australian Mediterranean Forests, Woodlands & Scrub (AU5)
children.content:
The South Australian Mediterranean bioregion, located in the Australia subrealm, consists mostly of woodlands and shrublands covering much of the length of Australia’s southern and western coastline, from St. Vincent Gulf to Shark Bay. The bioregion contains eight ecoregions—Coolgardie   Woodlands [197], Esperance Mallee [198], Eyre and Yorke Mallee [199], Flinders-Lofty Montane Woodlands [200], Hampton Mallee and Woodlands [201], Jarrah-Karri Forest and Shrublands [202], Southwest Australia Savanna [205], Southwest Australia Woodlands [206]—and adjacent marine areas in the Great Australian Bight and Indian Ocean. 

Learn more about each of the ​South Australian Mediterranean Forests, Woodlands & Scrub ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Southwest Australia Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occurs in the Southwest Australia global biodiversity hotspot, one of the five Mediterranean-type ecosystems around the world that are known for exceptionally high endemism and richness of plant species.

ecoregions.title: Southwest Australia Savanna
ecoregions.dek: The southwest savannas are a transition zone between the arid center of Australia and the long-isolated biodiversity hotspot of southwest Australia.

ecoregions.title: Jarrah-Karri Forest and Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: The tall, wet forests of the southwestern tip of Australia are an isolated refuge for wet forest species separated from Australia’s eastern moist forests by the arid center of the continent.

ecoregions.title: Hampton Mallee and Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occurs on ancient marine dunes and sediments uplifted along the southern coast of Australia.

ecoregions.title: Flinders-Lofty Montane Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: North-south ranges and hills dominate this small ecoregion, situated in southern east-central Australia.

ecoregions.title: Eyre and Yorke Mallee
ecoregions.dek: The mallee woodlands and shrublands of southern Australia are hotspots for plant biodiversity, an outstanding feature of the five Mediterranean-climate regions in the world.

ecoregions.title: Esperance Mallee
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is one of the world’s greatest concentrations of unique plants, being one of the richest ecoregions within the Southwest Australia (SWA) Mediterranean-climate global botanical hotspot.

ecoregions.title: Coolgardie Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes a transition woodland between the Mediterranean-climate of Australia’s south-west coast and the continent’s arid interior.

children.name: East Australian Mediterranean Woodlands & Temperate Savannas (AU4)
children.content:
The East Australian Mediterranean bioregion, located in the Australia subrealm, is situated between the coastal forests to the east and the continent’s great interior deserts to the west. It is a largely Mediterranean woodland biome but is tightly interconnected with the continent’s southeastern temperate savanna. The bioregion contains four ecoregions—Eastern Australia Mulga Shrublands [191], Southeast Australia Temperate Savanna [192], Murray-Darling Woodlands and Mallee [203], Naracoorte Woodlands [204]—including Kangaroo Island and adjacent marine areas in Long Bay and below. Its total land area is more than 76 million hectares.

Learn more about each of the ​East Australian Mediterranean Woodlands & Temperate Savannas ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Naracoorte Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: The Mediterranean-climate woodlands of the Naracoorte represent a globally-rare habitat type adapted to cool, wet winters and hot, dry summers.

ecoregions.title: Murray-Darling Woodlands and Mallee
ecoregions.dek: This is one of the world’s rare Mediterranean-climate ecoregions, all notable for rich concentrations of endemic plants.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8eb746f0-a1c0-449c-8be3-6742a77b11e5/203 Murray-Darling woodlands and mallee - Glen Fergus.jpg

ecoregions.title: Southeast Australia Temperate Savanna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a transition between the moist eastern coastal margin and the arid central interior Australia.

ecoregions.title: Eastern Australia Mulga Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: Low mulga woodlands and shrublands dominate the infertile soils of this ecoregion.

children.name: East Australian Temperate Forests & Mountain Shrublands (AU3)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b88de9cd-de6d-4658-8c46-da9cae6998f0/193 Australian Alps montane grasslands - Alex Cohen.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/db113bca-eb97-464c-8f2b-132cf00d7743/168 Eastern Australian temperate forests- Michael Barnett.jpg

children.content:
The East Australian Temperate bioregion, located in the Australia subrealm, stretches the length of the continent’s east coast and includes Tasmania. It is dominated almost entirely by temperate broadleaf forests with a pocket of alpine grasslands at the top of the Australian Alps. The bioregion contains six ecoregions—Eastern Australian Temperate Forests [168], Southeast Australia Temperate Forests [176], Tasmanian Central Highland   Forests [177], Tasmanian Temperate Forests [178], Tasmanian Temperate Rainforests [179], Australian Alps Montane Grasslands [193]—and adjacent marine areas in the Tasman Sea. Its total land area is more than 56 million hectares.

Learn more about each of the ​East Australian Temperate Forests & Montane ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Australian Alps Montane Grasslands
ecoregions.dek: The southern portion of the Great Dividing Range in southeast Australia has peaks reaching 2,228 m, making it the highest massif on the continent and the only ecoregion with alpine ecosystems.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b88de9cd-de6d-4658-8c46-da9cae6998f0/193 Australian Alps montane grasslands - Alex Cohen.jpg

ecoregions.title: Tasmanian Temperate Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes rainforests of western Tasmania which are among the world’s oldest forests.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b6434020-ef6d-468f-9b47-620b111bbd41/179 Tasmanian temperate rain forests - JJ Harrison.jpg

ecoregions.title: Tasmanian Temperate Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion houses Eucalypt woodlands, wombats, wallaby, kangaroo, echidnas, platypus, and tasmanian devils.

ecoregions.title: Tasmanian Central Highland Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion features a series of mountain peaks covered in unusual plant communities.

ecoregions.title: Southeast Australia Temperate Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the coastal lowlands and inland tablelands that lie inland of the Great Dividing Range and Australian Alps.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/01240db7-c4ed-4b1a-bd49-ae1a769202c5/176 Southeast Australia temperate forests - Andreas Schau.jpg

ecoregions.title: Eastern Australian Temperate Forests
ecoregions.dek: This wetter coastal ecoregion has acted as refuge for wet forest species for millions of years and many endemic and relictual species occur here.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/db113bca-eb97-464c-8f2b-132cf00d7743/168 Eastern Australian temperate forests- Michael Barnett.jpg

children.name: Central American Isthmian & Colombian Coastal Forests (NT24)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a06c6d06-5084-4ffa-a4a6-2a248b0a89cc/615 South American Pacific mangroves - Rhett Butler.jpg

children.content:
The Isthmian & Colombian Coastal bioregion, located in the Central America (Neotropical) realm, consists almost entirely of dense tropical forests with dry coastal forests surrounding Panama Bay and the Gulf of Parita on the southern side of the Isthmus of Panama. From a biogeographical perspective, Central America locks into the South American continent, extending down the full extent of Colombia’s Pacific coast and incorporating the humid forests of the Magdalena River valley that lies between two branches of the Northern Andes. The bioregion has nine terrestrial ecoregions – Chocó-Darién Moist Forests (454), Cocos Island Moist Forests (455), Eastern Panamanian Montane Forests (461), Isthmian-Atlantic Moist Forests (470), Isthmian-Pacific Moist Forests (471), Magdalena-Urabá Moist Forests (478), Talamancan Montane Forests (506), Panamanian Dry Forests (541), Malpelo Island Xeric Scrub (604) – and includes the large marine areas and extensive mangroves of the South American Pacific Mangroves (615) and Southern Mesoamerican Pacific Mangroves (617) on either side of the Isthmus. The total area of this bioregion is more than 27 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Central America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Central American Isthmian & Colombian Coastal Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Southern Mesoamerican Pacific Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The Southern Mesoamerican Pacific Mangrove ecoregion comprises five subecoregions.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/55637996-400a-46c5-a772-7483c31150c5/617 Southern Mesoamerican Pacific mangroves - Frank Hummel Birdquest.jpg

ecoregions.title: Mesoamerican Gulf-Caribbean Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The Mesoamerican Gulf-Caribbean Mangroves ecoregion holds eleven subecoregions. The mangrove fragments remaining across this ecoregion are important refuges for many breeding and migratory species.

ecoregions.title: Malpelo Island Xeric Scrub
ecoregions.dek: Malpelo Island is a small, isolated Pacific island 435 km to the west of Colombia and south of Panama.

ecoregions.title: Panamanian Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is distributed in distinct areas, such as small residual deciduous and semi-deciduous forests and gallery forests along the rivers.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a90f0ba2-7c92-4138-8cbd-b7590488b50d/541 Panamanian dry forests - Dirk van der Made.jpg

ecoregions.title: Talamancan Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: Located in the highlands of Costa Rica and western Panama, the Talamanca Montane Forests ecoregion occurs above 750 m and above 1,500 m in some places on the Pacific slope, up to approximately 3,000 m.

ecoregions.title: Magdalena-Urabá Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Located in northern Colombia, the moist forests of the Magdalena-Urabá ecoregion link the northern ecoregions of Mesoamerica and the Chocó with the Andean and Amazonian ecoregions.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/54119334-e982-4b5c-a11a-020c0f0a02c9/478 Magdalena-Urabá moist forests - Parque Nacionales Naturales de Colombia.jpg

ecoregions.title: Isthmian-Pacific Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends along the Pacific lowlands and foothills of southern Costa Rica and Panama.

ecoregions.title: Isthmian-Atlantic Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the lowland Atlantic slopes mainly below 500 m elevation in southern Nicaragua, northern Costa Rica, and most of Panama.

ecoregions.title: Eastern Panamanian Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: The eastern Panamanian Montane Forests are located in the southeastern portion of Panama, in the Darién Province.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/679cb01d-f93c-42c3-beff-f59f178d578d/461 Eastern Panamanian montane forests - D Olson.jpg

ecoregions.title: Chocó-Darién Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends from eastern Panama, in the provinces of Darién and Kuna-Yala, along almost the entire Pacific Coast of Colombia.

ecoregions.title: South American Pacific Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The South American Pacific Mangrove ecoregion is comprised of five subecoregions.

children.name: Yucatan & Veracruz Mixed Forests (NT27)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/4e009580-ab9d-4eae-9abc-d27ec19ddd2c/494- Usumacinta River from Yaxchilan, Chiapas, Mexico-Ec0494-CC-Thelma Datter-2011_resized.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/968c7744-2ff2-485e-9983-17cdeeacac01/514 Veracruz Moist Forests William L. Farr cc2.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b1436264-81fc-4860-b841-c7763e9ee96a/514 Veracruz Moist Forests Carlos Adampol Galindo.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/99cc5b1e-bff3-41f0-9a53-67784393ab41/514 Veracruz Moist Forests William L. Farr cc.jpg

children.content:
The Yucatan bioregion, located in the Central America (Neotropical) realm, extends from the Petén Basin in central Guatemala to the beginning of the dry mesquite woodlands (mezquital) in northern Mexico, contained between the Eastern Sierra Madre mountain range and the Caribbean coast. It is dominated by the tropical moist forests of the Yucatán Peninsula along with sections of dry forest and pine savanna. The bioregion contains nine terrestrial ecoregions – Pantanos De Centla (489), Petén-Veracruz Moist Forests (494), Sierra De Los Tuxtlas (501), Veracruz Moist Forests (514), Veracruz Montane Forests (515), Yucatan Moist Forests (519), Veracruz Dry Forests (550), Yucatan Dry Forests (551), Belizean Pine Savannas (564) – along with extensive Mesoamerican Gulf-Caribbean Mangroves (613). The total area of this bioregion is more than 37 million hectares, not including adjacent marine areas.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Central America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Yucatan & Veracruz Mixed Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Belizian Pine Savannas
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is found almost entirely in Belize along the northwestern coast of the Caribbean.

ecoregions.title: Yucatan Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is on the northwestern portion of the Yucatán Peninsula in Mexico.

ecoregions.title: Veracruz Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The region is in the coastal plain of central Veracruz, north of the Santa Martha and San Andrés volcanoes.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a76c74bd-4231-4471-bc2a-1c1cfdbb1638/550 Veracruz dry forest - Héctor David Jimeno.jpg

ecoregions.title: Yucatan Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Yucatán Moist Forests are located at the junction between the physiographical provinces of Petén in the southeast and the Yucatán in the northwest.

ecoregions.title: Veracruz Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Veracruz Montane Forests are located in the Mexican State of Veracruz and are remnant of the Sierra Madre Oriental mountain range.

ecoregions.title: Veracruz Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This moist forest ecoregion is situated on the Gulf of Mexico’s northeastern coastal plain of Mexico, in the north of Veracruz and the south of Tamaulipas states.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/11c43a56-0541-4d11-aa38-505126011df6/514 Veracruz moist forest - Héctor David Jimeno.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sierra De Los Tuxtlas
ecoregions.dek: Sierra de los Tuxtlas constitutes the largest and northernmost intact portion of moist forests in Mexico.

ecoregions.title: Petén-Veracruz Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Spanning West to East along southeastern Mexico, the ecoregion narrows where the Mexican states of Veracruz, Oaxaca and Puebla meet, and continues as a wide strip of land towards the southeast.

ecoregions.title: Pantanos De Centla
ecoregions.dek: The Pantanos de Centla Moist Forests are in the state of Tabasco, Mexico.

ecoregions.title: Mesoamerican Gulf-Caribbean Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The Mesoamerican Gulf-Caribbean Mangroves ecoregion holds eleven subecoregions. The mangrove fragments remaining across this ecoregion are important refuges for many breeding and migratory species.

children.name: Mexican Subtropical Islands (NT29)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/4dcfb54b-177c-46ff-8dec-4f3e48e325ec/533 Islas Revillagigedo dry forests - Debora Barr NOAA.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/9e4e65fc-1130-46fe-b317-328e9b7d7f01/568 Clipperton Island shrub and grasslands - Shannon Rankin NOAA.jpg

children.content:
The Mexican Islands bioregion, located in the Pacific Ocean at the top of the Central America (Neotropical) realm, includes the Islas Revillagigedo just below the Baja California Peninsula as well as Clipperton Island farther south. These islands consist of tropical dry forest and shrublands with two ecoregions – Islas Revillagigedo Dry Forests (533), Clipperton Island Shrub and Grasslands (568) – as well as an important marine protected area proposed for the waters surrounding Clipperton Island. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 24,000 hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Central America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Mexican Subtropical Islands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Clipperton Island Shrub and Grasslands
ecoregions.dek: Clipperton Island, also referred to as “Ile de la Passion”, falls under the jurisdiction of the Republic of French Polynesia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/9e4e65fc-1130-46fe-b317-328e9b7d7f01/568 Clipperton Island shrub and grasslands - Shannon Rankin NOAA.jpg

ecoregions.title: Islas Revillagigedo Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: Volcanic activity from the Pleistocene gave rise to the four Revillagigedo Islands: Socorro, Clarión, San Benedicto, and Roca Partida, located approximately 390 km southwest of Cabo San Lucas in Mexico.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/4dcfb54b-177c-46ff-8dec-4f3e48e325ec/533 Islas Revillagigedo dry forests - Debora Barr NOAA.jpg

children.name: Mexican Dry & Coniferous Forests (NT28)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7c272c88-fb36-42c8-aef9-497282f2019d/557-The Cloud Forest of Santiago Comaltepec, Oaxaca, Mexico is some the best conserved in the world-Eco557-CC.JPG

children.content:
The Mexican Dry & Coniferous bioregion, located in the Central America (Neotropical) realm, starts at the Isthmus of Tehuantepec and includes most of the western Sierra Madre mountain range, running the entire length of Mexico’s Pacific coast. It consists entirely of tropical and subtropical dry forests and the pine-oak forests of the Sierra Madres. The bioregion contains 13 terrestrial ecoregions – Oaxacan Montane Forests (487), Bajío Dry Forests (521), Balsas Dry Forests (522), Jalisco Dry Forests (534), Sierra de la Laguna Dry Forests (544), Sinaloan Dry Forests (545), Southern Pacific Dry Forests (547), Sierra de la Laguna Pine-Oak Forests (556), Sierra Madre De Oaxaca Pine-Oak Forests (557), Sierra Madre Del Sur Pine-Oak Forests (558), Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt Pine-Oak Forests (559), San Lucan Xeric Scrub (607), Tehuacán Valley Matorral (610) – along with Northern Mesoamerican Pacific Mangroves (614). The total area of this bioregion is approximately 44 million hectares, not including adjacent marine areas.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Central America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Mexican Dry & Coniferous Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Northern Mesoamerican Pacific Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The Northwest Mexican Coast Mangroves are composed of two main mangrove areas located on the Pacific Coast and on the Gulf of California coast.

ecoregions.title: Tehuacán Valley Matorral
ecoregions.dek: The Tehuacán Valley Matorral ecoregion is situated in southeast Puebla and northwestern Oaxaca states in Mexico.

ecoregions.title: San Lucan Xeric Scrub
ecoregions.dek: The San Lucan Xeric Scrub ecoregion includes the southernmost part of the Baja California peninsula.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5ebec7f9-4c35-4e49-94c2-b81ad8087401/607 San Lucan xeric scrub - D Olson_resized.jpg

ecoregions.title: Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt Pine-Oak Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Trans-volcanic belt is a large mountain range running from west to east in the central portion of Mexico.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/bb3b9498-841e-4598-b06c-2611068f2cf9/559 Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt pine-oak forests - Julio César García.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sierra Madre Del Sur Pine-Oak Forests
ecoregions.dek: Most of this ecoregion falls within the Guerrero and Oaxaca states.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/0c268a82-dd9f-4b9d-851b-66a890906893/558  Sierra Madre del Sur pine-oak forests -James L Reveal.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sierra Madre De Oaxaca Pine-Oak Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is located in northern Oaxaca State, and is delineated by the Sierra Norte de Oaxaca Mountains, which have characteristically abrupt and rugged topography.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/be3af4d6-aba3-4156-8f70-36a82bb03ecb/557 Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests - Prisjl.JPG

ecoregions.title: Sierra de la Laguna Pine-Oak Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is contained in a larger area known as the Cape Region and constitutes the southernmost part of the Baja California Peninsula.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/308bcd15-a747-451b-8fab-49bf33072a62/556 Sierra de la Laguna pine-oak forests - German Ortiz Landa 7.jpg

ecoregions.title: Southern Pacific Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is located on the southeastern slopes of the Sierra Madre del Sur Mountains, which give way to a narrow fringe of coastal plains on which the dry forests of this ecoregion are found.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/d065e79e-f467-4bc2-8ec7-b758461fddfb/547 Southern Pacific dry forests - Darvin Santos.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sinaloan Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Sinaloan Dry Forests ecoregion is situated in the northwestern Pacific coastal plain of Mexico.

ecoregions.title: Sierra de la Laguna Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: Located at the southern end of the Baja California peninsula, this region was once an isolated island before joining the mainland.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/c58b294f-92b1-4197-85fa-4f2b83163d20/544 Sierra de la Laguna dry forests - D Olson.jpg

ecoregions.title: Jalisco Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Jalisco Dry Forests are located along the Pacific coast of the Mexican states of Nayarit, Jalisco, and Colima.

ecoregions.title: Balsas Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Balsas Dry Forest ecoregion is in southern Mexico, south of the mountainous Trans-volcanic belt.

ecoregions.title: Bajío Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is situated in western central Mexico, and forms part of the central trans-volcanic belt.

ecoregions.title: Oaxacan Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: Among the largest intact montane forests of southern Mexico, this ecoregion houses the highest diversity of amphibians and reptiles in the country.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a1df048b-ee59-4053-b1d1-17ae7c86fe10/487 Oaxacan montane forest - Héctor David Jimeno.jpg

children.name: Central American Mixed Forests (NT25)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/14a4ef5e-ea78-4b8f-91e8-030cd3667ca0/449 Cayos Miskitos-San Andrés and Providencia moist forests - Luis Barreto.png

children.content:
The Mixed Forests bioregion, located in the Central America (Neotropical) realm, covers most of Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador, and the mountain highlands of southern Guatemala. It consists of a series of complex interlocking tropical biomes – from pine forest/grasslands and moist forests in the east to coniferous and dry forests in the west. The bioregion contains 12 terrestrial ecoregions altogether – Cayos Miskitos-San Andrés and Providencia Moist Forests (449), Central American Atlantic Moist Forests (450), Central American Montane Forests (451), Chiapas Montane Forests (452), Chimalapas Montane Forests (453), Costa Rican Seasonal Moist Forests (458), Sierra Madre De Chiapas Moist Forests (502), Central American Dry Forests (527), Chiapas Depression Dry Forests (528), Central American Pine-Oak Forests (553), Miskito Pine Forests (573), Motagua Valley Thornscrub (605) – and includes extensive mangroves, Mesoamerican Gulf-Caribbean Mangroves (613) and Southern Mesoamerican Pacific Mangroves (617), along both the Caribbean and Pacific coastlines. The total area of this bioregion is over 36 million hectares, not including adjacent marine areas or the massive Lago Cocibolca in the south.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Central America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Central American Mixed Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Southern Mesoamerican Pacific Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The Southern Mesoamerican Pacific Mangrove ecoregion comprises five subecoregions.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/55637996-400a-46c5-a772-7483c31150c5/617 Southern Mesoamerican Pacific mangroves - Frank Hummel Birdquest.jpg

ecoregions.title: Miskito Pine Forests
ecoregions.dek: These coastal pine forests of the Caribbean coast and of the Honduras and Nicaragua lowlands contrast sharply with the surrounding tropical moist forest.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/85243e89-3477-458e-9ef4-290932ee74c0/573 Miskito pine forests - William M Ciesla Forest Health Management International.jpg

ecoregions.title: Central American Pine-Oak Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion incorporates the central Mexican state of Chiapas, southern Guatemala, most of Honduras and El Salvador, and small areas of west central Nicaragua.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/59b9f201-6412-425b-a5dc-a145fa5510e2/553 Central American pine-oak forests - Gerson Rodriguez.jpg

ecoregions.title: Chiapas Depression Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The most extensive dry forests in the state of Chiapas, Mexico lies on a vast portion of flat lands called the Central Chiapas Depression.

ecoregions.title: Central American Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Central American Dry forest ecoregion stretches along the Pacific Coast of southern Chiapas, Mexico to Guanacaste, Costa Rica.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7ef7e08e-c11d-4e47-be78-9adb3e03c483/527 Central American dry forests - Gregoire Dubois.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sierra Madre De Chiapas Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The species rich and diverse moist forests of Chiapas lie on both sides of the Sierra Madre de Chiapas.

ecoregions.title: Costa Rican Seasonal Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Costa Rican Seasonal Moist Forests ecoregion is a transitional subtropical habitat between the surrounding wet and dry forest ecoregions.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/9865df8e-ef32-4067-9361-f6f3297527cd/458 Costa Rican Seasonal Moist Forest - Liz Roy.jpg

ecoregions.title: Cocos Island Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Cocos Island in the central eastern Pacific Ocean lies 523 km southwest of Cabo Blanco, in Costa Rica.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/fc875f5d-1eb6-44fd-b74e-9cedb5b6535b/455 Cocos Island moist forests - J Rawl S.jpg

ecoregions.title: Chimalapas Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Chimalapas Montane Forests occur in mountains above approximately 1,000 m at the junction of the three most biodiverse states of Mexico: Veracruz, Oaxaca, and Chiapas.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/53f8bd34-ab92-48c6-b9a1-48679f4bbc3b/453 Chimalapas montane forests - Mario Jimenez Leyva.jpg

ecoregions.title: Chiapas Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is located in the state of Chiapas, Mexico, on the northeast mountain range, with elevations from 1,200-2,200 m.

ecoregions.title: Central American Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Central American Montane Forests ecoregion comprised of more than 40 relatively small islands extending from southern Mexico towards the southeast through Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, and Nicaragua.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/84e8b6b2-a4bc-4def-8f11-74619e249740/451 Central American montane forests - Gerson Rodriguez.jpg

ecoregions.title: Central American Atlantic Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is located along the Caribbean lowlands of Central America through southeast Guatemala.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/032170a8-c8c0-47b0-9031-f0ada55405c3/450 Central American Atlantic moist forests - Rebecca Ore.jpg

ecoregions.title: Cayos Miskitos-San Andrés and Providencia Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is formed by the moist forests of the Cayos Miskitos, San Andrés, and Providencia Islands.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/14a4ef5e-ea78-4b8f-91e8-030cd3667ca0/449 Cayos Miskitos-San Andrés and Providencia moist forests - Luis Barreto.png

ecoregions.title: Mesoamerican Gulf-Caribbean Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The Mesoamerican Gulf-Caribbean Mangroves ecoregion holds eleven subecoregions. The mangrove fragments remaining across this ecoregion are important refuges for many breeding and migratory species.

ecoregions.title: Motagua Valley Thornscrub
ecoregions.dek: The Motagua Valley is situated in northeastern Guatemala along the border of Honduras.

children.name: Caribbean Islands (NT26)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8a1245fb-ce66-4a09-91eb-86e0c35b744e/475 Leeward Islands Moist Forests Kouakou ph cc.jpg

children.content:
The Caribbean Islands bioregion, located in the Central America (Neotropical) realm, incorporates all 700 of the islands and islets of the Caribbean Sea, with the exception of Aruba, Curaçao, and other small islands just off the coast of Venezuela. It also includes the Everglades in the southern tip of Florida, which demarcates the transition between the Nearctic and Neotropical realms. The islands contain a mixture of dry and moist forests, both broadleaf and conifer, surrounded by mangroves. The largest island, Cuba, is mostly dry broadleaf forest with extensive flooded grasslands and some cactus scrub. The bioregion contains 19 terrestrial ecoregions altogether – Cuban Moist Forests (459), Hispaniolan Moist Forests (468), Jamaican Moist Forests (472), Leeward Islands Moist Forests (475), Puerto Rican Moist Forests (495), Windward Islands Moist Forests (517), Cuban Dry Forests (530), Hispaniolan Dry Forests (532), Jamaican Dry Forests (535), Lesser Antillean Dry Forests (537), Puerto Rican Dry Forests (543), Bahamian Pineyards (552), Cuban Pine Forests (554), Hispaniolan Pine Forests (555), Cuban Wetlands (579), Enriquillo Wetlands (580), Everglades Flooded Grasslands (581), Caribbean Shrublands (599), Cuban Cactus Scrub (600) – with extensive mangroves, including the Bahamian-Antillean Mangroves (612), across all the islands. The total area of this bioregion is over 24 million hectares, not including adjacent marine areas.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Central America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Caribbean Islands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Puerto Rican Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Montane forests cover the Sierra de Luquillo and the higher peaks of the Cordillera Central.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/962aee03-1b40-4fab-b8b5-4f39c288973f/495 Puerto Rican moist forests - Gregoire Dubois.jpg

ecoregions.title: Bahamian-Antillean Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The Bahamas islands ecoregion consist of over 3,000 low-lying islands with a maximum elevation of 60 m.

ecoregions.title: Cuban Cactus Scrub
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is dispersed in strips or small patches along Cuba’s shore, particularly in the southeastern part of the island.

ecoregions.title: Caribbean Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes the Leeward Islands, specifically most of Grande Terre and Marie-Galante of Guadeloupe, Antigua, Anguilla, St. Martin, St. Barthelemy, Saba, and the eastern portions of the US and British Virgin Islands.

ecoregions.title: Everglades Flooded Grasslands
ecoregions.dek: The Everglades, located at the southern tip of peninsular Florida, is the most well-known wetland in the United States and one of the most distinct in the world.

ecoregions.title: Enriquillo Wetlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is primarily composed of lakes, lake islands, and surrounding habitats.

ecoregions.title: Cuban Wetlands
ecoregions.dek: Most of Cuba’s wetlands are located on floodplains and depressions influenced by the tides.

ecoregions.title: Hispaniolan Pine Forests
ecoregions.dek: The pine forests of this ecoregion are located on slopes with shallow soils and at higher elevations in the Hispaniolan mountain systems.

ecoregions.title: Cuban Pine Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Cuban Pine Forests are located on the eastern and western sides of the island in the province of Isla de la Juventud and Pinar del Río.

ecoregions.title: Bahamian Pineyards
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is found in varying proportions on the northern Bahamian islands of Grand Bahama, Abaco, Andros, New Providence in the Bahamas, and the Caicos Islands of North and Middle Caicos and Pine Cay.

ecoregions.title: Puerto Rican Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Puerto Rican Dry Forests ecoregion is located along the south-central and southwestern coast of Puerto Rico and on the adjacent islands of Mona, Vieques, Culebra, Desecheo, and Caja de Muertos.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7f6dc517-6466-406d-a506-94d160b6591f/543 Puerto Rican dry forests - Gregoire Dubois.jpg

ecoregions.title: Lesser Antillean Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers small portions of the Caribbean’s Leeward Islands.

ecoregions.title: Jamaican Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion comprises approximately 15% of the land area on the island and covers most of the dry forests near the coast.

ecoregions.title: Hispaniolan Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The areas occupied by this ecoregion are located throughout the western two thirds of the island of Hispaniola, making up about 20% of the vegetation.

ecoregions.title: Cuban Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion contains 141 bird species, 11 of them endemic to the island, and some of which are endangered.

ecoregions.title: Windward Islands Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Windward Island Moist Forests ecoregion is found in much of the central portion of each of the Caribbean’s Windward Islands and is characterized by rugged mountains, lush tropical vegetation, and high annual rainfall.

ecoregions.title: Leeward Islands Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is found in various proportions on the Caribbean’s Leeward Islands characterized by rugged volcanic mountains covered in moist tropical forest.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/d2694c32-3330-4bdd-8477-47c750a854e7/475 Leeward Islands moist forests - Nicolas Vilars.jpg

ecoregions.title: Jamaican Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion comprises approximately 85% of Jamaica’s land area covering most of the island except coastal areas and lowland dry forests.

ecoregions.title: Hispaniolan Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The endangered Hispaniolan solenodon is endemic to its namesake island with much of its suitable habitat falling in this ecoregion.

ecoregions.title: Cuban Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is distributed in multiple patches of different sizes along the ranges and highlands of the island of Cuba.

children.name: Afghan-Balochistan Drylands, Mountain Meadows & Conifer Forests (PA30)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1542843a-1326-466b-958d-25296e565d3c/694 East Afghan montane conifer forests - Brian Christiansen.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f4f40fa8-2ebf-415d-b6c9-ed965111e5dc/813 Badghyz and Karabil semi-desert - koldo hormaza.jpg

children.content:
The Afghan-Balochistan Drylands, Mountain Meadows & Conifer Forests bioregion is part of the Persian Deserts & Forests subrealm located in the Central Eurasia realm (central Palearctic). It contains eight ecoregions—East Afghan Montane Conifer Forests (694), Ghorat-Hazarajat Alpine Meadow (752), Sulaiman Range Alpine Meadows (766), Afghan Mountains Semi-Desert (807), Badghyz and Karabil Semi-Desert (813), Balochistan Xeric Woodlands (814), Central Afghan Mountains Xeric Woodlands (816), Paropamisus Xeric Woodlands (834)—totaling approximately 78 million hectares of land area.

Learn more about each of the Afghan-Balochistan Drylands, Mountain Meadows & Conifer Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Paropamisus Xeric Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is located mostly in Northern Afghanistan on the central mountains, where higher altitudes and more rainfall permit open xeric woodlands to thrive.

ecoregions.title: Central Afghan Mountains Xeric Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion forms a broad crescent shapes belt surrounding the eastern and southern sides of the Afghan central mountains.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/12976637-f64f-4401-b7b3-3d215dde0020/816 Central Afghan Mountains xeric woodlands - Uploader.jpg

ecoregions.title: Baluchistan Xeric Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends from the Las Bela Valley and high plateaus of Baluchistan Province in southwest Pakistan and southeastern Afghanistan north to the Trans-Indus Plains of the North-West Frontier Province.

ecoregions.title: Badghyz and Karabil Semi-Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches through the hilly plateaus north of the Paropamiz mountain, part of the Hindu Kush range.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f4f40fa8-2ebf-415d-b6c9-ed965111e5dc/813 Badghyz and Karabil semi-desert - koldo hormaza.jpg

ecoregions.title: Afghan Mountains Semi-Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is made up of three disjunct areas of small, dry valleys along the slopes of Hindu Kush mountain range in Afghanistan.

ecoregions.title: Sulaiman Range Alpine Meadows
ecoregions.dek: This disjunct ecoregion covers the alpine meadows of the high elevations, above 1,500 m of the Sulaiman Range.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/48fcb1e2-5d73-44c7-ba74-bfeee5c27eb3/766 Sulaiman Range alpine meadows - Hayatullah Khan Durrani.JPG

ecoregions.title: Ghorat-Hazarajat Alpine Meadow
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion follows the western extension of the subalpine thickets and Cushion Shrubland floristic unit and is made up of several distinct parts.

ecoregions.title: East Afghan Montane Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion spans from the Eastern Hindu Kush mountain range in Afghanistan to the Central North of Pakistan.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1542843a-1326-466b-958d-25296e565d3c/694 East Afghan montane conifer forests - Brian Christiansen.jpg

children.name: Persian Deserts & Mountain Woodlands (PA29)
children.content:
The Persian Deserts & Mountain Woodlands bioregion is part of the Persian Deserts & Forests subrealm located in the Central Eurasia realm (central Palearctic). It contains four ecoregions—Kuh Rud and Eastern Iran Montane Woodlands (757), Central Persian Desert Basins (820), Registan-North Pakistan Sandy Desert (838), South Iran Nubo-Sindian Desert and Semi-Desert (841)—totaling approximately 134 million hectares of land area.

Learn more about each of the Persian Deserts & Mountain Woodlands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Registan-North Pakistan Sandy Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion spans southern Afghanistan, extreme eastern Iran, and part of Northwest Pakistan.

ecoregions.title: Central Persian Desert Basins
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers Iran’s central plateau, reaching into a small part of Northwest Afghanistan.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/6c14ef5a-6cf2-446a-a773-b4b756305972/820 Central Persian desert basins - Naser Mizbani.jpg

ecoregions.title: South Iran Nubo-Sindian Desert and Semi-Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches across the Southern swathe of Iran, reaching into small areas of Iraq and Pakistan.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/85839e53-a45b-4cf1-a94d-f27c84de4c36/841 South Iran Nubo-Sindian desert and semi-desert - Bilal Mizra.jpg

ecoregions.title: Kuh Rud and Eastern Iran Montane Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses the highlands of central and Eastern Iran, reaching into a very small area of Pakistan.

children.name: South Caspian Coastal & Mountain Mixed Forests (PA28)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/18784990-0ba8-4d8a-8011-d6a97be91558/649 Caspian Hyrcanian Mixed Forests Courtesy of Alireza Javaheri.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5cfea9f9-1e26-47db-8e82-d6714706b17c/649 Caspian Hyrcanian Mixed Forests Argooya CC.jpg

children.content:
The South Caspian Coastal & Mountain Mixed Forests bioregion is part of the Persian Deserts & Forests subrealm located in the Central Eurasia realm (central Palearctic). It contains two ecoregions—Caspian Hyrcanian Mixed Forests (649), Elburz Range Forest Steppe (695)—totaling nearly 12 million hectares of land area.

Learn more about each of the South Caspian Coastal & Mountain Mixed Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Elburz Range Forest Steppe
ecoregions.dek: The Elburz Range Forest Steppe is in Northern Iran, spanning the Southern and Eastern slopes of the Elburz Mountains.

ecoregions.title: Caspian Hyrcanian Mixed Forests
ecoregions.dek: The vast majority of the ecoregion lies in Northwest Iran, while part of it covers the Lenkoran lowlands and Talysh Mountains of Southeast Azerbaijan.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/18784990-0ba8-4d8a-8011-d6a97be91558/649 Caspian Hyrcanian Mixed Forests Courtesy of Alireza Javaheri.jpg

children.name: Zagros Mountain Forests & East Anatolian Steppe (PA27)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/68f11829-dad7-49d6-a773-abe4bbc59375/727 Eastern Anatolian montane steppe - Tuna Olger.jpg

children.content:
The Zagros Mountain Forests & East Anatolian Steppe bioregion is part of the Persian Deserts & Forests subrealm located in the Central Eurasia realm (central Palearctic). It contains two ecoregions—Zagros Mountains Forest Steppe (688), Eastern Anatolian Montane Steppe (727)—totaling nearly 57 million hectares of land area.

Learn more about each of the Zagros Mountain Forests & East Anatolian Steppe ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Eastern Anatolian Montane Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion traverses East Turkey, Northwest Iran, the Nakhchyvan Autonomous Republic in Azerbaijan, Armenia, and South Georgia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/68f11829-dad7-49d6-a773-abe4bbc59375/727 Eastern Anatolian montane steppe - Tuna Olger.jpg

ecoregions.title: Zagros Mountains Forest Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion spans the Zagros mountain arch.

children.name: Tian Shan-Pamir Grasslands, Mountain Steppe & Conifer Forests (PA31)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/3e82d942-ac12-4f47-93b1-7ab3cdd18f73/767 Tian Shan montane steppe and meadows - Ruslan Kadyrov.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1facfa2d-1142-42c0-8b5a-cfeb6a1fb67f/721 Alai-Western Tian Shan steppe - Сергей Юмагулов.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/831159fc-e1a0-4f95-8915-da8241be28a7/709 Tian Shan montane conifer forests (Kyrgyzstan) - John Morrison.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/123ab7ed-1c0b-4124-aab0-fe3ac1dfb48b/740 Tian Shan foothill arid steppe - AndreiGarm.jpg

children.content:
The Tian Shan-Pamir Grasslands, Mountain Steppe & Conifer Forests bioregion is part of the Tien Shan Mountains subrealm located in the Central Eurasia realm (central Palearctic). It contains five ecoregions—Tian Shan Montane Conifer Forests (709), Alai-Western Tian Shan Steppe (721), Gissaro-Alai Open Woodlands (730), Tian Shan Foothill Arid Steppe (740), Tian Shan Montane Steppe and Meadows (767)—totaling more than 73 million hectares of land area.

Learn more about each of the Tian Shan-Pamir Grasslands, Mountain Steppe & Conifer Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Tian Shan Montane Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: Surrounded by the desert basins of northern China, this ecoregion is an isolated, east-west trending mountain range

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/831159fc-e1a0-4f95-8915-da8241be28a7/709 Tian Shan montane conifer forests (Kyrgyzstan) - John Morrison.jpg

ecoregions.title: Tian Shan Foothill Arid Steppe
ecoregions.dek: The Tian Shan (Celestial Mountains) rises from the deserts and steppe basins of Inner Asia to form the largest temperate-arid mountain system on Earth.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/123ab7ed-1c0b-4124-aab0-fe3ac1dfb48b/740 Tian Shan foothill arid steppe - AndreiGarm.jpg

ecoregions.title: Gissaro-Alai Open Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion intersects five countries: Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan.

ecoregions.title: Alai-Western Tian Shan Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion spreads over five countries along lowland and loess plains.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1facfa2d-1142-42c0-8b5a-cfeb6a1fb67f/721 Alai-Western Tian Shan steppe - Сергей Юмагулов.jpg

ecoregions.title: Tian Shan Montane Steppe and Meadows
ecoregions.dek: The Tian Shan are separated from the Kunlun Mountains and the Tibetan Plateau by the broad, hyper-arid Tarim Basin and Taklimakan Desert.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8cc62abd-6850-491b-b031-7e6c3809a03d/767 Tian Shan Montane Steppe and Meadows Michael E cc.jpg

children.name: Caspian Sea, Coastal Deserts & Kopet Dagh Mountain Woodlands (PA33)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/bab941f6-952f-4305-8f23-8604bd61f8f8/812 Azerbaijan shrub desert and steppe - Kristian Ellis Wood.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2507ad68-f041-4c2f-ab90-f0d7eae111b0/756 Kopet Dag woodlands and forest steppe - Reza Babaeian.JPG

children.content:
The Caspian Sea, Coastal Deserts & Kopet Dagh Mountain Woodlands bioregion is part of the Caspian Sea & Central Asian Deserts subrealm located in the Central Eurasia realm (central Palearctic). It contains four ecoregions—Kopet Dag Woodlands and Forest Steppe (756), Azerbaijan Shrub Desert and Steppe (812), Caspian Lowland Desert (815), Kopet Dag Semi-Desert (829)—totaling approximately 41.5 million hectares of land area. 

Learn more about each of the Caspian Sea, Coastal Deserts & Kopet Dagh Mountain Woodlands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Kopet Dag Semi-Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies largely within Turkmenistan, reaching into a small area of Northeastern Iran. Fringing the magnificent Kopet Dag Mountains, it spans the transition zone between foothills and vast lowland desert.

ecoregions.title: Caspian Lowland Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies on the northern and eastern shores of the Caspian Sea following the coastlines of Russia, Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, and Iran.

ecoregions.title: Azerbaijan Shrub Desert and Steppe
ecoregions.dek: Seventy percent of this ecoregion lies within Azerbaijan, with the rest reaching into Southeast Georgia and Northwest Iran.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/bab941f6-952f-4305-8f23-8604bd61f8f8/812 Azerbaijan shrub desert and steppe - Kristian Ellis Wood.jpg

ecoregions.title: Kopet Dag Woodlands and Forest Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses the Kopet Dag—a chain of mountains stretching along the border of Iran and Turkmenistan.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2507ad68-f041-4c2f-ab90-f0d7eae111b0/756 Kopet Dag woodlands and forest steppe - Reza Babaeian.JPG

children.name: Central Asian Deserts & Riparian Woodlands (PA32)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/c201509d-a7ae-4962-8f2d-94b1a189074b/818 Central Asian riparian woodlands - Ю Данилевский.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b5ca8ca3-5cc1-4a1e-9774-b4428bbeadd8/819 Central Asian southern desert - David Stanley.jpg

children.content:
The Central Asian Deserts & Riparian Woodlands bioregion is part of the Caspian Sea & Central Asian Deserts subrealm located in the Central Eurasia realm (central Palearctic). It contains four ecoregions—Central Asian Northern Desert (817), Central Asian Riparian Woodlands (818), Central Asian Southern Desert (819), Kazakh Semi-Desert (828)—totaling approximately 200 million hectares of land area. 

Learn more about each of the Central Asian Deserts & Riparian Woodlands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Kazakh Semi-Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches from the Ural River to the west, encompassing the North Aral Sea in the southwest, to the Kazakh Uplands, a vast low-relief plain, in the central east, which has low mountain oases.

ecoregions.title: Central Asian Southern Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers two massive deserts, the Kyzylkum in Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan, and the Karakum in Turkmenistan.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b5ca8ca3-5cc1-4a1e-9774-b4428bbeadd8/819 Central Asian southern desert - David Stanley.jpg

ecoregions.title: Central Asian Riparian Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers four disjunct portions in Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan, and Kazakhstan.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/c201509d-a7ae-4962-8f2d-94b1a189074b/818 Central Asian riparian woodlands - Ю Данилевский.jpg

ecoregions.title: Central Asian Northern Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers disjunct areas mainly in Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan, with small parts in Kyrgyzstan and Turkmenistan.

children.name: Siberian Hemiboreal Forests & Steppe (PA35)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/862f167d-14cd-4c61-849c-2f01d40c3d06/687-Bugotak Hills Protected Area, Novosibirsk Oblast-CC-Седых Денис Александрович-2015_resized.jpg

children.content:
The Siberian Hemiboreal Forests & Steppe bioregion is part of the Kazakh Forest Steppes & Hemiboreal Forest subrealm located in the Central Eurasia realm (central Palearctic). It contains one ecoregion—Western Siberian Hemiboreal Forests (687).

Learn more about the Siberian Hemiboreal Forests & Steppe ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Western Siberian Hemiboreal Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion forms a latitudinal belt within the southern taiga zone of West Siberia.

children.name: Kazakh Forest Steppe & Grasslands (PA34)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/76a6ffaf-b1a9-4f0b-9eb3-6cdc010a9bb5/732- The steppes of central Kazakshtan (Akmola Province)-Eco732-CC-2007.jpg

children.content:
The Kazakh Forest Steppe & Grasslands bioregion is part of the Kazakh Steppes & Hemiboreal Forests subrealm located in the Central Eurasia realm (central Palearctic). It contains three ecoregions—Kazakh Forest Steppe (731), Kazakh Steppe (732), Kazakh Upland Steppe (733)—totaling approximately 130 million hectares of land area. 

Learn more about each of the Kazakh Forest Steppe & Grasslands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Kazakh Upland Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is composed of three separate areas: Kokchetau Uplands in northern Kazakhstan; Aktau, Ortau, and Karkaraly mountain area in central-eastern Kazakhstan; and Chingiztau mountain area to the east.

ecoregions.title: Kazakh Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This large ecoregion is bounded in the west by the Ural River, in the north and east by more humid forest steppe, and in the south by the Kazakh Semi-Desert ecoregion.

ecoregions.title: Kazakh Forest Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion forms a long, 150–250 km-wide band, stretching from the Ural Mountains to foothills of the Altai and Sayan Mountains.

children.name: Altai Mountain Forests, Grasslands & Desert Steppe (PA37)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/114f7588-5b90-4506-b9d5-021d0dbfb541/749 Altai alpine meadow and tundra - Jacqueline Macou.jpg

children.content:
The Altai Mountains & Ermin Valley bioregion is part of the Altai-Sayan Mountains subrealm located in the Central Eurasia realm (central Palearctic) and contains four ecoregions—Altai Montane Forest and Forest Steppe [690], Altai Steppe and Semi-Desert [724], Emin Valley Steppe [728], Altai Alpine Meadow and Tundra [749]. 

Learn more about each of the Altai Mountains & Ermin Valley ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Emin Valley Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion straddles the Kazakhstan-China border along the north slope of the Tian Shan mountain range.

ecoregions.title: Altai Alpine Meadow and Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies above conifer forest treeline, occupying the headwaters of two of Siberia’s greatest rivers, the Ob and the Irtysh.

ecoregions.title: Altai Steppe and Semi-Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion forms a transition between the forests of the Altai Mountain ecoregions to the north and east and the Kazakh desert plain to the west.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/aec7f697-b695-46ce-b173-a38c5edc87da/724 Altai steppe and semi-desert - Dimitry A Mottl.jpg

ecoregions.title: Altai Montane Forest and Forest Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion traces the Altai Mountains southeastward, dividing arid basins of Inner Asia from Siberian river systems that drain to the Arctic.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2bffe339-f8fb-4d51-a544-43d4872f1dbf/690 Altai montane forest and forest steppe - svetlanavic.jpg

children.name: Sayan Mountain Conifer Forests, Alpine Meadows & Steppe (PA36)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f38bc8ac-6b24-4656-9fbf-0fd1a3f39aed/736-Confluence of the Kaa-Kem and Pii-Kem Rivers-CC-2015.jpg

children.content:
The Sayan Mountains & Siberian Forest Steppe Bioregion bioregion is part of the Altai-Sayan Mountains subrealm located in the Central Eurasia realm (central Palearctic) and contains four ecoregions—Sayan Montane Conifer Forests (707), Sayan Intermontane Steppe (736), South Siberian Forest Steppe (738), Sayan Alpine Meadows and Tundra (764).

Learn more about each of the Sayan Mountain Conifer Forests, Alpine Meadows & Steppe ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Sayan Alpine Meadows and Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers areas above the tree line between the Altai Mountains and Lake Baikal in Russia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f4706cf0-8c71-43be-b6f2-a65d48b6362f/764 Sayan alpine meadows and tundra - Kanenori.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sayan Intermontane Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is found between ridges of the Tannu-Ola mountains to the south and the Western Sayan mountains to the north, within the Central Tuva Depression.

ecoregions.title: Sayan Montane Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is situated on the boundary between Siberian taiga forest and Central Asian desert, comprising the mid-elevations of the highest mountains in Siberia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/992e023e-f1d4-4f91-b8f3-12524c348d21/707 Sayan montane conifer forests - Daniel Bellinson.jpg

ecoregions.title: South Siberian Forest Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is made up of four patches of a mix of grasslands and sparse forest in a thin band of lowland terrain.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7b90c147-0d85-4143-9983-920db76826a1/738 South Siberian forest steppe - Pascal Chauffeton.JPG

children.name: Greater Gobi Desert (PA43)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/083aa25d-0a25-44cc-84a2-316b007751d5/825 Great Lakes Basin desert steppe - Jacqueline Macou.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8b4c0402-5c2f-46eb-8de0-a7fa2dd8d2da/824 Eastern Gobi desert steppe (Ikh Nart Natural Reserve Mongolia) - John Morrison.jpg

children.content:
The Mongolian Desert Steppes bioregion is located in the East Asian Desert subrealm. It contains three ecoregions–Eastern Gobi Desert Steppe (824), Gobi Lakes Valley Desert Steppe (825), Great Lakes Basin Desert Steppe (826)—totaling nearly 110 million hectares of land area.

Learn more about each of the Mongolian Desert Steppes ecoregions below.

children.name: Taklimakan Desert & Lowland Deciduous Forests (PA39)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f3ef5d16-5a7e-4d7b-9eea-969fbcec95c2/684 Tarim Basin deciduous forests and steppe -Michael Manning.jpg

children.content:
The Taklimakan Desert & Lowland Deciduous Forests bioregion is located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic) and contains two ecoregions – Tarim Basin Deciduous Forests and Steppe (684), Taklimakan Desert (843) – totaling approximately 80 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Taklimakan Desert & Lowland Deciduous Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Taklimakan Desert
ecoregions.dek: Encircled by tall mountains near the geographic center of Eurasia, the Taklamakan Desert is deprived of moisture from all sources—monsoonal, westerly, and Arctic.

ecoregions.title: Tarim Basin Deciduous Forests and Steppe
ecoregions.dek: Situated across Xinjiang, China, the Tarim Basin is further from the ocean than any other place in the world, with high mountains blocking both the Asian monsoon and westerly winter storms.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f3ef5d16-5a7e-4d7b-9eea-969fbcec95c2/684 Tarim Basin deciduous forests and steppe -Michael Manning.jpg

children.name: Junggar Semi-Desert & Ermin Valley Steppe (PA38)
children.content:
The Junggar Semi-Desert & Ermin Valley Steppe bioregion is located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic) and contains two ecoregions – Emin Valley Steppe (728), Junggar Basin Semi-Desert (827) – totaling approximately 37 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Junggar Semi-Desert & Ermin Valley Steppe ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Great Lakes Basin Desert Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This huge depression is bounded by the Mongolian Altai mountains to the west, Gobi Altai mountains to the south, Tannu Ola mountains to the north, and the Sangilen and Khangai ranges to the west.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7af19e85-45ed-41fd-89de-8d5cfc21f4c9/826 Great Lakes Basin desert steppe - Александр Лещёнок.jpg

ecoregions.title: Junggar Basin Semi-Desert
ecoregions.dek: The Junggar Basin is one of the great intermontane basins of Central Asia. Situated between the Tian Shan and Altai mountain ranges, it supports a vast expanse of semi-desert habitat.

ecoregions.title: Gobi Lakes Valley Desert Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion sits between the Khangai Mountains and the eastern end of the Mongolian Altai mountain range, covering the eastern end of the Gobi Altai mountains, including their highest peak, Ikh Bogd, 3,957m tall.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/083aa25d-0a25-44cc-84a2-316b007751d5/825 Great Lakes Basin desert steppe - Jacqueline Macou.jpg

ecoregions.title: Eastern Gobi Desert Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers an area of 282,369 km2 and extends from the Inner Mongolian plateau in northern China and Mongolia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8b4c0402-5c2f-46eb-8de0-a7fa2dd8d2da/824 Eastern Gobi desert steppe (Ikh Nart Natural Reserve Mongolia) - John Morrison.jpg

ecoregions.title: Alashan Plateau Semi-Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses the Helan Mountains to the East, Quilian Mountains the West, and the Tibetan Plateau to the south, both in China.

children.name: Tibetan-Pamir Alpine Steppes, Shrublands & Mountain Forests (PA41)
children.content:
The Tibetan-Pamir Alpine Steppes, Shrublands & Mountain Forests bioregion is part of the Tibetan Plateau subrealm located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic). It contains eight ecoregions—Northeastern Himalayan Subalpine Conifer Forests (702), Eastern Himalayan Alpine Shrub and Meadows (751), Hindu Kush Alpine Meadow (753), Karakoram-West Tibetan Plateau Alpine Steppe (754), Northwestern Himalayan Alpine Shrub and Meadows (760), Pamir Alpine Desert and Tundra (762) Western Himalayan Alpine Shrub and Meadows (769), Yarlung Zanbo Arid Steppe (770).

Learn more about each of the Tibetan-Pamir Alpine Steppes, Shrublands & Mountain Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Karakoram-West Tibetan Plateau Alpine Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies within the catchment of the upper Indus River where it is shadowed from rain by the Karakoram and the northwestern Himalayan mountain ranges.

ecoregions.title: Yarlung Zanbo Arid Steppe
ecoregions.dek: The Yarlung Zanbo valley is situated at a lower elevation than other parts of the Tibetan Plateau and is further warmed during summer by föhn winds that descend the north slope of the Himalaya.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/4dc88a95-5e6c-44f9-b684-1549ae2c7814/770 Yarlung Zanbo Arid Steppe Gerd Eichmann cc.jpg

ecoregions.title: Western Himalayan Alpine Shrub and Meadows
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the alpine meadows and shrublands between 3,000 and 5,000 m in the western Himalaya, from the Kali Gandaki River gorge in Nepal to the Indian State of Uttar Pradesh.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e31b395e-741f-4b21-96f9-7488d1e44333/769 Western Himalayan alpine shrub and meadows - Araghu.JPG

ecoregions.title: Pamir Alpine Desert and Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes broad valleys and steeply rolling hills with an ecological and physiographic similarity to the Tibetan Plateau, that are instead situated at a mean elevation of about 4,200 m, substantially lower (and warmer) than the high basins of northwestern Tibet.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7585f8b0-f566-4cc9-8568-aa7e8c7c866a/762 Pamir alpine desert and tundra - Brian Harrington Spier.jpg

ecoregions.title: Northwestern Himalayan Alpine Shrub and Meadows
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents a narrow band of alpine scrub and meadows between 3,300 and 3,600 m, especially in the Vale of Kashmir.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/251f59e9-81b4-4021-883f-a9037314f009/760 Northwestern Himalayan alpine shrub and meadows - Tahsin A Shah.jpg

ecoregions.title: Hindu Kush Alpine Meadow
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion forms part of the western Hindu Kush Himalayas in Afghanistan and is bordered by Pakistan in the east and Tajikistan in the north.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7f7a173f-9197-42cb-b61d-7b93c99a1025/753 Hindu Kush alpine meadow - Falk Oberdorf.png

ecoregions.title: Eastern Himalayan Alpine Shrub and Meadows
