ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is atop the roof of the world, surrounding the highest mountain peaks on Earth; Everest—locally known as Sagarmatha—Makalu, Dhaulagiri, and Jomalhari.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e4942a05-3527-4be6-8ad3-86aa3504bc62/751 Eastern Himalayan alpine shrub and meadows - skeeze.jpg

ecoregions.title: Northeastern Himalayan Subalpine Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupy slopes of the Zangbo Gorge, the deepest river valley on Earth.⁠

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1c366642-db07-43f8-862b-91131e23cde8/702 Northeast Himalayan subalpine conifer forests - 元江 李.jpg

children.name: Greater Tibetan Plateau Alpine Meadows & Shrublands (PA40)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/016ccab3-48d6-4b0a-95c8-407dec3d2561/750 Central Tibetan Plateau alpine steppe - yuxiu0702.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/893ce247-66c7-45fa-a6ce-7eb2d243e594/759 North Tibetan Plateau-Kunlun Mountains Alpine Desert Nick Kent-Basham cc.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a8e54b8f-1ac6-4085-b274-fbd0a7b2db3b/768 Tibetan Plateau Alpine Shrublands and Meadows Chen Zhi cc.jpg

children.content:
The Greater Tibetan Plateau Alpine Meadows & Shrublands bioregion is part of the Tibetan Plateau subrealm located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic). It contains seven ecoregions—Qilian Mountains Conifer Forests (705),  Central Tibetan Plateau Alpine Steppe (750), North Tibetan Plateau-Kunlun Mountains Alpine Desert (759), Qilian Mountains Subalpine Meadows (763), Southeast Tibet Shrublands and Meadows (765), Tibetan Plateau Alpine Shrublands and Meadows (768), Qaidam Basin Semi-Desert (835)—totaling more than 202 million hectares of land area. 

Learn more about each of the Greater Tibetan Plateau Alpine Meadows & Shrublands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Southeast Tibet Shrublands and Meadows
ecoregions.dek: Abutting the highest mountain range in the world, the southeastern Tibetan Plateau supports an exceptionally moist alpine habitats.

ecoregions.title: Qilian Mountains Subalpine Meadows
ecoregions.dek: The Qilian Mountains crest along the northeastern rim of the Tibet Plateau at elevations over 5,500 m.

ecoregions.title: Qilian Mountains Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Qilian Mountains rise to 5,500 m elevation along the northeastern margin of the Tibetan Plateau, providing snowmelt to desert oases at the foot of the range.

ecoregions.title: Qaidam Basin Semi-Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies a tectonic depression, or graben, that slumps between the Tibet Plateau, the Altun mountain range, and the western part of the rapidly uplifting Qilian mountain range.

ecoregions.title: Tibetan Plateau Alpine Shrublands and Meadows
ecoregions.dek: Alpine shrublands and meadows extend 1,500 km across the central part of the Tibetan Plateau from the Tsangpo river valley near Lhasa to the Qilian Mountains in the far northeast.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/95ebbda6-221c-48cd-8637-af354bbd4aa8/768 Tibetan Plateau alpine shrublands and meadows - Luo Shaoyang.jpg

ecoregions.title: North Tibetan Plateau-Kunlun Mountains Alpine Desert
ecoregions.dek: The vast Tibetan Plateau supports a range of alpine habitats, of which the most extreme environments are located in the northwest where precipitation is scant, temperatures are frigid, and elevations exceed 4,800 m for hundreds of kilometers in all directions.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/062172e0-37c4-4fc6-b9e5-c7b1d583de6d/759 North Tibetan Plateau-Kunlun Mountains alpine desert - Nick Kent-Basham.jpg

ecoregions.title: Central Tibetan Plateau Alpine Steppe
ecoregions.dek: Between the monsoon-affected southeast and the frigid, desiccated northwest lies this ecoregion, hundreds of thousands of square kilometers of steppe meadow, where individual small plants are typically separated by bare earth.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1dccd1ee-ca00-4316-a708-344c8151e890/750 Central Tibetan Plateau Alpine Steppe Slyvannus cc.jpg

children.name: Mongolian Grasslands, Alpine Meadows & Forest Steppe (PA44)
children.content:
The Mongolian Grasslands, Alpine Meadows & Forest Steppe bioregion is located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic) and contains six ecoregions – Khangai Mountains Conifer Forests (700), Daurian Forest Steppe (726), Mongolian-Manchurian Grassland (734), Selenge-Orkhon Forest Steppe (737), Nenjiang River Grassland (743), Khangai Mountains Alpine Meadow (755) – totaling approximately 139 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Mongolian Grasslands, Alpine Meadows & Forest Steppe ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Khangai Mountains Alpine Meadow
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses a mosaic of habitats at the highest altitudes of Mongolia’s central Khangai mountain range.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/cfa47378-a6b4-48fd-9728-b8744ca6cf8c/755 Khangai Mountains alpine meadow - Andre Felbrich.jpg

ecoregions.title: Nenjiang River Grassland
ecoregions.dek: The Nenjiang River originates in the Khingan mountain range, near the eastern end of the Mongolian Plateau, then flows to the lowlands of central Manchuria in northeastern China.

ecoregions.title: Selenge-Orkhon Forest Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the basins of the Tesiin Gol River, which runs to the west; the Selenge River, which run north east to Lake Baikal; and its major tributary, the Orkhon River.

ecoregions.title: Mongolian-Manchurian Grassland
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is one of the largest, most intact grassland ecosystems on Earth, lying between Siberian conifer forests, Central Asian rocky deserts, and the Manchurian hills of Northeastern China.

ecoregions.title: Khangai Mountains Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is restricted to a narrow northern strip of the Khangai Mountain range of Mongolia, where dense conifer forests grow on the northern aspect of mountain slopes.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/6ea5df19-9c39-48f8-a22b-85522afdf3d1/700 Khangai Mountains conifer forests - Báthory Péter.jpg

ecoregions.title: Daurian Forest Steppe
ecoregions.dek: Mongolia’s Daurian Forest Steppe ecoregion covers the northern part of the UNESCO-designated ‘Landscapes of Dauria’, a majestic reach of forest and steppe-grassland that extends across northeastern Mongolia into southern Siberia.

children.name: Ordos Plateau Steppe & Mountain Conifer Forests (PA42)
children.content:
The Ordos Plateau Steppe & Mountain Conifer Forests bioregion is located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic) and contains two ecoregions – Helanshan Montane Conifer Forests (696), Ordos Plateau Steppe (761) – totaling approximately 24 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Ordos Plateau Steppe & Mountain Conifer Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Ordos Plateau Steppe
ecoregions.dek: The Ordos Plateau lies within the Great Bend of the Huang He (Yellow River) in China.

ecoregions.title: Helanshan Montane Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Helanshan mountain range projects northward for about 180 km from the Tibet-Qinghai Plateau in China.

children.name: Korean Peninsula Mixed Forests (PA48)
children.content:
The Korean Peninsula Mixed Forests bioregion is located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic) and contains two ecoregions – Central Korean Deciduous Forests (655), Southern Korea Evergreen Forests (681) – totaling approximately 12 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Korean Peninsula Mixed Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Central Korean Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies most of the Korean Peninsula, apart from the southern coastal margin and the hilly north.

ecoregions.title: Southern Korea Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: The climate and environmental conditions of the southern margin of the Korean Peninsula and Jeju Island support warm-temperate evergreen broadleaf forest.⁠

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/9968dad6-6a1a-4852-8df3-73888306cf33/681 Southern Korea evergreen forests - Yi Jo.jpg

children.name: Manchuria-Ussuri Mixed Forests & Meadow Steppes (PA46)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/721e456b-5b57-4a9d-9bbf-6560e5a4566c/673 Qin Ling Mountains deciduous forests - Charlie439753.jpg

children.content:
The Manchuria-Ussuri Mixed Forests & Meadow Steppes bioregion is located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic) and contains six ecoregions – Changbai Mountains Mixed Forests (656), Manchurian Mixed Forests (669), Northeast China Plain Deciduous Forests (673), Ussuri Broadleaf and Mixed Forests (685), Amur Meadow Steppe (741), Suiphun-Khanka Meadows and Forest Meadows (746)  – totaling approximately 118.5 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Manchuria-Ussuri Mixed Forests & Meadow Steppes ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Suiphun-Khanka Meadows and Forest Meadows
ecoregions.dek: Lake Khanka sits astride the China-Russia border in the center of this ecoregion, which is composed of lowlands surrounding 25 rivers.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/35a2846b-d5c4-4aba-9aa5-c360f385c442/746 Suiphun-Khanka meadows and forest meadows - Берег_Ханки.jpg

ecoregions.title: Amur Meadow Steppe
ecoregions.dek: The expansive rivers, Amur and Songhua, wind through the vast, open plains of this ecoregion.

ecoregions.title: Ussuri Broadleaf and Mixed Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is found just north of the Amur River, which swings northwards through the ecoregion, east of the Ussuri River on the gentle western slopes of the Sikhote-Alin Mountains, and on the steep eastern slopes of the Sikhote-Alin to the coast of the Sea of Japan.

ecoregions.title: Changbai Mountains Mixed Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion spans across northern North Korea and north-eastern China.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7b76a6f1-f7c7-46f5-b63d-c86f2f797a69/656 Changbai Mountains mixed forests - Uwe Brodrecht CCO2.jpg

ecoregions.title: Northeast China Plain Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Northeast China Plain deciduous forests ecoregion follows the Liao river upstream from the Bay of Bohai, crosses a low watershed divide into the Songhua river, and extends to the confluence of the Songhua with the Heilongjiang (Amur) River on the Russian frontier.

ecoregions.title: Manchurian Mixed Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Manchurian Mixed Forests ecoregion is affected by a cold continental airflow from interior Asia that brings dry, frigid conditions during winter.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/d208cc34-7223-4917-88b7-23b9872a9e20/669 Manchurian mixed forests - Uwe Brodrecht CCO2.jpg

children.name: Dzhagdy Mountain Conifer Forests (PA45)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/d3fc3944-15fc-40ef-bad9-211c94314fe3/693 Da Hinggan-Dzhagdy Mountains Conifer Forests cc.jpg

children.content:
The Dzhagdy Mountain Conifer Forests bioregion is located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic) and contains one single ecoregion – Da Hinggan-Dzhagdy Mountains Conifer Forests (693)  – totaling nearly 25 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the Dzhagdy Mountain Conifer Forests ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Da Hinggan-Dzhagdy Mountains Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: Western interior reaches of the Da Hinggan (Khingan) mountain range of Chinese Inner Mongolia extend north to the Dzhagdy Mountains of Russia, an eastern extension of the great Altai mountain system.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/04894b1f-2170-4a46-aa24-589e627aedc8/693 Da Hinggan-Dzhagdy Mountains conifer forests - heteroscedascity.JPG

children.name: Japan Forest Islands (PA47)
children.content:
The Japan Forest Islands bioregion is located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic) and contains seven ecoregions – Hokkaido Deciduous Forests (666), Nihonkai Evergreen Forests (670), Nihonkai Montane Deciduous Forests (671), Taiheiyo Evergreen Forests (682), Taiheiyo Montane Deciduous Forests (683), Hokkaido Montane Conifer Forests (698), Honshu Alpine Conifer Forests (699)  – totaling approximately 38 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Japan Forest Islands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Honshu Alpine Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers several areas of alpine vegetation amidst montane deciduous forests areas in Northern Honshu (Japan's main island) and Southern Hokkaido islands.

ecoregions.title: Hokkaido Montane Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Hokkaido Montane Conifer Forests ecoregion is located on Japan's northernmost volcanic Island of Hokkaido, the country's second-largest island.

ecoregions.title: Taiheiyo Montane Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This mountainous ecoregion extends from Kyushu island in the south of Japan to the northeastern coast of Honshu, with a small section on Shikoku island.

ecoregions.title: Taiheiyo Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses areas across several of Japan’s major islands, stretching from Kyushu and Shikoku in the south to the western coast of Honshu further north.

ecoregions.title: Nihonkai Montane Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This mountainous ecoregion lies predominantly within Japan’s largest island—Honshu—with a small section in the southerly tip of Hokkaido beneath the Kuromatsunai line.

ecoregions.title: Nihonkai Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses much of the west coast of Honshu—Japan’s largest island—from the city of Hamada in the south to Yurihonjo in the north.

ecoregions.title: Hokkaido Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers 36,301 km2 of lowland temperate deciduous forests mostly on Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost island.

children.name: Hengduan Mountain Conifer Forests (PA53)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/73c6de83-2579-4d78-bfac-8b05634f693d/697 Hengduan Mountains subalpine conifer forests - littleP.jpg

children.content:
The Hengduan Mountain Conifer Forests bioregion includes a group of parallel mountain ranges that connect the southeast portion of the Tibetan Plateau with the Yunnan-Guizhou Plateau in southwest China. These forested mountains are defined by three rivers -- the Yangtze, Mekong, and Salween -- and are recognized today as the Three Parallel Rivers UNESCO World Heritage Site, one of the most biologically diverse temperate region on Earth, home to 6,000 plant species, 173 mammal species, and 417 bird species, many of which are endemic to the region. This bioregion contains three ecoregions — Hengduan Mountains Subalpine Conifer Forests (697), Nujiang Lancang Gorge Subalpine Conifer and Mixed Forests (704), Qionglai-Minshan Conifer Forests (706) — totaling over 26 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Hengduan Mountain Conifer Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Qionglai-Minshan Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: As tectonic forces push Eastern Tibet against the rigid continental crust of the Sichuan Basin, steep mountain escarpments have cropped up to form the Qionglai-Minshan mountain system.

ecoregions.title: Nujiang Lancang Gorge Subalpine Conifer and Mixed Forests
ecoregions.dek: Several parallel river gorges, separated by steep mountain ridges, divide the Yunnan Plateau of China from the eastern Himalaya.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/352d44bf-d7a1-45d6-8953-b257b049a54b/704 Nujiang Langcang Gorge alpine conifer and mixed forests - Rhett Butler.jpg

ecoregions.title: Hengduan Mountains Subalpine Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Hengduan mountain system, the most biologically diverse temperate region on Earth, forms a landscape of deep river gorges and tall dividing ranges at the southeastern margin of the Tibet Plateau.

children.name: Guizhou & Yunnan Subtropical Forest Plateaus (PA52)
children.content:
The Guizhou & Yunnan Subtropical Forest Plateaus bioregion is located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic) and contains two ecoregions – Guizhou Plateau Broadleaf and Mixed Forests (642), Yunnan Plateau Subtropical Evergreen Forests (643) – totaling approximately 51 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Guizhou & Yunnan Subtropical Forest Plateaus ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Yunnan Plateau Subtropical Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Yunnan Plateau, literally “South of the Clouds,” is a transition from the monsoon tropics of Indochina to the eastern Himalayan region.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8c05d1e7-32fc-4fa2-ad2f-e79e30d39368/643 Yunnan Plateau subtropical evergreen forests - 简体中文.jpg

ecoregions.title: Guizhou Plateau Broadleaf and Mixed Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Guizhou Plateau lies at an elevation of 1,000 to 1,400 m and comprises a rugged landscape of block-shaped limestone hills separated by steep-walled basins; it is part of a geological realm called the South China Karst.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f2eaed04-aa1e-4d9e-a8ba-c8dece24f6b8/642 Guizhou Plateau broadleaf and mixed forests - Vined.jpg

children.name: Sichuan Basin & Central Mountain Forests (PA51)
children.content:
The Sichuan Basin & Central Mountain Forests bioregion is located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic) and contains three ecoregions – Daba Mountains Evergreen Forests (659), Qin Ling Mountains Deciduous Forests (677), Sichuan Basin Evergreen Broadleaf Forests (680)  – totaling approximately 39 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Sichuan Basin & Central Mountain Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Sichuan Basin Evergreen Broadleaf Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Sichuan Basin is a fertile expanse of low hills and plains almost entirely encircled by mountains: the Tibet Plateau to the west, karst limestone uplands to the south, row upon row of rugged hills to the north and east, cut through by the Chang Jiang.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e8f7720d-7e66-4462-a371-b859d1df41b3/680 Sichuan Basin evergreen broadleaf forests - fannyss 1.jpg

ecoregions.title: Daba Mountains Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Daba Mountains have the most extensive primary forests remaining in central China.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/68f6f08b-2362-4ac1-9e4f-e1f33620000c/659 Daba Mountains evergreen forests - 中 彭 cq19690527.jpg

ecoregions.title: Qin Ling Mountains Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Qinling Mountains first formed more than 200 million years ago as a suture zone where the tectonic plate of Southern China, moving north, accreted to the Asian continent.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/261f7ce8-e70d-4f3f-9710-59771c942614/677 Qin Ling Mountains deciduous forests - Charlie Yan.jpg

children.name: Chang Jiang Plain Evergreen Forests (PA50)
children.content:
The Chang Jiang Plain Evergreen Forests bioregion is located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic) and contains two ecoregions – Changjiang Plain Evergreen Forests (657), Yellow Sea Saline Meadow (748) – totaling approximately 44.5 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Chang Jiang Plain Evergreen Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Yellow Sea Saline Meadow
ecoregions.dek: One reach of coastal saline meadow, the Yancheng coastline, extends northward from the mouth of the Yangtze River towards the Shandong Peninsula, holding the Yellow Sea Saline Meadow ecoregion.

ecoregions.title: Changjiang Plain Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is delineated to the south and west by the mountainous uplands of southern China; to the north, it is separated from the plains of the Huang He by a low watershed divide.

children.name: Loess Plateau & Huang He Plain Mixed Forests (PA49)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/0c0ca624-a301-4ad6-aaff-7494ae02c676/653 Central China Loess Plateau Mixed Forests Rheins CC.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5a171d27-d954-404a-8b64-d77239f7bb2f/667 Huang He Plain mixed forests - Alex Ansley.jpg

children.content:
The Loess Plateau & Huang He Plain Mixed Forests bioregion is located in the Eastern Eurasia realm (eastern Palearctic) and contains three ecoregions – Central China Loess Plateau Mixed Forests (653), Huang He Plain Mixed Forests (667), Bohai Sea Saline Meadow (742) – totaling nearly 81 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Eastern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Loess Plateau & Huang He Plain Mixed Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Bohai Sea Saline Meadow
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies a crescent of the Chinese coast that faces the northern part of the Yellow Sea, north of the Shandong Peninsula.

ecoregions.title: Huang He Plain Mixed Forests
ecoregions.dek: Spreading across northeastern China, the Huang He Plain Mixed Forests ecoregion widens eastward as the floodplains that define it become broader towards the coast of the Yellow Sea.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5a171d27-d954-404a-8b64-d77239f7bb2f/667 Huang He Plain mixed forests - Alex Ansley.jpg

ecoregions.title: Central China Loess Plateau Mixed Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Central China Loess Plateau, northwest of the Yellow River Basin, forms a transition zone between the maritime-influenced ecoregions of eastern China and the steppes and deserts of Mongolia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1c6087a6-d142-407e-bf75-e7f2947ed04f/653 Central China Loess Plateau mixed forests - panayota.jpg

children.name: Borneo Tropical Forests & Sundaland Heath Forests (IM16)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/01873293-74a7-4cfb-8a7a-dd883341ef83/Borneo peat swamp forest Ruanda Agung SugardimanAusAID CC.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1aedb2af-8e1d-431b-89d9-f75c59cde2a0/313 Kinabalu montane alpine meadows - John Morrison.jpg

children.content:
The Borneo Tropical Forests & Sundaland Heath Forests bioregion is located in the Southeast Asian Forests subrealm of Indomalaya and contains six terrestrial ecoregions – Borneo Lowland Rainforests (219), Borneo Montane Rainforests (220), Borneo Peat Swamp Forests  (221), Southwest Borneo Freshwater Swamp Forests (273), Sundaland Heath Forests (281), Kinabalu Montane Alpine Meadows (313) – along with the Sunda Shelf Mangroves (322) totaling approximately nearly 75 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Borneo Tropical Forests & Sundaland Heath Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Sunda Shelf Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lines the coasts of the islands of Borneo and Sumatra, astride the geologically active fault known as the ‘Ring of Fire’ that arcs around the Pacific Ocean.

ecoregions.title: Kinabalu Montane Alpine Meadows
ecoregions.dek: Straddling the 4,095 m peak of Mount Kinabalu that towers above the vast tropical rainforests of Borneo, this ecoregion represents the alpine and subalpine meadows and shrublands of the Kinabalu and Crocker ranges.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1aedb2af-8e1d-431b-89d9-f75c59cde2a0/313 Kinabalu montane alpine meadows - John Morrison.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sundaland Heath Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is made up of the forests growing on patches of white-sand soils on sandstone plateaus and ridges, and beaches raised from the seabed which have well-drained acidic soils that leach nutrients.

ecoregions.title: Southwest Borneo Freshwater Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the freshwater swamp forests that line the southern and western coast of Borneo in Indonesian Kalimantan.

ecoregions.title: Borneo Peat Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the peat swamps along the coasts of Borneo and around the clusters of inland lakes associated with the Mahakam and Kapuas rivers.

ecoregions.title: Borneo Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion representing the montane forests along the central spine of Borneo has been described as a montane archipelago in an ocean of lowland dipterocarp forests.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/75b81322-6d11-4233-a560-f31801362811/220 Borneo montane rain forests - Paul White.jpg

ecoregions.title: Borneo Lowland Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: The biodiversity of Borneo’s rainforests is among the richest in the world, rivalling forests of New Guinea and the Amazon.

children.name: Peninsular Malaysian & Sumatran Tropical Rainforests (IM18)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/77eba7c7-c586-4f6e-bf4e-4bb57c103b6b/278 Sumatran lowland rain forests - R Butler.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8c0d6d26-9011-416c-b95c-71023e9541a3/263 Peninsular Malaysian montane rain forests - John Morrison.jpg

children.content:
The Peninsular Malaysian & Sumatran Tropical Rainforests bioregion is located in the Southeast Asian Forests subrealm of Indomalaya and contains ten ecoregions – Mentawai Islands Rainforests (245), Sumatran Montane Rainforests (279), Sumatran Lowland Rainforests (278), Sumatran Tropical Pine Forests (305), Sumatran Freshwater Swamp Forests (277), Sumatran Peat Swamp Forests (280), Peninsular Malaysian Rainforests (265), Peninsular Malaysian Peat Swamp Forests (264), Peninsular Malaysian Montane Rainforests (263), Sunda Shelf Mangroves (322) — totaling nearly 62 million hectares of land area with extensive surrounding marine areas. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Peninsular Malaysian & Sumatran Tropical Rainforests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Sumatran Tropical Pine Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion consists of five discrete patches of tropical pine forests scattered across the mountain range and embedded within the montane broadleaf forests of Sumatra.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e27440f8-cdb7-4a7a-a273-c368f43b7a4e/305 Sumatran tropical pine forests - Mohd Fahmi.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sumatran Peat Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Sumatran Peat Swamp Forests lie along the southeastern coast of Sumatra.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f48ba44a-2110-4154-8be2-40a28652e8c0/280 Sumatran peat swamp forests - James Maiden CIFOR.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sumatran Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the forests above 1,000 m in elevation along the Barisan Mountain Range that runs the length of Sumatra.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/23932304-20aa-4f5d-bdad-fefe30277beb/279 Sumatran montane rain forests - Nomo Michael Hoefner.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sumatran Lowland Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the lowland rainforests of Sumatra.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/77eba7c7-c586-4f6e-bf4e-4bb57c103b6b/278 Sumatran lowland rain forests - R Butler.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sumatran Freshwater Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the disjunct patches of freshwater swamp forests adjacent to the peat swamp forests in eastern Sumatra.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/54ef5c75-75b0-4710-b965-141d156d6994/277 Sumatran freshwater swamp forests - Rhett Butler.jpg

ecoregions.title: Peninsular Malaysian Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the lowland moist forests of peninsular Malaysia, with small sections extending into southern Thailand.

ecoregions.title: Peninsular Malaysian Peat Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is located along the coastal regions of Peninsular Malaysia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8cdb6116-4ef7-46b6-a128-e572a431f608/Peninsular Malaysian Peat Swamp Forests Frostpolar CC.jpg

ecoregions.title: Peninsular Malaysian Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the montane forests in central peninsular Malaysia, barely extending to the southernmost areas of Thailand.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8c0d6d26-9011-416c-b95c-71023e9541a3/263 Peninsular Malaysian montane rain forests - John Morrison.jpg

ecoregions.title: Mentawai Islands Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the islands 80 to 120 km off the western coast of Sumatra.

ecoregions.title: Sunda Shelf Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lines the coasts of the islands of Borneo and Sumatra, astride the geologically active fault known as the ‘Ring of Fire’ that arcs around the Pacific Ocean.

children.name: Javan-Bali Tropical Rainforests (IM17)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/d259e213-5467-4c47-a541-6bff3f770675/289 Western Java rain forests - Achmad Soerio Hutomo.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/fb100d16-4d48-490f-8ceb-dc47f2d7cf75/229 Eastern Java-Bali montane rain forests - Aknafi.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1329bd96-a64b-4f7f-b52a-727dad51bdb5/288 Western Java montane rain forests (Mt Salak) - John Morrison.jpg

children.content:
The Javan-Bali Tropical Rainforests bioregion is located in the Southeast Asian Forests subrealm of Indomalaya and contains five ecoregions – Christmas and Cocos Islands Tropical Forests (227), Eastern Java-Bali Montane Rainforests (229), Eastern Java-Bali Rainforests (230), Western Java Montane Rainforests (288), Western Java Rainforests (289) – totaling nearly 14 million hectares of land area with extensive surrounding marine areas. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Javan-Bali Tropical Rainforests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Western Java Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the lowland rainforests of western and central Java, an Indonesian island along the famous Ring of Fire that defines the seismically active border of the northward-drifting Pacific Plate.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/d259e213-5467-4c47-a541-6bff3f770675/289 Western Java rain forests - Achmad Soerio Hutomo.jpg

ecoregions.title: Western Java Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the montane forests of West and Central Java.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1329bd96-a64b-4f7f-b52a-727dad51bdb5/288 Western Java montane rain forests (Mt Salak) - John Morrison.jpg

ecoregions.title: Eastern Java-Bali Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the lowland moist forests of the eastern half of the island of Java and Bali, and the smaller islands off the northern coasts of both.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/ca760740-9ca9-410c-9e15-7d930cad2c7e/230 Eastern Java-Bali rain forests - Rochmad Setyadi.jpg

ecoregions.title: Eastern Java–Bali Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents forests along the central mountains of eastern Java and Bali, comprised of a row of about twenty active and dormant volcanos.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/fb100d16-4d48-490f-8ceb-dc47f2d7cf75/229 Eastern Java-Bali montane rain forests - Aknafi.jpg

ecoregions.title: Christmas and Cocos Islands Tropical Forests
ecoregions.dek: Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands are two peaks of ancient submarine volcanos that rise over 5,000 m from the Indian Ocean floor, now peeking out the ocean surface.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b08d589f-4401-47cc-9a37-146ef394e219/227 Christmas and Cocos Islands tropical forests - Michael Seebeck.jpg

children.name: Greater Deccan-Sri Lankan Forests & Drylands (IM8)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a07cf933-bf4a-4779-b92a-8141152b45d1/297 North Deccan dry deciduous forests - Theasg sap.JPG

children.content:
The Greater Deccan-Sri Lankan Forests & Drylands bioregion is located within the Indian Subcontinent subrealm in Indomalaya and contains six ecoregions – Central Deccan Plateau Dry Deciduous Forests [1], Deccan Thorn Scrub Forests [2], South Deccan Plateau Dry Deciduous Forests [3], East Deccan Dry-Evergreen Forests [4], Sri Lanka Dry-Zone Dry Evergreen Forests [5], Godavari-Krishna Mangroves [6] – totaling approximately 73 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Greater Deccan-Sri Lankan Forests & Drylands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Godavari-Krishna Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends as a narrow band along the middle-region coast of the Indian subcontinent. It forms larger patches in the estuaries of the Godavari and Krishna rivers.

ecoregions.title: Deccan Thorn Scrub Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the low, sparse thorn scrub vegetation in the arid parts of the Deccan Plateau.

ecoregions.title: Sri Lanka Dry-Zone Dry Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the tropical dry forests throughout most of Sri Lanka.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/18d9c759-8fed-444c-a033-02f591586ab7/301 Sri Lanka dry-zone dry evergreen forests - Eric Wikaramanayake.jpg

ecoregions.title: South Deccan Plateau Dry Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: The ecoregion represents the expanse of tropical dry forests in the southern parts of the Deccan Plateau, in the rain shadow cast by the Western Ghats Mountains.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/653f3c32-1315-44cc-8e4e-142d68426819/298 South Deccan Plateau dry deciduous forests - Eric Wikramanayake.jpg

ecoregions.title: East Deccan Dry-Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is relatively small, and represents the narrow strip of dry evergreen forests along the coast of southeastern India.

ecoregions.title: Central Deccan Plateau Dry Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: The ecoregion sits in the middle of the Deccan Plateau that makes up most of India.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/ec258f4a-03b4-467e-872e-7ca7d6f35dff/290 Central Deccan Plateau dry deciduous forests - Eric Wikramanayake.jpg

children.name: Northern Deccan & Odisha Tropical Forests (IM7)
children.content:
The Northern Deccan & Odisha Tropical Forests bioregion is located within the Indian Subcontinent subrealm in Indomalaya and contains four  ecoregions – East Deccan Moist Deciduous Forests [1], North Deccan Dry Deciduous Forests [2], Orissa Semi-Evergreen Forests [3], Godavari-Krishna Mangroves [4] – totaling approximately 42 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Northern Deccan & Odisha Tropical Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Godavari-Krishna Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends as a narrow band along the middle-region coast of the Indian subcontinent. It forms larger patches in the estuaries of the Godavari and Krishna rivers.

ecoregions.title: North Deccan Dry Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends across three Indian states of Bihar, Orissa, and Madhya Pradesh, and represents the northern extent of dry deciduous forests in India.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a07cf933-bf4a-4779-b92a-8141152b45d1/297 North Deccan dry deciduous forests - Theasg sap.JPG

ecoregions.title: Orissa Semi-Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: The flora and fauna of this ecoregion has an ancient geological lineage with Gondwanaland origins, but now represents the forests along the low hills in the northeastern Indian State of Orissa.

ecoregions.title: East Deccan Moist Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a tropical moist deciduous forest ecoregion of east-central India.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/cf358114-2741-4198-b7f2-bbb2219f473d/228 East Deccan moist deciduous forests - Adityamadhav83.JPG

children.name: North Indian Tropical Forests & Sundarbans (IM6)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/cdd7322b-f622-487c-b0bc-5107a4d6faf1/287 Upper Gangetic Plains moist deciduous forests - varsham 1.jpg

children.content:
The North Indian Tropical Forests & Sundarbans bioregion is the eastern section of the Indian Subcontinent subrealm in Indomalaya, containing seven terrestrial ecoregions – Upper Gangetic Plains Moist Deciduous Forests [1], Lower Gangetic Plains Moist Deciduous Forests [2], Meghalaya Subtropical Forests [3], Brahmaputra Valley Semi-Evergreen Forests [4], Sundarbans Freshwater Swamp Forests [5], Sundarbans Mangroves [6], Myanmar Coast Mangroves [7] – along with the Myanmar Coast Mangroves (321) and Sundarbans Mangroves (323) totaling approximately 66 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the North Indian Tropical Forests & Sundarbans ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Sundarbans Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies in a vast delta, an area over 10,000 km2 formed by the confluence of South Asia’s largest rivers, the Ganges, Hooghly, Padma, Brahmaputra and Meghna.

ecoregions.title: Upper Gangetic Plains Moist Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies along one of Asia’s largest and most sacred rivers, the Ganges, or Ganga.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/cdd7322b-f622-487c-b0bc-5107a4d6faf1/287 Upper Gangetic Plains moist deciduous forests - varsham 1.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sundarbans Freshwater Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the swamp forests surrounding the Sundarbans Mangroves, in the zone where the freshwater from the rivers push back the saline waters of the intruding ocean.

ecoregions.title: Meghalaya Subtropical Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the subtropical forests of the Khasi and Garo hills of the Indian State, Meghalaya, which literally means ‘abode of clouds’.

ecoregions.title: Lower Gangetic Plains Moist Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies along the confluence of two of Asia’s largest rivers, the Ganges and Brahmaputra Rivers.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/edb0256d-23ee-4514-bf96-fb2eb82418f4/238 Lower Gangetic Plains moist deciduous forests - JKDs.jpg

ecoregions.title: Brahmaputra Valley Semi-Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the swath of semi-evergreen forests along the upper reaches of the sacred Brahmaputra River.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/9e7e251b-54e6-4e33-bdca-24c682603127/222 Brahmaputra Valley semi-evergreen forests - Gregoire Dubois.jpg

ecoregions.title: Myanmar Coast Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends along the eastern rim of the Bay of Bengal through the coastal areas of India, Myanmar, Thailand, and Malaysia.

children.name: Himalayan Mixed Forests & Grasslands (IM5)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/fab2b772-a93a-418d-8415-cccb951f2a5f/309 Eastern Himalayan subalpine conifer forests - Eric Wikramanayake_resized.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e0da047f-72e7-45a3-806c-a5b7a6515ebd/302 Himalayan subtropical pine forests - Sanjoy Ghosh.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/329efe84-59b6-4bdd-942c-91d78cc2e093/310 Western Himalayan subalpine conifer forests - Paul Evans.jpg

children.content:
The Himalayan Mixed Forests & Grasslands bioregion is located at the very top of the Indian Subcontinent subrealm in Indomalaya and contains seven ecoregions – Eastern Himalayan Subalpine Conifer Forests [1], Eastern Himalayan Broadleaf Forests [2], Himalayan Subtropical Pine Forests [3], Terai-Duar Savanna and Grasslands [4], Himalayan Subtropical Broadleaf Forests [5], Western Himalayan Subalpine Conifer Forests [6], Western Himalayan Broadleaf Forests [7] – totaling approximately 35.5 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Himalayan Mixed Forests & Grasslands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Terai-Duar Savanna and Grasslands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches from northwest India across and into the inner river valleys of southern Nepal and to southwest Bhutan.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2d34447e-64a8-47e6-af53-cd3db4bcedd0/311 Terai-Duar savanna and grasslands - Meg _ Rahul.jpg

ecoregions.title: Western Himalayan Subalpine Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends west from the Kali Gandaki River in central Nepal through northwestern India into eastern Pakistan.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/329efe84-59b6-4bdd-942c-91d78cc2e093/310 Western Himalayan subalpine conifer forests - Paul Evans.jpg

ecoregions.title: Eastern Himalayan Subalpine Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the belt of conifer forest from the Kali Gandaki River in Nepal through Bhutan and into the Arunachal Pradesh State in India.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/fab2b772-a93a-418d-8415-cccb951f2a5f/309 Eastern Himalayan subalpine conifer forests - Eric Wikramanayake_resized.jpg

ecoregions.title: Western Himalayan Broadleaf Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a narrow band between 1,500 and 2,600 m in width, starting from the deep creeks of the Kali Gandaki River gorge in Central Nepal through northwestern India into Pakistan westward.

ecoregions.title: Eastern Himalayan Broadleaf Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the narrow band of temperate broadleaf forest, between 2,000 and 3,000 m in width in the eastern Himalaya.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/6235580a-cbec-43f6-8150-943b944d4b52/306 Eastern Himalayan broadleaf forests - Eric Wikramanayake.jpg

ecoregions.title: Himalayan Subtropical Pine Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches for over 3,000 km along the lower elevations of the Himalayan mountain range, from Pakistan to Bhutan, cutting through several Himalayan states of India and Nepal.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e0da047f-72e7-45a3-806c-a5b7a6515ebd/302 Himalayan subtropical pine forests - Sanjoy Ghosh.jpg

ecoregions.title: Himalayan Subtropical Broadleaf Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends from the tiny Himalayan Kingdom of Bhutan in the east to Nepal in the west, as it traverses the Siwalik Hills.

children.name: Indian Dry Deciduous Forests (IM3)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/fd9fc94d-664c-4b83-b6c9-f2941bc9a5ed/292 Chhota-Nagpur dry deciduous forests - Sk Noor Islam.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/af19f26d-fbfe-410f-b560-da50fd108822/320 Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea mangroves - Bishnu Sarangi.jpg

children.content:
The Indian Dry Deciduous Forests bioregion stretches across the Indian Subcontinent subrealm in Indomalaya. It contains four terrestrial ecoregions – Chhota-Nagpur Dry Deciduous Forests [1], Narmada Valley Dry Deciduous Forests [2], Khathiar-Gir Dry Deciduous Forests [3], Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea Mangroves [4] – totaling more than 56 million hectares of land area and includes the Gulf of Khambhat and adjoining Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea Mangroves (320). The bioregion, which includes the Narmada River and adjoining Vindhya and Chot Nagpur mountains, is defined by a very long dry season. While more than two-thirds of the region has been cleared, there are still large remaining tracts of original deciduous forests. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of ​Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace​ ​to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the ​Indian Dry Deciduous Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Narmada Valley Dry Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the dry forests along the Narmada River Valley, a rift valley situated in a fault zone marking the boundary of northern India and the Indian Peninsula.

ecoregions.title: Khathiar-Gir Dry Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the dry deciduous forests that are surrounded by the extensive thorn scrub forests that cover most of India’s northwestern regions.

ecoregions.title: Chhota-Nagpur Dry Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion still harbors large populations of Asia’s largest predator and herbivore, the tiger and Asian elephant, both of which are still able to roam the landscape with relative freedom, a rarity in this bioregion.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/fd9fc94d-664c-4b83-b6c9-f2941bc9a5ed/292 Chhota-Nagpur dry deciduous forests - Sk Noor Islam.jpg

ecoregions.title: Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is in several disjunct patches that line the shorelines of the Indus River Delta and the Gulfs of Kutch and Khambhat.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/af19f26d-fbfe-410f-b560-da50fd108822/320 Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea mangroves - Bishnu Sarangi.jpg

children.name: Indian Tropical Coastal Forests (IM2)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/ad28c115-95d6-4367-865c-9160a9fc0f87/254 North Western Ghats montane rain forests - Bishnu Sarangi.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e0e0f274-4e5f-4945-8798-0a866ef5c8f9/242 Malabar Coast moist forests - Bishnu Sarangi.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/3f1e2474-2ae8-4e56-b5a3-b174081e1fa0/271 South Western Ghats montane rain forests - Rajib Ghosh.jpg

children.content:
The Indian Tropical Coastal Forests bioregion is located along the western coast of the Indian Subcontinent subrealm in Indomalaya. It contains seven ecoregions – Sri Lanka Lowland Rain Forests [1], Sri Lanka Montane Rain Forests [2], Malabar Coast Moist Forests [3], South Western Ghats Montane Rain Forests [4], South Western Ghats Moist Deciduous Forests [5], North Western Ghats Montane Rain Forests [6], North Western Ghats Moist Deciduous Forests [7] – totaling approximately 17 million hectares of land area and adjacent marine areas. Defined by the long Western Ghats mountain range and adjoining coastline, this bioregion was once dominated by rainforests that thrived in the annual monsoon cycle, which can bring as much as 8 feet of rainfall to the region. While nearly all of the natural forests have been cleared, some pockets remain as sacred groves preserved by local communities. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of ​Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace​ ​to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the ​Indian Tropical Coastal Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: South Western Ghats Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the rainforests above 1,000 m elevation of the southern Western Ghats mountain range along the west coast of the Indian subcontinent.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/3f1e2474-2ae8-4e56-b5a3-b174081e1fa0/271 South Western Ghats montane rain forests - Rajib Ghosh.jpg

ecoregions.title: South Western Ghats Moist Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion surrounds the montane rain forests along the southern extent of the Western Ghats Mountain Range, and represents the drier, deciduous forest ecosystems.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/41edeb7c-1750-4f6b-9133-2160b2785519/270 South Western Ghats moist deciduous forests - Eric Wikramanayake.jpg

ecoregions.title: North Western Ghats Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the upper montane forests along the Western Ghats mountain range, from north of Mumbai to the Wyanad evergreen forests in the south.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/ad28c115-95d6-4367-865c-9160a9fc0f87/254 North Western Ghats montane rain forests - Bishnu Sarangi.jpg

ecoregions.title: North Western Ghats Moist Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends through the Indian states of Maharashtra and Karnataka, northwards from where the South Western Ghats Moist Deciduous Forests ends.

ecoregions.title: Malabar Coast Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends from the coast to the 250 m elevation contour of the steep Western Ghats Mountains a few kilometers inland.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e0e0f274-4e5f-4945-8798-0a866ef5c8f9/242 Malabar Coast moist forests - Bishnu Sarangi.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sri Lanka Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the island’s montane and sub-montane wet forests above 1,000 m.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8beba5d2-32e3-4184-84c7-fb506d683cc5/275 Sri Lanka montane rain forests - Eric Wikramanayake.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sri Lanka Lowland Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: These rainforests have been separated from the nearest rainforests in the Western Ghats mountain range along the west coast of India since the late Miocene, over 7 million years ago, allowing species to evolve in isolation.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/c8b34d41-f46e-4ace-9620-5a5d606b0e18/274 Sri Lanka lowland rain forests - N Chamal.JPG

children.name: North Indomalayan Deserts & Scrub Forest (IM4)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/af19f26d-fbfe-410f-b560-da50fd108822/320 Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea mangroves - Bishnu Sarangi.jpg

children.content:
The North Indomalayan Desert & Scrub Forest bioregion is located in the northwest of the Indian Subcontinent subrealm in Indomalaya and contains five terrestrial ecoregions – Indus Valley Desert [1], Aravalli West Thorn Scrub Forests [2], Thar Desert [3], Rann of Kutch Seasonal Salt Marsh [4], Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea Mangroves [5] – (320) totaling nearly 78 million hectares of land area, not including the Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea Mangroves and adjoining marine areas. The bioregion is dominated by the drylands and deserts of the Indus River and Luni River valleys. Though a harsh, desolate environment, the seasonal salt flats spanning surrounding  the Gulf of Kutch provide refuge for the endangered Asiatic wild ass and support the one of the world's largest breeding colonies of flamingos.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of ​Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace​ ​to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the ​North Indomalayan Deserts & Scrub Forest ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is in several disjunct patches that line the shorelines of the Indus River Delta and the Gulfs of Kutch and Khambhat.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/af19f26d-fbfe-410f-b560-da50fd108822/320 Indus River Delta-Arabian Sea mangroves - Bishnu Sarangi.jpg

ecoregions.title: Thar Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies to the west of the Aravalli Mountain Range in the northwestern Indian States of Gujarat, Rajasthan, extending across the border to the Punjab and Sind regions of Pakistan.

ecoregions.title: Indus Valley Desert
ecoregions.dek: This hot, arid ecoregion sits in the middle of Pakistan’s Indus Valley, flanked by the Glaiman Mountain Range to the west, and the Chenab River to the east.

ecoregions.title: Aravalli West Thorn Scrub Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the thorn scrub forests in the northwestern parts of the Indian subcontinent, along the Aravalli Mountains, transcending the international border between India and Pakistan.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/6874ab22-7868-4dce-b618-5fecbc2637df/314 Aravalli west thorn scrub forests - Indranil Banerjie 1.jpg

ecoregions.title: Rann of Kutch Seasonal Salt Marsh
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the saline wetlands and mudflats at the mouth of the Luni River that flows down from the Aravalli Hills in northwestern India.

children.name: Central Indian Ocean Islands (IM1)
children.content:
The Central Indian Ocean Islands bioregion is part of the Indian Subcontinent subrealm within Indomalaya. It contains one ecoregion — Maldives-Lakshadweep-Chagos Archipelago Tropical Moist Forests [1] —totaling approximately 55 thousand hectares of land area and consisting primarily of the marine areas surrounding the Maldives, Lakshadweep, and Chagos -- three volcanic island groups in the Indian Ocean that together form a vast underwater mountain range, the Chagos-Laccadive Plateau. Known mostly for its biodiverse coral reef system, the islands themselves provide critical habitats for seabirds and turtles. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of ​Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace​ ​to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the ​Central Indian Ocean Islands ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Maldives-Lakshadweep-Chagos Archipelago Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents three island groups along a submarine mountain range known as the Chagos-Laccadive Plateau in the western Indian Ocean.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/920d6687-9073-422e-a79e-8c7f197a1667/243 Maldives-Lakshadweep-Chagos Archipelago tropical moist forests - Andreas Schau.jpg

children.name: Philippines & Sulu Sea Tropical Forests (IM15)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1210836a-9b3c-4043-8377-16537a01de1d/246 Mindanao montane rain forests - Bro Jeffrey Pioquinto SJ.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/14a0754a-faa9-44b6-8c3e-ea3c4a6bc916/276 Sulu Archipelago rain forests - Ervin Malicdem.jpg

children.content:
The Philippines & Sulu Sea Tropical Forests bioregion is located in the Southeast Asian Forests subrealm of Indomalaya and contains nine ecoregions – Luzon Rainforests [1], Luzon Montane Rainforests [2], Luzon Tropical Pine Forests [3], Palawan Rainforests [4], Mindoro Rainforests [5], Greater Negros-Panay Rainforests [6], Mindanao-Eastern Visayas Rainforests [7], Mindanao Montane Rainforests [8], Sulu Archipelago Rainforests [9] – totaling approximately 30 million hectares of land area. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Philippines & Sulu Sea Tropical Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Luzon Tropical Pine Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the tropical pine forest on the Central Cordillera Mountains on Luzon Island.

ecoregions.title: Sulu Archipelago Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents a chain of islands between the large islands of Borneo and Mindanao, Philippines.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/14a0754a-faa9-44b6-8c3e-ea3c4a6bc916/276 Sulu Archipelago rain forests - Ervin Malicdem.jpg

ecoregions.title: Palawan Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers Palawan and its peripheral islands.

ecoregions.title: Mindoro Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents Mindoro Island and the smaller satellite islands with a wet tropical climate.

ecoregions.title: Mindanao-Eastern Visayas Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the lowland forests below 1,000 m in elevation, on the Philippine islands of Mindanao, Samar, Leyte, Bohol, and several smaller satellite islands.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/21411430-9ad3-4532-a556-3de4be272d86/247 Mindanao-Eastern Visayas rain forests - John Morrison.jpg

ecoregions.title: Mindanao Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the montane rainforests, above 1,000 m elevation, on Mindanao Island.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1210836a-9b3c-4043-8377-16537a01de1d/246 Mindanao montane rain forests - Bro Jeffrey Pioquinto SJ.jpg

ecoregions.title: Luzon Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: The Luzon Rainforests ecoregion covers the rainforests below 1,000 m on Luzon Island.

ecoregions.title: Luzon Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the forests above 1,000 m in elevation along the Sierra Madre Mountain range, the longest in the Philippines, and the Zambales Mountains in the west.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/6f0ed7ff-4330-4d07-9b11-89269e8ea7b8/240 Luzon montane rain forests- R Brown.jpg

ecoregions.title: Greater Negros-Panay Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion consists of several islands; namely the larger Negros, Panay, Cebu, and several smaller islands.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/35e7d78a-2124-401b-bcf1-1d6d52e2948e/231 Greater Negros-Panay rain forests - John Morrison.jpg

children.name: South China Subtropical Evergreen & Monsoon Forests (IM13)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7ac8fd20-3b72-463f-895e-8c3168aaec9f/232 Hainan Island monsoon rain forests - Helen Nash.JPG
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7e6ad2b2-bb5c-4e90-a83e-807a0767fce0/269 South Taiwan monsoon rain forests - Max Chang.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/90a5bb05-5d96-45ae-996b-33e4d9c495ee/283 Taiwan subtropical evergreen forests - Gerralt van Soest.jpg

children.content:
The South China Subtropical Evergreen & Monsoon Forests bioregion is located in the Southeast Asian Forests subrealm of Indomalaya and contains five ecoregions – Hainan Island Monsoon Rain Forests [1], South China-Vietnam Subtropical Evergreen Forests [2], Jian Nan Subtropical Evergreen Forests [3], Taiwan Subtropical Evergreen Forests [4], South Taiwan Monsoon Rain Forests [5] – totaling approximately 94 million hectares of land area. This bioregion also includes adjoining coastal marine areas in the South China Sea. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the South China Subtropical Evergreen & Monsoon Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Taiwan Subtropical Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents most of the forests of the island of Taiwan, except for the southernmost section that lies to the south of the Tropic of Cancer.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/90a5bb05-5d96-45ae-996b-33e4d9c495ee/283 Taiwan subtropical evergreen forests - Gerralt van Soest.jpg

ecoregions.title: South Taiwan Monsoon Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the low elevation forests in the southern-most part of the island.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7e6ad2b2-bb5c-4e90-a83e-807a0767fce0/269 South Taiwan monsoon rain forests - Max Chang.jpg

ecoregions.title: South China-Vietnam Subtropical Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends from northern Vietnam into southeastern China, and includes Hainan Island.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b51a134f-a833-4e02-8421-416478798d67/268 South China-Vietnam subtropical evergreen forests - Craig Robson Birdquest.jpg

ecoregions.title: Jian Nan Subtropical Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the Nan Ling mountain range, a wide divide that separates the southern Zhujiang River basin from the northern Yangtze Valley.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f37b8329-17c8-406e-911f-7023f5d35133/236 Jian Nan subtropical evergreen forests - Rolf Muller.jpg

ecoregions.title: Hainan Island Monsoon Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the montane forests in the central region of the island, which has a more seasonal climate.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7ac8fd20-3b72-463f-895e-8c3168aaec9f/232 Hainan Island monsoon rain forests - Helen Nash.JPG

children.name: Indochina Mixed Forests & Peatlands (IM12)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a75dfbdb-a1d4-4f76-aae5-bc1117d10ff6/Thung Salaeng Luang nationalpark of Thailand, mountain view with sea of fog and forest dreamstime_158003599.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/92e3cca9-6cfe-48f2-93db-4abce94a4ed5/223 Cardamom Mountains rain forests - Rhett Butler.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/68f2fb88-19b1-49f7-8689-1a5e5e20394d/239 Luang Prabang montane rain forests - kolibri5.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2ea2d7a1-480f-4253-b9d1-26805334232e/300 Southern Vietnam lowland dry forests - Rhett Butler.jpg

children.content:
The Indochina Mixed Forests & Peatlands bioregion is located in the Southeast Asian Forests subrealm of Indomalaya and contains 15 terrestrial ecoregions – Red River Freshwater Swamp Forests [1], Northern Vietnam Lowland Rainforests [2], Northern Annamites Rainforests [3], Southern Annamites Montane Rainforests [4], Southern Vietnam Lowland Dry Forests [5], Southeastern Indochina Dry Evergreen Forests [6], Central Indochina Dry Forests [7], Tonle Sap-Mekong Peat Swamp Forest [8], Tonle Sap Freshwater Swamp Forests [9], Cardamom Mountains Rainforests [10], Chao Phraya Lowland Moist Deciduous Forests [11], Chao Phraya Freshwater Swamp Forests [12], Northern Thailand-Laos Moist Deciduous Forests [13], Luang Prabang Montane Rainforests [14], Northern Khorat Plateau Moist Deciduous Forests [15], Indochina Mangroves [16], South China Sea Islands [17] – totaling approximately 90.5 million hectares of land area. This bioregion also includes the South China Sea Islands (267) and surrounding marine areas.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Indochina Mixed Forests & Peatlands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Southern Vietnam Lowland Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the dry forests along the semi-arid coastal areas of southern Vietnam, where the Annamite Mountains restrict the flow of humid air during the monsoon season, and casts a rain shadow.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2ea2d7a1-480f-4253-b9d1-26805334232e/300 Southern Vietnam lowland dry forests - Rhett Butler.jpg

ecoregions.title: Southeastern Indochina Dry Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion sprawls across Cambodia and southern Vietnam, with parts extending into Thailand and Laos.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/81e2393e-832a-4477-8cd8-7f02a42e1213/299 Southeast Indochina dry evergreen forests - Roy Bateman.jpg

ecoregions.title: Central Indochina Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends across Thailand, from the dry lower slopes in the north and the foothills of the Tenasserim Range to the uplands around the Chao Phraya River Basin.

ecoregions.title: Tonle Sap-Mekong Peat Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the forests that are permanently inundated with shallow fresh- water around the Tonle Sap Lake and River, Southeast Asia’s largest natural lake and its river, located in central Cambodia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/329d955b-d69e-451b-b8ff-558dd81e57bd/286 Tonle Sap-Mekong peat swamp forests - Quolip.jpg

ecoregions.title: Tonle Sap Freshwater Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends south from Tonle Sap Lake in central Cambodia, along the Tonle Sap River, and then along the lower reaches of the Mekong River into southern Vietnam.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2d5b98d5-f27e-4dc3-a09f-21fa4a1da09a/285 Tonle Sap freshwater swamp forests - Sharon Ang.jpg

ecoregions.title: Southern Annamites Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the remote montane forests from Kontuey Neak, or “the Dragon’s Tail” in the northwest corner of Cambodia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a2d78672-cf93-4f9b-ac72-dcf5c04bb443/272 Southern Annamites montane rain forests - Craig Robson Birdquest.jpg

ecoregions.title: Northern Vietnam Lowland Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends south from the Red River, along the coast and lowlands, to Tam Ky in Central Vietnam.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1fb5c3d3-99fe-4c97-9f82-8f0e0c50b53e/260 Northern Vietnam lowland rain forests - Rhett Butler.jpg

ecoregions.title: Northern Thailand-Laos Moist Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes the limestone karst mountains in northern Thailand and Laos.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/51b9ec61-10b3-4fba-8d06-9a562884be29/258 Northern Thailand-Laos moist deciduous forests - Takeaway.jpg

ecoregions.title: Northern Khorat Plateau Moist Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is relatively small, and represents the moist deciduous forests in the northern part of the low, saucer-shaped plateau in western Thailand.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f68660bf-4796-4f25-86e7-5fdc4dd216e4/257 Northern Khorat Plateau moist deciduous forests - Erwannjacquin.JPG

ecoregions.title: Northern Annamites Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion straddles the Annamite, or Troung Son, mountain range and the international boundary between Laos and Vietnam.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/90afe9eb-99ea-4386-8993-d1d94c3b6f6e/255 Northern Annamites rain forests - Rolf Müller.jpg

ecoregions.title: Luang Prabang Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the forests above 800 m in northern and central Laos and in small areas of northeastern Thailand, barely touching northern Vietnam.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1406adb7-a6fa-4cf6-990b-8c239123d2fa/239 Luang Prabang Montane Rain Forests Nopparat thanatawan cc.jpg

ecoregions.title: Chao Phraya Lowland Moist Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occurs as two disjunct areas on either side of the Chao Phraya river basin’s lower reaches.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/42ea37de-8aa6-41ca-9005-c26b1a9c28bd/225 Chao Phraya lowland moist deciduous forests - Ahoerstemeier.jpg

ecoregions.title: Chao Phraya Freshwater Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: The sprawling capital of Thailand, Bangkok, which supports over 8 million people, sits in the lower reaches of this ecoregion.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1d74a57e-da4a-4ea8-922f-77520d27c4d6/224 Chao Phraya freshwater swamp forests - Heinrich Damm.jpg

ecoregions.title: Cardamom Mountains Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the wet evergreen forests of the Cardamom and Elephant mountains in southwest Cambodia and southeast Thailand.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/92e3cca9-6cfe-48f2-93db-4abce94a4ed5/223 Cardamom Mountains rain forests - Rhett Butler.jpg

ecoregions.title: South China Sea Islands
ecoregions.dek: The South China Sea Islands ecoregion consists of over 250 islands, atolls, and shoals scattered throughout the South China Sea, and grouped into three archipelagos.

ecoregions.title: Indochina Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The mangroves that comprise this ecoregion line the coastal areas of the Gulf of Thailand, where regular flooding by tidal or brackish water and saline gleysols provide conditions for mangroves.

ecoregions.title: Red River Freshwater Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion comprises the freshwater swamp forests of the Red River valley in northern Vietnam, immediately inland from the mangroves, and upriver along the wide shallow lower reaches of this 1,149 km long river.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b32a6046-f12c-40bb-8a6b-cad0ce2904d3/266 Red River freshwater swamp forests - Rungbachduoung.jpg

children.name: Irrawaddy & North Indochina Mixed Forests (IM11)
children.content:
The Irrawaddy & North Indochina Mixed Forests bioregion is located in the Southeast Asian Forests subrealm of Indomalaya and contains four ecoregions – Irrawaddy Moist Deciduous Forests [1], Irrawaddy Dry Forests [2], Northern Indochina Subtropical Forests [3], Kayah-Karen Montane Rainforests [4] – totaling nearly 74 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Irrawaddy & North Indochina Mixed Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Irrawaddy Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is comprised of several patches of dry forests where the environment is harsh and dry, with only about 650 mm of annual rainfall.

ecoregions.title: Northern Indochina Subtropical Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion straddles the intersection where the faunas of the northern Palearctic and the southern Indo-Malayan realms mix.

ecoregions.title: Kayah-Karen Montane Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies along the northern part of the Tenasserim Mountain Range, which forms the border between Thailand and Myanmar.

ecoregions.title: Irrawaddy Moist Deciduous Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the moist deciduous forests in the vast Irrawaddy River basin, including the catchments of the Bago Yoma mountains and the foothills of Rakhine Yoma.

children.name: Arakan Mountains & Northern Triangle Forests (IM10)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b82cdc1f-227a-47f0-a05b-1c35bd1c95ee/307 Northern Triangle temperate forests - Mark Fisher Fisher Creative.jpg

children.content:
The Arakan Mountains & Northern Triangle Forests bioregion defines the upper western boundary of the Southeast Asian Forests subrealm in Indomalaya, containing five ecoregions – Northern Triangle Temperate Forests [1], Northern Triangle Subtropical Forests [2], Northeast India-Myanmar Pine Forests [3], Mizoram-Manipur-Kachin Rainforests [4], Chin Hills-Arakan Yoma Montane Forests [5] – totaling approximately 24 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Arakan Mountains & Northern Triangle Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Northeast India-Myanmar Pine Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the pine forests distributed in three isolated patches in the Naga Hills, which form the international border between India and Myanmar.

ecoregions.title: Northern Triangle Subtropical Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Northern Triangle Subtropical Forests ecoregion mountains were formed from the upheaval and uplift that followed the collision between the Deccan Plateau and the Laurasian mainland, which also created the Himalayas.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8ce891b5-4ce2-443f-af75-4e5f9a62be06/259 Northern Triangle subtropical forests - Eric Daft Fisher Creative.jpg

ecoregions.title: Mizoram-Manipur-Kachin Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is vast, covering the remote sub-montane rainforests from the southern Arakan mountains and Chin Hills in western Myanmar into the northern mountains of Kachin State in Myanmar.

ecoregions.title: Chin Hills-Arakan Yoma Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the montane moist forests of the Chin Hills and Arakan (now known as Rakhine) Yoma along the west coast of Myanmar.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/71b771b5-882a-4a1a-9112-b708b5a49c50/226 Chin Hills-Arakan Yoma montane forests - Lionslayer.JPG

ecoregions.title: Northern Triangle Temperate Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents a relatively narrow band of temperate forests in northern Myanmar’s mountains.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b82cdc1f-227a-47f0-a05b-1c35bd1c95ee/307 Northern Triangle temperate forests - Mark Fisher Fisher Creative.jpg

children.name: Myanmar Coastal Rainforests & Andaman Sea Islands (IM9)
children.content:
The Myanmar Coastal Rainforests & Andaman Sea Islands bioregion is located in the west of the Southeast Asian Forests subrealm in Indomalaya, containing seven terrestrial ecoregions – Tenasserim-South Thailand Semi-Evergreen Rainforests [1], Myanmar Coastal Rainforests [2], Irrawaddy Freshwater Swamp Forests [3], Andaman Islands Rainforests [4], Nicobar Islands Rainforests [5] – along with Myanmar Coast Mangroves [6] and Indochina Mangroves [7], totaling approximately 21 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Myanmar Coastal Rainforests & Andaman Sea Islands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Tenasserim-South Thailand Semi-Evergreen Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a transition from the continental dry evergreen forests in central Thailand to the semi-evergreen rainforests along the neck of the Malayan peninsula.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/ed8afc92-dec8-4aa2-beb3-df7c6a99f8f6/Morning fog in dense tropical rainforest, kaeng krachan, thailand. Dreamstime.jpg

ecoregions.title: Nicobar Islands Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the cluster of Nicobar Islands in the archipelago along the eastern Indian Ocean undersea mountain range.

ecoregions.title: Myanmar Coastal Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the lowland evergreen and semi-evergreen rainforests along the western side of the Arakan Yoma and Tenasserim mountain ranges of Myanmar’s west coast.

ecoregions.title: Irrawaddy Freshwater Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the forests immediately behind the mangroves, in the zone where the fresh water from the Irrawaddy River pushes back the salt water.

ecoregions.title: Andaman Islands Rainforests
ecoregions.dek: The Andaman Islands, covered by this ecoregion, is part of an archipelago that continues southward to the Nicobar Islands on the eastern side of the Bay of Bengal.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7821669f-8542-47a8-bb7c-cb25026da3f5/218 Andaman Islands rain forests - Aliven Sarkar.JPG

ecoregions.title: Myanmar Coast Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends along the eastern rim of the Bay of Bengal through the coastal areas of India, Myanmar, Thailand, and Malaysia.

ecoregions.title: Indochina Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The mangroves that comprise this ecoregion line the coastal areas of the Gulf of Thailand, where regular flooding by tidal or brackish water and saline gleysols provide conditions for mangroves.

children.name: Nansei Islands Subtropical Evergreen Forests (IM14)
children.content:
The Nansei Islands Subtropical Evergreen Forests bioregion is located in the Southeast Asian Forests subrealm of Indomalaya and contains one ecoregion – Nansei Islands Subtropical Evergreen Forests [1] – located just south of Japan, totaling approximately 408 thousand hectares of land area and extensive marine areas surrounding this chain of forested islands. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Indomalaya. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more the Nansei Islands Subtropical Evergreen Forests ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Nansei Islands Subtropical Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the 1,050 km-long chain of over 100 small islands that stretches from Kyushu Island of Japan to Taiwan.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a813dfcf-ac20-4fe4-b83a-62fbaa4cfca5/251 Nansei Islands subtropical evergreen forests - Kanenori.jpg

children.name: Midwestern Tallgrass Prairie & Forest Transition (NA21)
children.content:
The Midwestern Tallgrass bioregion, located in the Northern America (Nearctic) realm, is the third major section of the continent’s Great Plains subrealm, extending eastward from the Missouri River, where it transitions to open forests across Illinois, known as the central grassland-forest transition. 

It contains three ecoregions – Central US Forest-Grasslands Transition (387), Central Tallgrass Prairie (388), Flint Hills Tallgrass Prairie (392) – and incorporates the western half of Lake Michigan as well as a large section of the Missouri River.
