The total land area of this bioregion is nearly 60 million hectares.

ecoregions.title: Central US Forest-Grasslands Transition
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies a large area between the deciduous forests of the eastern United States and the tallgrass prairies of the eastern Great Plains.

ecoregions.title: Flint Hills Tallgrass Prairie
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is distinguished from the Central Tallgrass Prairie to the east and northeast by its thin, cherty, limestone-derived soils, which hindered plowing for crop agriculture.

ecoregions.title: Central Tallgrass Prairie
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion, the heart of the tallgrass prairie, is the iconic North American prairie, with grasses up to 3 m tall on the best soils, waving in the wind over root systems just as long or sometimes longer.

children.name: Northern Prairie & Aspen Forests (NA12)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/dd141734-5a6c-461c-95df-16ad2fcc6ec4/396 Northern Shortgrass Prairie Brett Snyder cc.jpeg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/d93227b3-35e4-4ff1-9836-e0cd70e0a73b/386 Canadian Aspen Forests and Parklands Ken Lund, Flickr.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/0f8be477-8b52-461e-a128-74bce140cf29/386 Canadian Aspen Forests and Parklands Just a Prarie Boy, Flickr.jpg

children.content:
The Northern Prairie bioregion, located in the Great Plains subrealm of Northern America, is the upper section of the Great Plains, lying between the Great Lakes forests to the east and the Northern Rockies to the west. It is predominantly made up of shortgrass prairie mixed with aspen forests and tallgrass prairie in the east. The bioregion includes three ecoregions – Northern Shortgrass Prairie (396), Northern Tallgrass Prairie (397), Canadian Aspen Forests and Parklands (386) – and is defined largely by the expansive Missouri River watershed. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 113 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Northern Prairie & Aspen Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Northern Tallgrass Prairie
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the northernmost tallgrass prairie in North America, extending north into a true boreal climate.

ecoregions.title: Canadian Aspen Forests and Parklands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is an immense region stretching from southwestern Minnesota and southeastern North Dakota.

ecoregions.title: Northern Shortgrass Prairie
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion, sprawling across five U.S. states and two Canadian provinces, is the largest grassland ecoregion in North America.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b5e60317-e959-49d0-969f-bde223d0e163/396 Northern Shortgrass prairie - Badlands National Park.jpg

children.name: Southern Prairie Mixed Grasslands (NA20)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/16069900-4955-4e73-966d-5467ca9a7027/395 Nebraska Sand Hills mixed grasslands - Reed Noss.jpg

children.content:
The Southern Prairie bioregion, located in the Northern America (Nearctic) realm, is the lower section of the Great Plains subrealm and is composed entirely of grasslands stretching from the top of Nebraska to southern Texas, bounded by the Rockies to the west. It contains five ecoregions – (1) Western Shortgrass Prairie (2) Nebraska Sand Hills Mixed Grasslands (3) Central-Southern US Mixed Grasslands (4) Cross-Timbers Savanna-Woodland (5) Edwards Plateau Savanna – and has largely been converted to farmland. The total area of this bioregion is nearly 99 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Southern Prairie Mixed Grasslands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Western Shortgrass Prairie
ecoregions.dek: The Western Shortgrass Prairie is the second largest grassland ecoregion in North America, stretching from Texas and New Mexico in the south to Nebraska and Wyoming in the north.

ecoregions.title: Edwards Plateau Savanna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion, the heart of the famed Texas Hill Country, lies to the west of the Texas Blackland Prairies ecoregion and is bordered on the south by the Tamaulipan Mezquital and on the southwest by the Chihauhuan Desert.

ecoregions.title: Cross-Timbers Savanna-Woodland
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers a long latitudinal extent from Texas north through eastern Oklahoma and a small portion of eastern Kansas.

ecoregions.title: Central-Southern US Mixed Grasslands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion forms an ecological transition from tallgrass to shortgrass prairie. From north to south, its eastern boundary abuts the Central Tallgrass, Flint Hills Tallgrass, and Cross-Timber Savanna-Woodland ecoregions.

ecoregions.title: Nebraska Sand Hills Mixed Grasslands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is the smallest ecoregion in the Great Plains but stands out as the most intact of all Great Plains ecoregions and, most significantly, as the largest area of sand dunes in the entire Western Hemisphere.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/16069900-4955-4e73-966d-5467ca9a7027/395 Nebraska Sand Hills mixed grasslands - Reed Noss.jpg

children.name: Northwest Intermountain Conifer Forests (NA14)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/3b06861d-3c5f-4266-9daf-e5572c1747aa/355 Fraser Plateau and Basin conifer forests - Petra.jpg

children.content:
The Northwest Intermountain bioregion, located in the American West subrealm of Northern America, lies between the Rockies to the east and the Coast Mountains in the west and is dominated by conifer forests. This bioregion includes two ecoregions – Fraser Plateau and Basin Conifer Forests (355), Okanogan Dry Forests (362) – and encompasses the southern portion of the Lakes District in British Columbia, a network of hundreds of linear valley lakes. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 16 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Northwest Intermountain Conifer Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Okanogan Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a complex mix of forest, grassland, and desert shrubland, and in its western portion, subalpine and alpine vegetation.

ecoregions.title: Fraser Plateau and Basin Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies a transitional area of plateaus and plains covering much of the central interior of British Columbia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/3b06861d-3c5f-4266-9daf-e5572c1747aa/355 Fraser Plateau and Basin conifer forests - Petra.jpg

children.name: Greater Rockies & Mountain Forests (NA13)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/63f65df1-df06-4c9f-9d75-1dacbc4d2a7b/361 Northern Rockies conifer forests - Harvey Locke.jpg

children.content:
The Greater Rockies bioregion is the backbone of the American West subrealm within Northern America. It extends northward from Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming all the way to Lake Williston in British Columbia. It is covered predominately by temperate conifer forests but includes the foothill grasslands covering the floor of the many valleys that are intertwined with the adjacent mountains. The bioregion includes four ecoregions – Central British Columbia Mountain Forests (350), Northern Rockies Conifer Forests (361), South Central Rockies Forests (367), Montana Valley and Foothill Grasslands (394) – and encompasses the northern portion of the Lakes District in British Columbia as well as Glacier National Park of Canada. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 70 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Greater Rockies & Mountain Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Montana Valley and Foothill Grasslands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion forms the matrix of the northern Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE), westward into central Idaho.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/78aae34f-50ca-49c9-8350-6d5253047612/394 Montana Valley and Foothill grasslands - USFWS.jpg

ecoregions.title: South Central Rockies Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion contains the world’s first national park, Yellowstone, as well as Grand Teton National Park and many designated Wilderness areas.

ecoregions.title: Central British Columbia Mountain Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is oriented northwest-southeast and lies to the east of the Coast Mountains.

ecoregions.title: Northern Rockies Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses the well-known Rocky Mountain parks of Canada (Jasper, Banff, Yoho, Glacier, Kootenay, and Waterton Lakes National Parks, as well as several Provincial Parks) and the United States (Glacier National Park and several Wilderness Areas, including the Bob Marshall, Selway-Bitterroot, and Cabinet Mountains).

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/63f65df1-df06-4c9f-9d75-1dacbc4d2a7b/361 Northern Rockies conifer forests - Harvey Locke.jpg

children.name: Colorado Plateau & Mountain Forests (NA19)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/cfe29e6e-6fc4-4336-afaf-54fcd1788850/353-Spruce forest in the CO Rockies-CC-Charles M Sauer-2007.jpg

children.content:
The Colorado Plateau bioregion, located in the American West subrealm of Northern America, is encircled by mountains on all sides and consists primarily of desert shrublands and shrub steppe, spanning from the Arizona Mountains in the south to northern Wyoming, where it abuts the Central Rockies. It contains five ecoregions – Arizona Mountains Forests (346), Colorado Plateau Shrublands (429), Wasatch and Uinta Montane Forests (368), Colorado Rockies Forests (353), Wyoming Basin Shrub Steppe (438) – and for over a thousand years has been home to many different Native American tribes. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 72 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Colorado Plateau & Mountain Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Wyoming Basin Shrub Steppe
ecoregions.dek: The large Wyoming Basin Shrub Steppe ecoregion is largely confined to Wyoming, but overlaps into southern Montana, southeastern Idaho, northeastern Utah, and northwestern Colorado.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/58dcc90a-945d-44ad-b18b-784f921bebc1/438 Wyoming Basin shrub steppe - David Mark.jpg

ecoregions.title: Colorado Plateau Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is bounded on the north by the Wyoming Basin Shrub Steppe and on the east by the Colorado Rockies Forests.

ecoregions.title: Wasatch and Uinta Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion constitutes the western edge of the greater Rocky Mountains and consists of two mountain ranges: the north-south oriented Wasatch Range and the east-west oriented Uinta Range.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5703f52f-c17e-4514-8f9f-01be459e9c3c/368 Wasatch and Uinta montane forests - Jared Pedroza.jpg

ecoregions.title: Colorado Rockies Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Colorado Rockies Forests ecoregion is massive and diverse in physical conditions and vegetation.

ecoregions.title: Arizona Mountains Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies to the north of southeastern Arizona’s and southwestern New Mexico’s isolated “sky islands,” the northern outliers of the extensive Sierra Madre Occidental Pine-Oak Forests ecoregion.

children.name: Great Basin & Columbia Steppe (NA18)
children.content:
The Great Basin & Columbia Steppe bioregion, located in the American West subrealm of Northern America, is encircled by mountains on all sides, except for its southern boundary which marks the beginning of the Mojave Desert. It is made up predominantly of desert shrub-steppe dotted with small mountains, which are covered by conifer forest. It contains three ecoregions – Great Basin Montane Forests (356), Great Basin Shrub Steppe (430), and Snake-Columbia Shrub Steppe (434) – and incorporates the Great Salt Lake in central Utah. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 50 million hectares.

Learn more about each of the Great Basin & Columbia Steppe ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Snake-Columbia Shrub Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This vast ecoregion encompasses the sagebrush steppe of southeastern Oregon, northern Nevada, extreme northeastern California, southern Idaho, and a tiny slice of western Wyoming.

ecoregions.title: Great Basin Shrub Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This huge ecoregion encompasses most of Nevada, nearly half of Utah, and small adjoining areas of California and Idaho.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2bbf1870-6cc8-44f5-a8cd-7d58cc76390f/430 Great Basin shrub steppe - Tip Kilby.jpg

ecoregions.title: Great Basin Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: A conspicuous feature of the Great Basin of North America is an archipelago of uplifted fault block mountains jutting out of a vast sea of sagebrush.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/16c79413-72d4-4410-8868-c46e0061ae19/356 Great Basin montane forests - James Bouldin USGS.jpg

children.name: Columbia Plateau & Blue Mountains (NA17)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/80086064-c938-409c-9663-be2470e625fb/348 Blue Mountains Forests Miguel Vieira cc.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/03d626ec-d313-4964-b20e-6af5927d8ff3/398 Palouse Prairie Lynn Suckow US Forest Service cc.jpg

children.content:
The Columbia Plateau, located in the American West subrealm of Northern America, is an intermontane bioregion contained by the Rockies to the east and the Cascades to the west. This bioregion consists largely of high-altitude prairie but incorporates the conifer forests that cover the range of the lower lying, volcanic mountains to the south. It contains two ecoregions – Palouse Prairie (398), Blue Mountains Forests (348) – and includes a large portion of the Snake River, which merges with the Columbia River in southern Washington. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 15.5 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Columbia Plateau & Blue Mountains ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Palouse Prairie
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies a large area of the Columbia Basin and Okanogan Highlands physiographic provinces of north-central Oregon, central and eastern Washington, and small areas of western Idaho and south-central British Columbia.

ecoregions.title: Blue Mountains Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies a broad swath of central Oregon (east of the Eastern Cascades) and northeastern Oregon, as well as adjacent areas of southeastern Washington and western Idaho.

children.name: Greater California (NA31)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/73bde107-6c5f-41da-a9e4-3ca2e4f6ab47/424 California montane chaparral and woodlands - jsanchezd.jpg

children.content:
The Greater California bioregion, located in the North Pacific Coast subrealm of Northern America, is defined by the Mediterranean chaparral and woodlands that run between the Pacific Coast and the Lower California mountain range enclosing the Central Valley, which is one of the most productive agricultural regions in the world. This bioregion also incorporates the Sierra Nevada mountain range to the east, with its ancient sequoias, deep canyons, and high mountain lakes and waterfalls famous for inspiring the writings of John Muir, which led to the beginning of the US national parks system. The bioregion contains six ecoregions – Santa Lucia Montane Chaparral and Woodlands [1], California Interior Chaparral and Woodlands [2], California Central Valley Grasslands [3], Sierra Nevada Forests [4], California Montane Chaparral and Woodlands [5], California Coastal Sage and Chaparral [6] – and adjacent marine areas along the Pacific coast. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 23 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Greater California ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Santa Lucia Montane Chaparral and Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a small region bordering the Pacific Ocean in the Santa Lucia Mountains and vicinity, part of the Southern Coast Ranges of California.

ecoregions.title: California Montane Chaparral and Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies the Transverse Ranges of southern California, from north of Santa Barbara to northeast of San Bernardino, and the Peninsular Ranges, from east of San Jacinto southward to east of San Diego, as well as several disjunct blocks in northern Baja California.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/73bde107-6c5f-41da-a9e4-3ca2e4f6ab47/424 California montane chaparral and woodlands - jsanchezd.jpg

ecoregions.title: California Interior Chaparral and Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion wraps around California’s Central Valley, extending from Shasta Lake in the north to the vicinity of Wheeler Ridge in the south.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b453db4f-d2f4-439c-9227-840d242635a1/423 California interior chaparral and woodlands - David Mark.jpg

ecoregions.title: California Coastal Sage and Chaparral
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches from the vicinity of Santa Barbara, California, southward along the coastal plain, coastal terraces, and mountains south of the east-west Traverse Ranges to northeastern Baja California, Mexico.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/144210cf-b028-40d2-a07f-4cf980ae57ca/422 California coastal sage and chaparral - D Olson.jpg

ecoregions.title: California Central Valley Grasslands
ecoregions.dek: The California Central Valley ecoregion stretches from Red Bluff, California, southeastward 720 km to the vicinity of Wheeler Ridge.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/eb5019ea-cee0-4661-aef9-86d7c5ab81ba/385 California Central Valley grasslands -Gary Kramer USDA.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sierra Nevada Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies between the California Central Valley Grasslands ecoregion to the west, which is enveloped by the California Interior Chaparral and Woodlands ecoregion, and the Great Basin Shrub Steppe ecoregion to the east.

children.name: Cascades Mountain Forests & Valleys (NA16)
children.content:
The Cascades bioregion, located in the Pacific Coast subrealm of Northern America, is defined by the dense forests of the Cascades Range, stretching from northern California to the Canadian border. This bioregion also incorporates the grasslands at the foot of the Cascades Range in western Oregon. It contains four distinct ecoregions – North Cascades Conifer Forests (358), Central-Southern Cascades Forests (352), Eastern Cascades Forests (354), Willamette Valley Oak Savanna (403) – and includes the Columbia Gorge and many lakes dotted throughout the region. The land area of this bioregion is approximately 16 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Cascades Mountain Forests & Valleys ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: North Cascades Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses the northern section of the Cascades Mountains in Washington and adjacent British Columbia.

ecoregions.title: Eastern Cascades Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion spans the eastern slope of the Cascades Mountains.

ecoregions.title: Central-Southern Cascades Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches from the northern edge of the Sierra Nevada Range in California, just south of Mt. Lassen, northward through western Oregon to north of Mt. Rainier in Washington.

ecoregions.title: Willamette Valley Oak Savanna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies the Willamette River Valley of northwest Oregon, between the Cascade Mountains and the Oregon Coast Range.

children.name: Pacific Northwest Coastal Forests (NA15)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e584b5c0-7596-4bd5-88e7-d6afae7d8741/351 Central Pacific Northwest coastal forests - Rhett Butler.jpg

children.content:
The Pacific Northwest, located in the Northern America (Nearctic) realm, is an expansive coastal bioregion that stretches from the Santa Cruz Mountains in California, crossing over the San Francisco Peninsula, to Graham Island in British Columbia. The bioregion is famous for its old growth redwood forests and includes six ecoregions – British Columbia Coastal Conifer Forests (349), Central Pacific Northwest Coastal Forests (351), Klamath-Siskiyou Forests (357), Northern California Coastal Forests (359), Puget Lowland Forests (364), Haida Gwaii Conifer Forests (365) – and adjacent marine areas. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 30 million hectares. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Pacific Northwest Coastal Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Northern California Coastal Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is often called the Redwood Region because it encompasses most of the range of one of the truly spectacular forests on Earth—the coast redwood forest.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/18706eed-9da9-4d68-a0a1-d7702424f023/359 Northern California coastal forests - D Olson.jpg

ecoregions.title: Klamath-Siskiyou Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is the most biologically important temperate forest ecoregion in all of western North America, in terms of concentrations of endemic species and ancient lineages.

ecoregions.title: Haida Gwaii Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses all 150 islands and the many islets in this archipelago.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/542d0db7-c946-40c6-89c6-156b4e9cc0fe/365 Queen Charlotte Islands conifer forests - Sam Beebe.jpg

ecoregions.title: Puget Lowland Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is centered on a north-south depression, the Puget Trough, between the Cascade Range and the Olympic Peninsula in Washington, including Seattle.

ecoregions.title: Central Pacific Northwest Coastal Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a thin but long ecoregion extending from the southern Oregon coast in the south, northward through coastal Washington and British Columbia to the border with Alaska.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e584b5c0-7596-4bd5-88e7-d6afae7d8741/351 Central Pacific Northwest coastal forests - Rhett Butler.jpg

ecoregions.title: British Columbia Coastal Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies between the Pacific Coastal Mountain Icefields and Tundra ecoregion to the west and the Central British Columbia Mountain Forests ecoregion to the east.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8cbfb119-1596-4ff2-ba3c-d212197ce80e/349 British Columbia coastal conifer forests - Sam Beebe.jpg

children.name: Interior Plateau & Southern Great Lakes Forests (NA23)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1cda266e-bb3f-4705-8367-a61c4010d977/336 Interior Plateau US Hardwood Forests - Reed Noss_resized.jpg

children.content:
The Interior Plateau bioregion, located in the Northeast American Forests subrealm of Northern America, sits between the Appalachian Mountains to the east and the central grassland-forest transition to the west, extending northward to include the eastern half of Lake Michigan and the entirety of Lake Erie. It contains two ecoregions – Interior Plateau US Hardwood Forests (336), Southern Great Lakes Forests (342) – and is dominated by broadleaf forest. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 35 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Interior Plateau & Southern Great Lakes Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Southern Great Lakes Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies much of the industrial heartland of North America and is also highly agricultural.

ecoregions.title: Interior Plateau US Hardwood Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies to the west of the Cumberland Plateau and includes a small part of northern Alabama, most of central Tennessee, central and western Kentucky, and the southernmost portions of Illinois, Indiana, and southwestern Ohio.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1cda266e-bb3f-4705-8367-a61c4010d977/336 Interior Plateau US Hardwood Forests - Reed Noss_resized.jpg

children.name: Appalachia & Allegheny Interior Forests (NA24)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/74ca34a9-3871-46a5-aa41-28261bcfe155/328 Allegheny Highlands forests - Nicholas A Tonelli CC.jpg

children.content:
The Appalachia & Allegheny bioregion, located in the Northeast American Forests subrealm of Northern America, extends from central Alabama all the way up to the highlands of central New York, following the line of the Blue Ridge Mountains. It is dominated by broadleaf forests but contains four unique ecoregions – Allegheny Highlands Forests (328), Appalachian Mixed Mesophytic Forests (329), Appalachian Piedmont Forests (330), Appalachian-Blue Ridge Forests (331) – including numerous rivers and small lakes. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 58.5 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Appalachia & Allegheny Interior Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Appalachian-Blue Ridge forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes the Blue Ridge and Valley and Ridge physiographic provinces, a long region stretching from central Alabama northeastward to New York state and including portions of 10 states.

ecoregions.title: Appalachian Piedmont Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies between the Coastal Plain and the Appalachian Mountains.

ecoregions.title: Appalachian Mixed Mesophytic Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes the Cumberland Plateau, Cumberland Mountains, and much of the Allegheny Plateau physiographic provinces, stretching from northern Alabama to western Pennsylvania.

ecoregions.title: Allegheny Highlands Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses a large part of the Allegheny Plateau physiographic province, including both unglaciated and glaciated portions, in Pennsylvania and New York.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/74ca34a9-3871-46a5-aa41-28261bcfe155/328 Allegheny Highlands forests - Nicholas A Tonelli CC.jpg

children.name: Northern Great Lakes Forests (NA11)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/01a09930-5c24-4b63-81e8-1e0c816e2100/333-Jacques-Cartier River valley from Andante montain, Jacques-Cartier National Park, Quebec, Canada-CC-2009_resized.jpg

children.content:
The Northern Great Lakes bioregion, located in the Northeast American Forests subrealm in Northern America, spans from Quebec to Minnesota just below the Canadian Shield forests. The bioregion is predominantly made up of broadleaf forests and includes four ecoregions – Western Great Lakes Forests [1],  Upper Midwest US Forest-Savanna Transition [2], Eastern Canadian Temperate-Boreal Forest Transition [3], Eastern Great Lakes Lowland Forests [4] – encompassing most of the Great Lakes. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 193 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Northern Great Lakes Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Western Great Lakes Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches from Michigan, where it encompasses nearly half of the Lower Peninsula and all of the Upper Peninsula, through northern Wisconsin and Minnesota, southwestern Ontario, to the southeastern corner of Manitoba.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b57cc56a-8746-4d15-acd5-8c5d06090db0/344 Western Great Lakes forests - Reed Noss.jpg

ecoregions.title: Upper Midwest US Forest-Savanna Transition
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses most of the Minneapolis-St. Paul metropolitan area and many smaller cities.

ecoregions.title: Eastern Great Lakes Lowland Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers most of the region around the eastern Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence River.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/6b01c793-e704-4d10-9ff9-6e044f090a45/334 Eastern Great Lakes lowland forests - Yinan Chen.jpg

ecoregions.title: Eastern Canadian Temperate-Boreal Forest Transition
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses the southern portion of the Canadian (Precambrian) Shield in Ontario and Quebec, with the southern boundary of the Shield defining the southern border of this ecoregion.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5ac803c5-6f7a-45f2-8e78-300dc4ba9bee/333 Eastern Canadian Forest-Boreal transition - Denise Riches.jpg

children.name: Northeastern American Mixed Forests (NA10)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5196d99b-3c00-410d-b78a-af40dce46908/338 New England-Acadian Forests Kejimkujik National Park Davis Bennett cc.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/92d216a9-d30a-4b6e-a98d-895822ef3f2f/335 Gulf of St. Lawrence lowland forests - Graham Hobster.jpg

children.content:
The Northeastern American bioregion, located in the Northern America (Nearctic) realm, extends from the top of New Brunswick, Canada to the Blue Ridge mountains in the mid-Atlantic region of the US. The bioregion is predominantly made up of broadleaf forests and includes three ecoregions – Northeast US Coastal Forests [1], New England-Acadian Forests [2], Gulf of St. Lawrence Lowland Forests [3] – covering most of the Northeastern Seaboard. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 44 million hectares. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Northeastern American Mixed Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Northeast US Coastal Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches across a long strip of latitude and includes parts of 11 states, from Virginia to southern Maine.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/bd5eb3c4-0562-4416-97ed-3fa327eaa906/339 Northeast US Coastal forests - David Mark.jpg

ecoregions.title: New England-Acadian Forests
ecoregions.dek: This vast ecoregion has a humid cold temperate to boreal climate. The entire region, including most of the coastal zone, is hilly to mountainous, with the highest elevations in the White Mountains of New Hampshire.

ecoregions.title: Gulf of St. Lawrence Lowland Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is surrounded by the New England-Acadian Forests ecoregion and the Atlantic Ocean’s Gulf of St. Lawrence.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/92d216a9-d30a-4b6e-a98d-895822ef3f2f/335 Gulf of St. Lawrence lowland forests - Graham Hobster.jpg

children.name: Southern Mixed Forests & Blackland Prairies (NA28)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/640bcf2a-8286-46e4-b6a2-907c5880843d/363 Piney Woods Forests William L. Farr cc.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2d5fdf69-c4ff-4099-94cb-12e3edbe9c82/363 Piney Woods Forests William L. Farr cc4.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/c4487674-81bf-4e7c-9915-103705e1f75c/363 Piney Woods Forests William L. Farr cc2.jpg

children.content:
The Southern Mixed Forests bioregion, located in the Southeast U.S. Savannas & Forests subrealm of Northern America, consists of a swathe of forests through eastern Texas surrounded on two sides by Blackland prairie, with a large area of pines to the north. The bioregion consists of three ecoregions – East Central Texas Savanna-Woodland (332), Piney Woods Forests (363), Texas Blackland Prairies (401) – and includes the Sabine River. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 25 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Southern Mixed Forests & Blackland Prairies ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Texas Blackland Prairies
ecoregions.dek: The northern portion encompasses the city of Dallas, whereas the narrow southern portion encompasses most of Austin and San Antonio.

ecoregions.title: Piney Woods Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies the West Gulf Coastal Plain and encompasses eastern Texas (including the “Big Thicket”) as well as western Louisiana, southwestern Arkansas, and a small portion of southeastern Oklahoma.

ecoregions.title: East Central Texas Savanna-Woodland
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a relatively long (in latitude) but narrow ecoregion almost entirely confined to Texas, plus a small part of southeastern Oklahoma north of the Red River.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/3f84a4dc-bc8b-4b28-901a-fe2dab0e4371/332 East Central Texas forests - Travis Witt.JPG

children.name: Western Gulf Coastal Grasslands (NA27)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/12357f02-e5fc-4603-91ca-b5402bbd43d9/384 Western Gulf Coastal Grasslands William L. Farr cc.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a3b23aac-746a-4169-9bb2-8e77392ec765/384 Western Gulf Coastal Grasslands Katy Prairie Conservancy cc.jpeg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/791e11d8-e593-4b89-9c70-2e4dd8b419f0/384 Western Gulf Coastal Grasslands William L Farr cc copy.jpg

children.content:
The Western Gulf bioregion is unique in the Northern America (Nearctic) realm as the only example of a subtropical grasslands biome. Situated within the Southeast U.S. Savannas & Forests subrealm it runs along the coast of Texas and consists of one single ecoregion – Western Gulf Coastal Grasslands (384) – and includes the adjacent marine area in the Gulf of Mexico. Its land area is approximately 9 million hectares. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the Western Gulf Coastal Grasslands ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Western Gulf Coastal Grasslands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is part of the North American Coastal Plain, which in 2016 was formally recognized by the Critical Ecosystem Partnership Fund as the 36th global biodiversity hotspot.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/12357f02-e5fc-4603-91ca-b5402bbd43d9/384 Western Gulf Coastal Grasslands William L. Farr cc.jpg

children.name: Bermuda (NA26)
children.content:
Bermuda is an island over 1000 km from the Atlantic seaboard, and as an outlying island covered with subtropical conifer forests, it is unique in the Northern America (Nearctic) realm. It consists of one single ecoregion – Bermuda Subtropical Conifer Forests (325) – and the marine areas surrounding the island. Its land area is approximately 4000 hectares. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about  the Bermuda ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Bermuda Subtropical Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Bermuda Islands are an isolated, crescent-shaped chain of more than 150 limestone islands distinguished by the northernmost mangrove swamps and tropical coral reefs in the Atlantic Ocean.

children.name: Southeast Savannas & Riparian Forests (NA25)
children.content:
The Southeast Savannas bioregion, located in the Northern America (Nearctic) realm, covers much of the Atlantic seaboard and the Southeast U.S. Savannas & Forests subrealm. It consists predominantly of coastal and conifer savannas but includes the Atlantic coastal pine barrens in the north and the Mississippi lowland forests to the west. The bioregion contains four ecoregions – Mississippi Lowland Forests (337), Atlantic Coastal Pine Barrens (347), Mid-Atlantic US Coastal Savannas (393), Southeast US Conifer Savannas (399) – and includes adjacent marine areas in the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico, as well as the lower section of the Mississippi River. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 73 million hectares. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Southeast Savannas & Riparian Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Southeast US Conifer Savannas
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is the biologically richest portion of the North American Coastal Plain.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a8444185-fac7-4f61-b441-18024498ee0c/399 Southeast US conifer savannas - Reed Noss.jpg

ecoregions.title: Mid-Atlantic US Coastal Savannas
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a northern extension of the vast Southeast US Conifer Savannas ecoregion.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a211d6a1-5cb7-4e26-b728-c75f276ba354/393 Mid-Atlantic US coastal savannas - Reed Noss_resized.jpg

ecoregions.title: Atlantic Coastal Pine Barrens
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion represents the northern end of the North American Coastal Plain geological region.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2fd971ef-a32f-4b9b-a6a6-fd40e7fe5f5f/347 Atlantic coastal pine barrens - David Mark.jpg

ecoregions.title: Mississippi Lowland Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies the lower portion of this watershed, along the Mississippi River and its tributaries from the river mouth in Louisiana to the southern tip of Illinois.

children.name: Ozarks Mixed Forests (NA22)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/6c07fa19-ce92-4c24-81bc-ae39df0e6b1f/341 Alberta-British Columbia Foothills Forests As2020sa cc.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/46327f04-15f8-44cd-9cde-979ba6b26ebd/340 Ozark Highlands mixed forests - David Mark.jpg

children.content:
The bioregion spanning the forests of the Ozark mountains and highlands, located in the Southeast US Savannas & Forests subrealm of Northern America, sits between the pine woods to the south and the central grassland-forest transition to the north, bordered to the east by the lower Mississippi valley. It contains two ecoregions—Ozark Highlands Mixed Forests (340), Ozark Mountain Forests (341)—and includes most of the Arkansas River. The total area of this bioregion is nearly 18 million hectares.

Learn more about each of the Ozarks Mixed Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Ozark Mountain Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion comprises the Boston Mountains (a deeply dissected plateau that forms the southwestern and highest portion of the Ozark Plateau), the Arkansas (River) Valley, and the Ouachita Mountains.

ecoregions.title: Ozark Highlands Mixed Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion constitutes the western portion of the central hardwoods forest region of the United States, but as a transitional region between forest and prairie it also contains many types of grassland.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/46327f04-15f8-44cd-9cde-979ba6b26ebd/340 Ozark Highlands mixed forests - David Mark.jpg

children.name: Baja California & Southern Deserts (NA30)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f3219098-a072-4b2d-9a1a-65612009f88f/435-El Pinacate y Gran Desierto de Altar Biosphere Reserve, NW México.-CC-2010.jpg

children.content:
The Baja California bioregion, located within the larger Mexican Drylands subrealm of Northern America, includes most of the Baja Peninsula and the scorching deserts of southern California. The bioregion contains four ecoregions – Baja California Desert (426), Gulf of California Xeric Scrub (431), Mojave Desert (433), Sonoran Desert (435) – and adjacent marine areas in the Gulf of California and the Pacific Ocean. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 45 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Baja California & Southern Deserts ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Sonoran Desert
ecoregions.dek: In addition to portions of Arizona and Sonora, the Sonoran Desert occupies southeastern California (south of the Mojave Desert) and northeastern Baja California.

ecoregions.title: Mojave Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers southern Nevada and portions of western Arizona and southeastern California.

ecoregions.title: Gulf of California Xeric Scrub
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches along the eastern coast of the Baja Peninsula, bordering the Gulf of California from Bufeo in the north to La Paz in the south.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e7db277a-4654-44a2-84a1-fd5c11ee24c9/431 Gulf of California xeric scrub - Eduardo Chavez.jpg

ecoregions.title: Baja California Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is one of the wildest and most intact ecoregions in Mexico, occupying most of the Baja California Peninsula and almost all of its western portion in both the states of Baja California Norte and Baja California Sur.

children.name: Sierra Madre Forests & Mexican Drylands (NA29)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/070c1a68-eac8-439a-9cec-e9805b368410/326 Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests - Rael.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/882eaca6-46a8-4d40-b9e8-2b9c0208ba78/428-Yucca, creosote, and mesquite typify the plants in the Chihuahuan Desert-VanHorn-TX-Eco 428-CC-2008.jpg

children.content:
The Sierra Madre bioregion, located in the Northern America (Nearctic) realm, covers the upper half of Mexico and consists of an array of different ecoregions that are tightly interconnected. The bioregion is dominated by desert and dry shrublands, but the eastern and western ranges of the Sierra Madres are covered with subtropical pine and oak forests. It contains eight ecoregions – Sonoran-Sinaloan Subtropical Dry Forest (324), Sierra Madre Occidental Pine-Oak Forests (326), Sierra Madre Oriental Pine-Oak Forests (327), Central Mexican Matorral (427), Chihuahuan Desert (428), Meseta Central Matorral (432), Tamaulipan Matorral (436), Tamaulipan Mezquital (437). The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 116 million hectares. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Northern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Sierra Madre Forests & Mexican Drylands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Tamaulipan Mezquital
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies the southwestern portion of the Gulf Coastal Plain in southern Texas and northeastern Mexico.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b18ba3ab-315f-41ee-8036-2fa98a2ed24b/437 Tamaulipan mezquital - Texas Parks _ Wildlife Department.jpg

ecoregions.title: Tamaulipan Matorral
ecoregions.dek: The Tamaulipan Matorral is a small ecoregion located in a transitional area between the Nearctic and Neotropic realms

ecoregions.title: Meseta Central Matorral
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is an arid lowland plain separating the massive mountain ranges of the Sierra Madre.

ecoregions.title: Chihuahuan Desert
ecoregions.dek: The Chihuahuan Desert, the largest and most biologically diverse North American desert, sprawls across southeastern Arizona, southern New Mexico, much of western Texas, and north-central Mexico.

ecoregions.title: Central Mexican Matorral
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a relatively flat desert, with elevations up to 2,000 m, surrounded by mountains and with mountain ranges embedded within it.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/ae96ad07-2b9e-4312-bbdd-65e837a365b6/427 Central Mexican matorral - Comisión Mexicana de Filmaciones.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sierra Madre Oriental Pine-Oak Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends from several isolated mountain ranges in the southwestern U.S., including the Davis and Chisos Mountains in the Big Bend area of Texas and the San Andres and Organ Mountains of southern New Mexico, south through several Mexican states to just northeast of Mexico City.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/6d574e12-f191-45bc-8a80-06ab15bbf128/327 Sierra Madre Oriental pine-oak forests - cortesab.jpg

ecoregions.title: Sierra Madre Occidental Pine-Oak Forests
ecoregions.dek: Stretching from southeastern Arizona’s “sky islands” to just north of Guadalajara in Jalisco, this extensive ecoregion is one of the most species-rich in North America

ecoregions.title: Sonoran-Sinaloan Subtropical Dry Forest
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is transitional between the Nearctic Sonoran Desert to the north and west and the Neotropic Sinaloan Dry Forests to the south and east.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/156ed228-255a-4abe-a857-764f8e257b7a/324 Sonoran-Sinaloan subtropical dry forest - Tomas Castelazo.jpg

children.name: Hawai’i Tropical Islands (OC11)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/cdfc0339-92b9-4534-ac24-c7942de688b9/639 Hawai'i tropical high shrublands - Amelia Leubscher.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f6059746-bf82-4ba7-826d-ce86cee83ce0/641 Northwest Hawai_i scrub - Cindy Rehkemper USDI.jpg

children.content:
The Hawai’i Tropical Islands bioregion is located in the Oceania realm and contains five ecoregions – Hawai'i Tropical Moist Forests [1], Hawai'i Tropical Dry Forests [2], Hawai'i Tropical High Shrublands [3], Hawai'i Tropical Low Shrublands [4], Northwest Hawai'i Scrub [5] – totaling over 1.5 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Oceania. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Hawai’i Tropical Islands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Northwest Hawai'I Scrub
ecoregions.dek: The far-flung chain of nine major islands extends approximately 1,600 km from rocky Nihoa in the southeast to low Kure Atoll.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f6059746-bf82-4ba7-826d-ce86cee83ce0/641 Northwest Hawai_i scrub - Cindy Rehkemper USDI.jpg

ecoregions.title: Hawai'I Tropical Low Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion contains the driest of all lowland habitats in the archipelago.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/eb1502ad-55b1-42b9-b962-9422a114c1c1/640 Hawai_i tropical low shrublands - Forest _ Kim Starr.jpg

ecoregions.title: Hawai'i Tropical High Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion’s alpine deserts, alpine grasslands, and sparse shrublands occur above 3,000 m up to 4,207 m and only support a few hardy drought- and cold-adapted species.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/cdfc0339-92b9-4534-ac24-c7942de688b9/639 Hawai'i tropical high shrublands - Amelia Leubscher.jpg

ecoregions.title: Hawai'I Tropical Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The leeward side of the main islands of Hawai’i are drier as the central ranges and large volcanoes capture much of the rain brought by the trade winds.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/6cd6f09a-52cb-4ad5-a50e-70b5d8846e38/636 Hawai'i tropical dry forests - Arthur Madeiros.JPG

ecoregions.title: Hawai'I Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Tropical moist forests of Hawai'i occur as mixed mesic forests, rain forests, wet shrublands, and bogs in swampy areas.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/114e05f6-84ee-4266-85a0-6e35c8f79fd6/623 Hawai'i tropical moist forests - D Olson_resized.jpg

children.name: Guam & Marianas Dry Tropical Islands (OC9)
children.content:
The Guam & Marianas Dry Tropical Islands bioregion is located in the Oceania realm and contains one ecoregion – Marianas Tropical Dry Forests [1] – totaling approximately 104 thousand hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Oceania. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the Guam & Marianas Dry Tropical Islands ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Marianas Tropical Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Mariana Islands cover a 900 km arc in the western Pacific Ocean.

children.name: Palau & Caroline Tropical Islands (OC8)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/90127115-fb7e-4753-943d-75389d44fddf/627 Palau tropical moist forests - Jay Park.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/49d9be6f-4a04-4f26-9ec6-7026d04f5084/638 Yap tropical dry forests - Pacific Worlds Yap-Ulithi.jpg

children.content:
The Palau & Caroline Tropical Islands bioregion is located in the Oceania realm and contains three ecoregions – Carolines Tropical Moist Forests [1], Palau Tropical Moist Forests [2], Yap Tropical Dry Forests [3] – totaling approximately 114 thousand hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Oceania. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Palau & Caroline Tropical Islands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Yap Tropical Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Yap Islands group is located about 450 km northeast of Palau.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/49d9be6f-4a04-4f26-9ec6-7026d04f5084/638 Yap tropical dry forests - Pacific Worlds Yap-Ulithi.jpg

ecoregions.title: Palau Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: An incredible 586 islands make up the archipelago of Palau in western Micronesia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/90127115-fb7e-4753-943d-75389d44fddf/627 Palau tropical moist forests - Jay Park.jpg

ecoregions.title: Carolines Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Caroline Islands includes the Remetau Group, Chuuk, Pohnpei, and Kosrae.

children.name: Fiji & Tongan Tropical Islands (OC6)
children.content:
The Fiji & Tongan Tropical Islands bioregion is located in the Oceanic Islands subrealm and contains four ecoregions—Fiji Tropical Moist Forests [622], Kermadec Islands Subtropical Moist Forests [624], Tongan Tropical Moist Forests [631], Fiji Tropical Dry Forests [635]—totaling approximately two million hectares of land area.

Learn more about each of the Fiji & Tongan Tropical Islands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Fiji Tropical Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, the two biggest islands in Fiji, has about a third of their land area covered in dry forest along each of their northwest lowlands.

ecoregions.title: Tongan Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Tongan islands are volcanic, though the southern island of 'Eua is believed to be a fragment of the ancient Gondwanaland supercontinent and may harbor some ancient invertebrates and plants.

ecoregions.title: Fiji Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Out of over 300 islands, the islands of Viti Levu and Vanua Levu occupy 78% of the ecoregion’s land area and support the tallest mountain at 1,323 m.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/caa21140-e9de-408d-8593-dd5f990c28c7/622 Fiji tropical moist forests - M Tokatoa'a.jpg

ecoregions.title: Kermadec Islands Subtropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The remote Kermadec archipelago occurs in an island chain of 13 small islands 1,000 km northeast of North Cape, New Zealand.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/33625ffe-a3e3-4817-ac98-3fd5409e6d0a/624 Kermadec Islands subtropical moist forests Lawrie Mead.jpg

children.name: Samoa & West Polynesian Tropical Islands (OC5)
children.content:
The Samoa & West Polynesian Tropical Islands bioregion is located in the Oceania realm and contains two ecoregions – Samoan Tropical Moist Forests [1],  Western Polynesian Tropical Moist Forests [2]  – totaling approximately 319 thousand hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Oceania. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Samoa & West Polynesian Tropical Islands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Western Polynesian Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The ecoregion has three clusters of atolls and makatea islands (uplifted reefs): 8 atolls in the Phoenix Islands; 4 in Tokelau; and 9 in Tuvalu.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/956d0ec7-d546-4fa2-b1bc-5aed6046068b/634 Western Polynesian tropical moist forests - Angela K Kepler.jpg

ecoregions.title: Samoan Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Samoa consists of a chain of 14 volcanic islands located 600 km east of Fiji.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/69db3208-d43a-4d2b-9675-a4bd0dd89138/629 Samoan tropical moist forests - James Atherton.jpg

children.name: Central Polynesian Islands (OC4)
children.content:
The Central Polynesian Islands bioregion is located in the Oceania realm and contains one ecoregion – Central Polynesian Tropical Moist Forests [1] – totaling approximately 62 thousand hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Oceania. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the Central Polynesian Islands ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Central Polynesian Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses the Northern Line Islands, Southern Line Islands, and Northern Cook Islands. Isolated Johnston is also included in this ecoregion.

children.name: Southeast Polynesian Islands (OC3)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/d16abfb7-275f-43ec-82f9-12151d2c983a/620 Cook Islands tropical moist forests - Robert Issell.jpg

children.content:
The Southeast Polynesian Islands bioregion is located in the Oceania realm and contains four ecoregions – Cook Islands Tropical Moist Forests [1], Society Islands Tropical Moist Forests [2], Tuamotu Tropical Moist Forests [3], Tubuai Tropical Moist Forests [4]  – totaling approximately 293 thousand hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Oceania. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Southeast Polynesian Islands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Tubuai Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Like the Society Islands to the north, the Tubuai Islands are eroded volcanic peaks that are surrounded by uplifted limestone reef.

ecoregions.title: Tuamotu Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This vast ecoregion encompasses the 76 atolls and islands of Tuamotu, and stretches 1,800 km to the Gambier Islands and the Pitcairn Islands 1,000 km to the east.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/c353516b-3146-49ac-b515-6136dd9f854b/632 Tuamotu tropical moist forests - Mark Van Beirs Birdquest.jpg

ecoregions.title: Society Islands Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: These verdant islands are covered in lowland rain forest, montane rain forest, and, at the highest points, cloud forest.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/50041550-1c5d-4528-9a0e-67322f1f39e9/630 Society Islands tropical moist forests - Yanik1214.jpg

ecoregions.title: Cook Islands Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Cook Islands, one of the most remote archipelagos in the world, are home to some of the planet’s most dazzling birds.

children.name: Marquesas Tropical Islands (OC2)
children.content:
The Marquesas Tropical Islands bioregion is located in the Oceania realm and contains one ecoregion – Marquesas Tropical Moist Forests [1]  – totaling approximately 108 thousand hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Oceania. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the Marquesas Tropical Islands ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Marquesas Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The 12 Marquesas Islands are volcanic high islands with very rugged topography, knife-edged ridges, deeply dissected gorges, and cliffs plunging from mountaintops steeply to sea level.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/9246d4c5-96aa-42be-b037-6d3b56e0127b/625 Marquesas tropical moist forests - Jack Grove.jpg

children.name: Salas y Gómez & Easter Islands (OC1)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/16866395-b364-4eab-bce3-a83e1beb5644/628 Rapa Nui and Sala y Gómez subtropical forests - kai2015.jpg

children.content:
The Salas y Gómez & Easter Islands bioregion is located in the Oceania realm and contains one ecoregion – Rapa Nui and Sala y Gómez Subtropical Broadleaf Forests [1] – totaling approximately 18 thousand hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Oceania. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the Salas y Gómez & Easter Islands ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Rapa Nui and Sala Y Gómez Subtropical Broadleaf Forests
ecoregions.dek: This isolated volcanic island in the eastern Pacific supported a simple and  unique ecosystem until Polynesians arrived thousands of years ago and transformed it to grass savannas.

children.name: Ogasawara Subtropical Islands (OC10)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7b30957d-e1dc-4aeb-8e07-b3e51311079d/Ogasawara Subtropical Moist Forests Anagounagi, Creative Commons.jpg

children.content:
The Ogasawara Subtropical Islands bioregion is located in the Oceania realm and contains a single ecoregion – Ogasawara Subtropical Moist Forests [1] – totaling approximately 10 thousand hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Oceania. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the Ogasawara Subtropical Islands ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Ogasawara Subtropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Ogawasara (or Bonin) and Iwo (or Volcano) Islands are a widely scattered archipelago of 20 major volcanic islands once covered in subtropical moist and dry forests.

children.name: East Micronesian Islands (OC7)
children.content:
The East Micronesian Islands bioregion is located in the Oceania realm and contains one ecoregion – Eastern Micronesia Tropical Moist Forests [1] – totaling approximately 53 thousand hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Oceania. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the East Micronesian Islands ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Eastern Micronesia Tropical Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Low atolls scattered across the central Pacific comprise this ecoregion, with Wake Island and Nauru as single-island outliers, and the Marshall Islands and Kiribati archipelagos of many islands.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8158e809-29ef-4289-8478-02f0da14c9fd/621 Eastern Micronesia tropical moist forests - Peter Mellow.jpg

children.name: Andean Mountain Forests & Valleys (NT11)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/56930e08-c067-4fc8-8103-aa5759461104/593-Crested Roses (Espeletia) in the Páramo de Guerrero of Colombia-Eco 593-CC-Friedrich Kircher-2008.JPG

children.content:
The Andean Mountain bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, is the upper half of the Andes mountain range, stretching from the very top of the continent to northern Argentina. The bioregion is defined by tropical and subtropical broadleaf forests with 17 unique ecoregions – Bolivian Yungas (444), Cauca Valley Montane Forests (448), Cordillera Oriental Montane Forests (457), Eastern Cordillera Real Montane Forests (460), Magdalena Valley Montane Forests (477), Marañón Dry Forests (479), Northwest Andean Montane Forests (486), Peruvian Yungas (493), Southern Andean Yungas (504), Venezuelan Andes Montane Forests (513), Bolivian Montane Dry Forests (523), Cauca Valley Dry Forests (526), Magdalena Valley Dry Forests (538), Patia Valley Dry Forests (542), Cordillera Central Páramo (590), Cordillera De Merida Páramo (591), Northern Andean Páramo (593) – which run along the more humid eastern side of the Andes. This bioregion contains the three sacred headwaters of the Amazon River. Its land area is approximately 93 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Andean Mountain Forests & Valleys ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Northern Andean Páramo
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes the high altitude wet grasslands that are above the tree line and below the snow line within the equatorial Andes.

ecoregions.title: Cordillera De Merida Páramo
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion consists of specialized high elevation grassland communities which occur in three distinct oblong patches.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/30bff2db-bc1f-4efb-97af-6c20066f5b25/591 Cordillera de Merida páramo - Cristo Adolfo.jpg

ecoregions.title: Cordillera Central Páramo
ecoregions.dek: Essential for the regional water cycle, this ecoregion is the origin of many streams running down the Pacific and Atlantic slopes.

ecoregions.title: Patía valley dry forests
ecoregions.dek: The Patía Valley is a dry pocket “valley” surrounded by the cloud forests of the Central and Western cordilleras of Colombia.

ecoregions.title: Magdalena Valley Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion, located within the Northern Andes, occurs along the dry inter-Andean valley formed by the largest river in Colombia, the Magdalena.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b359078e-41fc-4de1-8207-d0169e8965a3/538 Magdalena Valley dry forest - Javier Lopez.jpg

ecoregions.title: Cauca Valley Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The dry inter-Andean valley is located between the west and central Andes in Colombia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/07bc8db8-61fc-4049-9fe1-0973aab7cce6/526 Cauca Valley dry forests - Ariel Jiminez Gil.jpg

ecoregions.title: Bolivian Montane Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is restricted to south-central Bolivia, flanking the eastern Andes, and barely reaching northwest Argentina.

ecoregions.title: Venezuelan Andes Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies montane forests at middle elevations of the Venezuelan Andes, a northeastern branch of the Andes mountain range.

ecoregions.title: Southern Andean Yungas
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion, spanning across southwestern Bolivia and northwestern Argentina, is loosely bordered on the east by dry lowland vegetation of the Chaco and tightly on the west by the Bolivian Montane dry forests.

ecoregions.title: Peruvian Yungas
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion flanks the eastern slopes of the Andes, roughly from the Marañon Valley depression northern Peru to near the Rio Huari Huari (Cordillera Carabaya) near the Bolivian border.

ecoregions.title: Northwest Andean Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is found in northwest South America in the center of Colombia and Ecuador within a 150 km wide chain of the Andes Mountains.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/ace629a5-ddf4-4002-bba2-d3decfa49eb1/486 Northwest Andean Montane Forests - R Noss.jpg

ecoregions.title: Marañon Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends along the upper Marañon River valley and its tributaries in northwestern Peru.

ecoregions.title: Magdalena Valley Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: Magdalena Valley Forests grow on the inner slopes of the Eastern and Central cordilleras in the Northern Andes of Colombia.

ecoregions.title: Eastern Cordillera Real Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Eastern Cordillera Real Montane Forests ecoregion is located on the eastern slopes of the middle Andes, extending north-south from southern Colombia, through Ecuador, and into northern Peru.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/336c1f02-1a28-4346-a2f5-8531b42c0885/460 Eastern Cordillera Real montane forests - Alejandro Miranda.jpg

ecoregions.title: Cordillera Oriental Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: These forests span the eastern slopes of the Andean Cordillera Oriental from their northernmost point southwards through most of Colombia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8131146b-6deb-43d8-851f-97440601deac/457 Cordillera Oriental montane forests - Lucia Mafilito.jpg

ecoregions.title: Cauca Valley Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: Located at the northwestern end of the Andes Mountain Range in southwestern Colombia, the Cauca Valley is nestled between the western and central ranges of the Andes and stretches for 600 km in a south-north direction.

ecoregions.title: Bolivian Yungas
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion in Bolivia and parts of Peru forms a transition along the Andean slope between Amazonian and highland Puna habitats, which contributes to the high levels of biodiversity and endemism characterizing this unique ecoregion.

children.name: Ecuadorean Dry Coastal Forests & Flooded Grasslands (NT10)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e5bdcd81-b409-49bd-aa1d-83cddd9606f5/516 Western Ecuador moist forests - Albert Dezetter.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a06c6d06-5084-4ffa-a4a6-2a248b0a89cc/615 South American Pacific mangroves - Rhett Butler.jpg

children.content:
The Ecuadorian Dry Coastal bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, is centered on the Gulf of Guayaquil, the mouth of the Guayas River. The bioregion is dominated by dry forests, but it includes coastal moist forests to the north and flooded grasslands in its center with four terrestrial ecoregions -- Western Ecuador Moist Forests (516), Tumbes-Piura Dry Forests (549), Ecuadorian Dry Forests (531), Guayaquil Flooded Grasslands (582) – and adjacent marine areas, which include the South American Pacific Mangroves (615). The land area of this bioregion is approximately 10 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Ecuadorean Dry Coastal Forests & Flooded Grasslands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: South American Pacific Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The South American Pacific Mangrove ecoregion is comprised of five subecoregions.

ecoregions.title: Guayaquil Flooded Grasslands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is in the provinces of El Guayas, Los Ríos, and El Oro in Ecuador.

ecoregions.title: Tumbes-Piura Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This Tumbes-Piura Dry Forest ecoregion is located in the equatorial region of South American between the Pacific Ocean and the western slope of the Andes Mountains.

ecoregions.title: Ecuadorian Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends along the Pacific Coast southward from southern Esmeraldas province in northern Ecuador into the Guayas province, ending at the Golfo de Guayaquil.

ecoregions.title: Western Ecuador Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Located in southwestern Colombia and western Ecuador, the ecoregion boundaries extend from the Patia River in the north and ending at the foothills of the Andes Mountains in the east.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e5bdcd81-b409-49bd-aa1d-83cddd9606f5/516 Western Ecuador moist forests - Albert Dezetter.jpg

children.name: South American Coastal Deserts (NT8)
children.content:
The South American Coastal Deserts bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, occupies a narrow band west of the Andes Mountains, running along the Peruvian and northern Chilean coast. It contains two arid ecoregions – Atacama Desert (598), Sechura Desert (608) – and adjacent marine areas in the Pacific Ocean. The land area of this bioregion is approximately 29 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the South American Coastal Deserts ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Sechura Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies the western subtropical portion of South America. It borders the Pacific Ocean on the west and extends between 20–100 km inland on the east until reaching the Andean secondary ridges.

ecoregions.title: Atacama Desert
ecoregions.dek: The Atacama Desert is considered one of the driest coastal deserts in the world. It forms a continuous strip for nearly 1,000 km along the narrow coast of the northern third of Chile.

children.name: Juan Fernández & Desventuradas Islands (NT7)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/0e83dc6a-e89f-49cd-b5e1-5c77a5891a45/560 Juan Fernández Islands temperate forests - Serpentus.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8b1bd1a7-b7f6-4efc-89d2-4b6da2d79e8c/562 San Félix-San Ambrosio Islands temperate forests - Smithsonian Institution.jpg

children.content:
This small group of islands off the coast of Chile, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, make up a unique bioregion, consisting of temperate broadleaf forests and grasslands containing many endemic plant species. It also includes the rocky Desventuradas Islands, two ecoregions in total – Juan Fernández Islands Temperate Forests (560), San Félix-San Ambrosio Islands Temperate Forests (562) – and the surrounding marine areas, which contain a unique mix of tropical, subtropical, and temperate marine species and were recently designated as one of the largest marine parks in the Americas. The land area of this bioregion is nearly 16,000 hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Juan Fernández & Desventuradas Islands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: San Félix-San Ambrosio Islands Temperate Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Desventuradas archipelago, or “Unfortunate Islands”, are formed by four Pacific islands, including San Félix and San Ambrosio.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/8b1bd1a7-b7f6-4efc-89d2-4b6da2d79e8c/562 San Félix-San Ambrosio Islands temperate forests - Smithsonian Institution.jpg

ecoregions.title: Juan Fernández Islands Temperate Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Juan Fernández archipelago, also known as the Robinson Crusoe Islands, is located off the coast of Chile in the southeastern part of the Pacific Ocean.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/0e83dc6a-e89f-49cd-b5e1-5c77a5891a45/560 Juan Fernández Islands temperate forests - Serpentus.jpg

children.name: Chilean Matorral Shrublands & Savanna (NT6)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/6e8cd3c7-d474-4a14-bcfc-ad617961ad2c/596-Parque Nacional La Campana, Chili-2-Eco 596-CC-Jorge leon Cabello-2003_resized.jpg

children.content:
The Chilean Matorral, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, is South America’s only Mediterranean biome, a mix of hardwoods, shrubs, cacti, and grassland. It occupies a narrow band along the central coast of Chile and is made up of one single ecoregion – Chilean Matorral (596) – and includes many alpine lakes and adjacent marine areas in the Pacific Ocean. The land area of this bioregion is nearly 15 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the Chilean Matorral Shrublands & Savanna ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Chilean Matorral
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion constitutes a 100 km-wide strip extending along the central part of the Chilean coast between the Pacific Ocean to the west and the Andes Mountains to the east.

children.name: Andean Mountain Grasslands (NT5)
children.content:
The Andean Mountain Grasslands bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, is centered on the Altiplano, the world’s second highest plateau. It stretches from central Argentina to central Peru and is composed entirely of high-altitude grasslands. The bioregion contains five ecoregions – Central Andean Dry Puna (587), Central Andean Puna (588), Central Andean Wet Puna (589), High Monte (592), Southern Andean Steppe (595) – and incorporates Lake Titicaca, the largest lake in South America and one of the world’s highest bodies of water. The area of this bioregion is nearly 83 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Andean Mountain Grasslands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: High Monte
ecoregions.dek: The High Monte ecoregion, also called the High Monte desert locally, is bounded in the west in the rain shadow of the Andes, in the north by the high arid Puna, in the east by the arid–semiarid woodlands of the Chaco and Espinal.

ecoregions.title: Southern Andean Steppe
ecoregions.dek: A relatively untouched piece of nature, the Southren Andean Steppe ecoregion extends along the high elevations of the Andes of central Argentina and in part of Chile at altitudes between 1,800 and 5,000 m.

ecoregions.title: Central Andean Wet Puna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is located in the Andean Mountains of Peru and eastern Bolivia, with landscapes filled with snow-capped peaks, mountain grasslands, high lakes, plateaus, and valleys.

ecoregions.title: Central Andean Puna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a high elevation montane grassland in the southern high Andes, extending from southern Peru, though Bolivia, into northern Argentina.

ecoregions.title: Central Andean Dry Puna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is nestled between the tree-line and the permanent snow-line in a very dry region of this mountain range.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e7307dd7-0804-4e2f-806c-408394395b68/587 Central Andean Dry Puna - Cristian Ordenez.jpg

children.name: Galápagos Islands (NT9)
children.content:
The Galapagos bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, contains an archipelago of 61 volcanic islands and islands 520 nautical miles off the coast of Ecuador. With its array of plant, animal and marine species, the Galapagos have been listed as a UNESCO heritage site and was the inspiration for Darwin’s theory of evolution. The islands are home to 20 endemic reptiles and the famous Giant Tortoise. The marine biodiversity is equally rich with 20% of species endemic to the region. The bioregion is dominated by one ecoregion – Galápagos Islands Xeric Scrub (601) – but this belies the diversity of plant life present here, with over 500 native plant species, 180 of which are endemic. The land area of this bioregion is approximately 800,000 hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the Galápagos Islands ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Galápagos Islands Xeric Scrub
ecoregions.dek: The Galápagos Islands Xeric Scrub ecoregion encompasses the entire Galápagos archipelago, including about 128 named islands.

children.name: Chilean Mixed Forests (NT1)
children.content:
Comprising the western half of Patagonia at the bottom of South America and located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, the Chilean bioregion is defined by a myriad of waterways intertwined with coastal rainforests and includes Chile’s Lake District and several large glaciers at the southernmost extent of the Andes Mountains. The bioregion contains two ecoregions – Magellanic Subpolar Forests (561), Valdivian Temperate Forests (563) – and includes Tierra del Fuego and adjacent marine areas in both the southern Pacific and Atlantic oceans. The total land area of this bioregion is more than 41 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Chilean Mixed Forest ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Valdivian Temperate Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Valdivian Temperate Forests ecoregion is in the southern cone of South America.

ecoregions.title: Magellanic Subpolar Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Magellanic Subpolar Forests cover the flanks of the southern Andes and adjacent lowlands of South America.

children.name: Chaco Grasslands (NT4)
children.content:
The Chaco bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, covers much of Paraguay and northern Argentina.
