The name of this region is derived from the indigenous Quechua word chaqu which means “hunting land,” due to the rich variety of wildlife that was once abundant in these subtropical grasslands and shrublands. The bioregion contains two ecoregions – Dry Chaco (569), Humid Chaco (571) – incorporating several large salt flats in the south. The land area of this bioregion is more than 108 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Chaco Grasslands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Dry Chaco
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is generally restricted to the northwestern two-thirds of western Paraguay, and east of the Andes in southeastern Bolivia and northwestern Argentina

ecoregions.title: Humid Chaco
ecoregions.dek: The Humid Chaco ecoregion is located in northeastern Argentina, the center of Paraguay, and small areas in southwestern Brazil.

children.name: Rio de la Plata Grasslands (NT3)
children.content:
The Rio de la Plata bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, extends from the Espinal drylands east of the Andes Mountains to the Atlantic Ocean, encompassing Argentina’s humid pampas grasses and the flooded savannas formed by the Paraná River and its tributaries. This bioregion also includes Uruguay’s subtropical savanna, which forms the Northern border of the Río de la Plata estuary, containing five ecoregions in total – Uruguayan Savanna (574), Espinal (575), Humid Pampas (576), Paraná Flooded Savanna (585), Southern Cone Mesopotamian Savanna (586) – as well as adjacent marine areas in the Atlantic Ocean. The total land area of this bioregion is more than 111 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Rio de la Plata Grasslands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Southern Cone Mesopotamian Savanna
ecoregions.dek: The Southern Cone Mesopotamian savanna ecoregion is grassland-wetland mosaic covering the region of Argentine “Mesopotamia."

ecoregions.title: Paraná Flooded Savanna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes the floodplains of the middle and lower Paraná River and its tributary, the Paraguay River.

ecoregions.title: Humid Pampas
ecoregions.dek: The Humid Pampas occupy the plains in the east of Argentina, taking up most of the province of Buenos Aires.

ecoregions.title: Espinal
ecoregions.dek: The Espinal ecoregion is in central Argentina extending from central Santa Fe through the province of Córdoba to the north of San Luis.

ecoregions.title: Uruguayan Savanna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends from the extreme southern part of the Rio Grande do Sul, a Brazilian state, to include the entire country of Uruguay, and a small section of the Argentinean province of Entre Ríos.

children.name: Patagonia Steppe & Low Mountains (NT2)
children.content:
The Patagonia Steppe bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, incorporates most of the temperate grassland biome of South America, between the Andes Mountains to the west and the Espinal drylands to the east. The bioregion contains two ecoregions – Low Monte (577), Patagonian Steppe (578) – and includes the Islas Malvinas (Falkland Islands) and adjacent marine areas in the southern Atlantic Ocean. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 93 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Patagonia Steppe & Low Mountains ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Patagonian Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion mainly covers the Patagonia region of Argentina from the Atlantic Ocean shore and extends into southwestern Chile.

ecoregions.title: Low Monte
ecoregions.dek: The Low Monte is in north-central Argentina, extending along the eastern foothills of the Andes until reaching the Patagonian steppe, then extends eastwards to the Pacific Ocean.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/1cf0665a-35ba-4c32-a17d-a070dcdbb2a0/577- Monte y de las Sierras-Argentina-Eco 577-CC-Christian Ostrosky-2009.jpg

children.name: Brazilian Atlantic Dry Forests (NT15)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a2e4f861-d421-48a2-b8ef-f4434b815568/445 Caatinga Enclaves moist forests - Rapper Ouriço.jpg

children.content:
The Brazilian Atlantic Dry Forests bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, incorporates Brazil’s southeastern cape and adjacent marine areas. With it’s hot and dry climate, it is defined by a mosaic of shrublands, cacti, and thorny woodlands containing four distinct ecoregions – Caatinga Enclaves Moist Forests (445), Brazilian Atlantic Dry Forests (524), Caatinga (525), Maranhão Babaçu Forests (540). The marine biodiversity of the bioregion is rich, with 57% of the fish species endemic to the area. The total land area of this bioregion is 100 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Brazilian Atlantic Dry Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Maranhão Babaçu Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is located in eastern Brazil at the very eastern and southern flank of the Amazon Basin.

ecoregions.title: Caatinga
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is the largest dry forest region in South America and one of the richest dry forests in the world.

ecoregions.title: Brazilian Atlantic Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This forest-dominated ecoregion is surrounded by open vegetation of Caatinga in the north and east and Cerrado in the west and south.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/628bc617-95ca-4035-ac23-bcce4231c7b9/524 Brazilian Atlantic dry forests - Diego Rego Monteiro.JPG

ecoregions.title: Caatinga Enclaves Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion consists of five established patches of Atlantic forest that are surrounded by a variety of dry Caatinga vegetation in northeast Brazil.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a2e4f861-d421-48a2-b8ef-f4434b815568/445 Caatinga Enclaves moist forests - Rapper Ouriço.jpg

children.name: Cerrado Savannas (NT13)
children.content:
The Cerrado bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, covers more than one-fifth of Brazil’s total land area and consists of two ecoregions –  Campos Rupestres Montane Savanna (566) Cerrado (567) – with gallery forests running along the streams and rivers. The bioregion is considered to be one of the richest tropical savannas in the world, containing 10,000 plant species, 200 mammal species, and 10 endemic bird species. The total area of this bioregion is 194 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the Cerrado Savannas ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Cerrado
ecoregions.dek: Cerrado is the largest savanna region in South America and biologically the richest savanna in all the world.

ecoregions.title: Campos Rupestres Montane Savanna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is part of the Espinhaço Mountain Range in Brazil, an ancient plateau formed by pre-Cambrian crystalline rocks that extend from the North Bahia southward to Serra do Ouro Branco.

children.name: Pantanal Flooded Grasslands & Dry Forests (NT12)
children.content:
The Pantanal bioregion, located in the Brazil Cerrado & Atlantic Coast subrealm, lies just below the Amazon Basin, straddling the border between Brazil and Bolivia. It consists of two intertwined ecoregions—Chiquitano Dry Forests (529), Pantanal (584)—fed by the Paraguay River and hundreds of small lakes. It contains both the world’s largest tropical wetland and largest flooded grasslands, as well as fry tropical forests. A UNESCO heritage site, this bioregion has the highest concentration of bird, fish, and vertebrate wildlife on the continent and is home to the world’s largest jaguars. Its land area is approximately 40 million hectares.

Learn more about each of the Pantanal Flooded Grasslands & Dry Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Pantanal
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is located roughly in the center of South America, near the borders of Brazil, Bolivia, and Paraguay.

ecoregions.title: Chiquitano Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: Most of the Chiquitano forest lies within the eastern lowlands of Santa Cruz, Bolivia, with smaller patches extending into western Mato Grosso, Brazil.

children.name: Brazilian Atlantic Moist Forests (NT14)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/61171014-0469-4352-89fa-bf0fa98893ea/442 Bahia Coastal Forests Daniele Longui Creative Commons.jpg

children.content:
The Brazilian Atlantic Moist Forests (Mata Atlântica) bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, spans nearly the entire length of Brazil’s eastern coast and consists almost entirely of tropical broadleaf forests, which extend into the heart of the Cerrado. The bioregion includes 12 ecoregions – Alto Paraná Atlantic Forests (439), Araucaria Moist Forests (440), Atlantic Coast Restingas (441), Bahia Coastal Forests (442), Bahia Interior Forests (443), Fernando De Noronha-Atol Das Rocas Moist Forests (462), Pernambuco Coastal Forests (491), Pernambuco Interior Forests (492), Serra Do Mar Coastal Forests (500), Trindade-Martin Vaz Islands Tropical Forests (509), St. Peter and St. Paul Rocks (609), Southern Atlantic Brazilian Mangroves (616). The bioregion is home to hundreds of rare and endemic species of plants and animals, and one study found that the remaining forest harbors 20,000 species of plants, with almost 450 tree species found in a single hectare. Its total land area is approximately 123 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Brazilian Atlantic Moist Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Southern Atlantic Brazilian Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The Southern Atlantic Brazilian Mangroves ecoregion comprises four subecoregions.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/0f5d95c6-209e-4b26-a8da-f4eb7ef170ab/616 Southern Atlantic Brazilian mangroves - Brigitte Werner.jpg

ecoregions.title: St. Peter and St. Paul Rocks
ecoregions.dek: More than 800 km from South America, St. Peter and St. Paul’s Rocks are a small group of islands in the equatorial Atlantic Ocean.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/4080c7e7-43ba-4260-bd8d-e03cac346ba9/609 St. Peter and St. Paul Rocks - John Vergari.jpg

ecoregions.title: Trindade-Martin Vaz Islands Tropical Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Trindade and Martin Vaz Archipelago is the most eastward point of Brazilian territory and is a result of volcanic activity deep below the Atlantic Ocean.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/64b36e8e-f597-492a-a0a0-278e4ebe20fa/509 Trindade-Martin Vaz Islands tropical forests - Simone Marinho.jpg

ecoregions.title: Serra Do Mar Coastal Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Serra do Mar coastal forests cover a 100-km wide strip along the Atlantic Coast of Southern Brazil.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5bc774bf-b00f-4dc1-8834-0fac103daac6/500 Serra do Mar coastal forests - Bruno Urso.jpg

ecoregions.title: Pernambuco Interior Forests
ecoregions.dek: Pernambuco Interior Forest is located in a narrow strip, approximately 50 km wide, between the ecoregions of Pernambuco Coastal Forests and Caatinga, in northeastern Brazil.

ecoregions.title: Pernambuco Coastal Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Pernambuco Coastal Forests ecoregion is one of the most unique habitats in the Atlantic coast region of Brazil.

ecoregions.title: Fernando De Noronha-Atol Das Rocas Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The archipelago of Fernando de Noronha and its neighbor Atol das Rocas belong to the Fernando de Noronha Chain of submerged east-west volcanic mountains.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/4ca28bfe-14f0-4fc6-8205-1f0a34d14eac/462 Fernando de Noronha-Atol das Rocas moist forests - Tadeu Pereira.jpg

ecoregions.title: Bahía Interior Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers a large area, including the Brazilian states of Sergipe, Bahía, Minas Gerais, Espírito Santo, and Rio de Janeiro.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/be005002-1803-42da-b411-2fdb190c9a87/443 Bahia interior forests Fernando Marino cc.jpg

ecoregions.title: Bahia Coastal Forests
ecoregions.dek: Bahía Coastal Forests have been given highest priority for biodiversity conservation by local governments because they harbor an extraordinary number of endemic species of vascular plants, birds, primates, and butterflies.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/61171014-0469-4352-89fa-bf0fa98893ea/442 Bahia Coastal Forests Daniele Longui Creative Commons.jpg

ecoregions.title: Atlantic Coast Restingas
ecoregions.dek: Atlantic Coast Restingas consist of three well-defined areas of restinga forests distributed from northeastern to southeastern Brazil.

ecoregions.title: Araucaria Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is bordered on the north and west by the Alta Paraná Atlantic Forests, on the south by the pampas grasslands, and on the east by Serra do Mar Coastal Moist Forests.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/df3ac226-ecb7-4cc4-aebf-1be2e6d095bf/440- Araucaria forest in Aparados da Serra National Park-Eco440-CC-Valerio Pillar-2005.jpg

ecoregions.title: Alto Paraná Atlantic Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Alto Paraná Atlantic Forests represent a large block of Atlantic semi-deciduous forest spread from Southeast Brazil and Paraguay to northern Argentina.

ecoregions.title: Campos Rupestres Montane Savanna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is part of the Espinhaço Mountain Range in Brazil, an ancient plateau formed by pre-Cambrian crystalline rocks that extend from the North Bahia southward to Serra do Ouro Branco.

children.name: Northern Amazonian Forests (NT20)
children.content:
The Northern Amazonian bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, lies between the Amazon River and the Guiana Shield and includes the Rio Negro, the principle northern tributary of the Amazon. The bioregion consists entirely of moist tropical forests, containing five ecoregions – Gurupa Várzea (467), Japurá-Solimões-Negro Moist Forests (473), Negro-Branco Moist Forests (484), Rio Negro Campinarana (498), Uatumã-Trombetas Moist Forests (511) — as well as the largest biological reserve in Brazil. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 105 million hectares.

Learn more about each of the Northern Amazonian Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Uatumã-Trombetas Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Uatumã-Trombetas moist forests comprise the vast region north of the Amazon River in the eastern portion of Brazil, extending almost to the Atlantic coast and upwards to Guyana and Suriname.

ecoregions.title: Rio Negro Campinarana
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occur as isolated patches “sand forest” along the Rio Negro and Rio Branco basins in Venezuela and northern Brazil.

ecoregions.title: Negro-Branco Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Rivers in the countries of Colombia, Venezuela, and Brazil bind the Negro-Blanco Moist Forests ecoregion.

ecoregions.title: Japurá-Solimões-Negro Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is situated on the lowland plateau in the central northern portion of the Amazon Basin in Brazil with tiny sections touching Colombia and Venezuela.

ecoregions.title: Gurupa Várzea
ecoregions.dek: The Gurupa várzea ecoregion is named for the large alluvial island, Ilha Grande de Gurupá, occurring in the mouth of the Amazon River.

children.name: Western Amazonian Forests & Plains (NT18)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/032625ba-f428-4372-8d07-08f69bc3d961/512-Cordillera_Azul_National_Park_-_ZooKeys-Eco512-CC-Venegas P, Torres-Carvajal O, Duran V, Queiroz K-2013.jpg

children.content:
The Western Amazonian bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, stretches north from Bolivia to the Amazon river in Peru, contained by the Andes Mountains to the west. It consists mostly of moist and seasonally flooded tropical forests, but also incorporates savanna to the south that is encircled by forest. The bioregion contains four ecoregions – Iquitos Várzea (469), Southwest Amazon Moist Forests (505), Ucayali Moist Forests (512), Beni Savanna (565) – and includes the western mainstem of the Amazon River, the Ucayali River, and several lakes in the South. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 111 million hectares.

Explore the Western Amazonian Forests & Plains ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Beni Savanna
ecoregions.dek: The Beni Savannas are the 3rd largest complex of savannas in South America.

ecoregions.title: Ucayali Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is located entirely within Peru at the foot of the Andes mountains and includes the basin west of the Ucayali river, a major branch of the Amazon river.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/3b51f4b3-74e0-4922-9bd7-65ca4057fe47/512 Ucayali moist forests - Tadd _ Debbie Ottman.jpg

ecoregions.title: Southwest Amazon Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Southwest Amazon moist forest region covers an extensive area of the Upper Amazon Basin comprising four sub-basins.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/01d26ffd-e97e-4c16-aaed-6d2ecca9c6d6/505 Southwest Amazon moist forests - Gleilson Miranda _ State of Acre.jpg

ecoregions.title: Iquitos Várzea
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion  comprises the low and upper Amazon, Ucayali, Marañon, Madre de Dios in Peru and Bolivia, and several smaller tributaries to the Amazon in Peru, and the upper Juruá and Purus Rivers in Brazil.

children.name: Southern Amazonian Forests (NT17)
children.content:
The Southern Amazonian bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, stretches from the Marajó Archipelago to Bolivia, south of the Amazon river. It consists almost entirely of highly diverse, tropical moist forest and incorporates the drier forests bordering the Cerrado. The bioregion contains four ecoregions – Madeira-Tapajós Moist Forests (476), Mato Grosso Tropical Dry Forests (481), Tapajós-Xingu Moist Forests (507), Xingu-Tocantins-Araguaia Moist Forests (518) – and includes many major and minor tributaries of the Amazon River. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 174 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Southern Amazonian Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Xingu-Tocantins-Araguaia Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Located primarily between the Xingu and Lower Tocantins Rivers in Brazil, this ecoregion also includes the area around the Araguaia River.

ecoregions.title: Tapajós-Xingu Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies in central-eastern Brazil south of the Amazon River, comprising the interfluvial plain between the Tapajós and Xingu Rivers, both major tributaries to the Amazon River.

ecoregions.title: Mato Grosso Tropical Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Mato Grosso Tropical Dry Forests are in the Mato Grosso and Para provinces of central Brazil.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/e914ee43-7375-4f14-8971-f1c275a7d9e5/481 Mato Grosso tropical dry forests - Fotografiaampl.jpg

ecoregions.title: Madeira-Tapajós Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The ecoregion lies in central Amazonia, including a considerable expanse of land area between the Madeira and Tapajós Rivers (both major tributaries to the Amazon).

children.name: Amazon River Estuary (NT16)
children.content:
The Amazon River Estuary Bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, includes a huge river delta formed at the end of the Amazon River’s 4000-mile journey to the sea in northern Brazil, where it meets up with the Tocantins River, encompassing the Marajó Archipelago. It is the easternmost Amazonian bioregion consisting predominantly of tropical forest surrounding the delta and incorporates a narrow band of beach forests extending to the east with four ecoregions – Marajó Várzea (480), Tocantins/Pindare Moist Forests (508), Northeast Brazil Restingas (485), Amazon-Orinoco-Southern Caribbean Mangroves (611). The total area of this bioregion is more than 31 million hectares, not including adjacent marine areas.

Learn more about each of the Amazon River Estuary ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Northeast Brazil Restingas
ecoregions.dek: The Northeastern Brazil Restingas extend approximately 400 km along a disjunct coastal strip, through the northern portions of the Brazilian states of Maranhão, Piauí, and Ceará.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b3a887d3-a18b-40a7-b581-14f5deebe2dc/485 Northeast Brazil restingas - Mayra Pavanello Munerato.jpg

ecoregions.title: Amazon-Orinoco-Southern Caribbean Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The Amazon-Orinoco-Southern Caribbean Mangrove ecoregion is comprised of seven subecoregions.

ecoregions.title: Tocantins/Pindare Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: In the Brazilian State of Pará, the ecoregion extends west to the Tocantins River and south to the Mearim River in Maranhão State.

ecoregions.title: Marajó Várzea
ecoregions.dek: This várzea ecoregion comprises the entire Marajó Island, many smaller channel islands, and the surrounding mainland on both the northern and southern banks of the Amazon.

children.name: Central Amazonian Forests (NT19)
children.content:
The Central Amazonian forests bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, contains the central mainstem of the Amazon River and includes three major tributaries—the Japurá in the north and the Madeira and Purus in the south—forming what some call the “heart” of the Amazon. This bioregion is divided into eastern and western halves with seven ecoregions—Caqueta Moist Forests (446), Juruá-Purus Moist Forests (474), Monte Alegre Várzea (482), Napo Moist Forests (483), Purus Varzea (496), Purus-Madeira Moist Forests (497), Solimões-Japurá Moist Forests (503)—unified by the seasonally flooded forests that line its rivers and streams, extending to the foot of the Andes Mountains in the north. It also includes many lakes formed at the junction of the Amazon River and its major tributaries. The total area of this bioregion is nearly 127 million hectares.

Learn more about each of the Central Amazonian Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Solimões-Japurá Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies on well-drained upland tertiary alluvial plains in western Amazonia.

ecoregions.title: Purus-Madeira Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Purus-Madeira Moist Forest ecoregion lies in the center of the Brazilian Amazon, between the Purus and Madeira Rivers.

ecoregions.title: Purus Várzea
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion in Brazil comprises portions of the low, seasonally flooded river basins of the central Amazon.

ecoregions.title: Napo Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Rio Napo ecoregion covers the north-western portion of Peru, the Amazon region of Ecuador, and the southwestern corner of Colombia’s Amazon.

ecoregions.title: Monte Alegre Várzea
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion in Brazil comprises portions of the low, seasonally flooded river basins of the central and lower Amazon.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/65e1bc0c-45a6-4247-99c3-332c61ffdfd6/482 Monte Alegre várzea - Neil Palmer CIAT.jpg

ecoregions.title: Juruá-Purus Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Juruá-Purus Moist Forests ecoregion covers the valleys between the westernmost Amazon River to the Purus River.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a1039651-0be2-42b3-9894-51ce147cc87c/474 Juruá-Purus moist forests - Wilson Dias Agencia Brasil.jpg

ecoregions.title: Caqueta Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Caquetá Moist Forest occurs in the Colombian Amazon. It is bound on the northeast by the Guainía, Guaviare, and Guayabero Rivers and on the western extreme by the small Rio Losada, south of the Serranía de la Macarena.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f21b59de-93fb-471f-8769-56830b46b107/446 Caqueta moist forests - Carlos Castaño Uribe.jpg

children.name: Venezuelan Coast (NT23)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/c9cccb8f-0e6c-4a81-bab7-8f214b0ff914/447-Parque Nacional Ciénagas del Catatumbo-Eco 447-Juan Pablo Bottaro-2014.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f99507e7-880c-456e-9b71-92dd44b8d613/536 Lara-Falcón Dry Forests Juan Carlo Castillo Ortega.jpeg

children.content:
The Venezuelan Coast bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, runs the length of South America’s Caribbean coastline. It is largely dominated by dry coastal scrublands interspersed with pockets of moist tropical forest, as well as dry tropical forest and the ice-capped Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta plateau, which many indigenous tribes believe to be the “beating heart” of the continent. The bioregion contains 11 terrestrial ecoregions – Catatumbo Moist Forests (447), Cordillera de la Costa Montane Forests (456), Santa Marta Montane Forests (499), Lara-Falcón Dry Forests (536), Maracaibo Dry Forests (539), Sinú Valley Dry Forests (546), Santa Marta Páramo (594), Araya and Paria Xeric Scrub (597), Guajira-Barranquilla Xeric Scrub (602), La Costa Xeric Shrublands (603), Paraguana Xeric Scrub (606) – as well as Amazon-Orinoco-Southern Caribbean Mangroves (611). The total area of this bioregion is nearly 24 million hectares, not including adjacent marine areas.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Venezuelan Coast ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Paraguana Xeric Scrub
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies within two of the four existing physiographic provinces, which are characterized by distinct geography and landscape features, in the northwest region of Venezuela.

ecoregions.title: La Costa Xeric Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: The La Costa Xeric Shrublands are part of the Coastal Cordillera geographical region in northern Venezuela.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b38765f0-c378-4ca2-bc19-3ba8a36f3273/603 La Costa xeric shrublands - Kate Stevenson and Daniel Poulter_resized.jpg

ecoregions.title: Guajira-Barranquilla Xeric Scrub
ecoregions.dek: The Guajira-Barranquilla Xeric Scrub is found within three enclaves in parts of Venezuela and Colombia along the Caribbean Sea.

ecoregions.title: Araya and Paria Xeric Scrub
ecoregions.dek: The ecoregion extends through portions of Margarita Island, the Araya-Paria peninsula, and onto the mainland of Cumaná in Venezuela.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/dc761dc3-bbb8-4153-bbf8-356d6a314b32/597 Araya and Paria xeric scrub - JP Ferrer Paris.jpg

ecoregions.title: Santa Marta Páramo
ecoregions.dek: The Santa Marta páramos are the northernmost occurrence of this habitat type in South America.

ecoregions.title: Sinú Valley Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is situated at the northwestern extreme of the Andes, near the Darien-Panama bridge and between two major ecoregions—Chocó Wet Forests and Magdalena Medio Rain Forests.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/57bbb5d5-63e8-42d4-b120-edff2fb49ccd/Sinú Valley Dry Forests. Courtesy of David Tryse 3.jpg

ecoregions.title: Maracaibo Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Maracaibo Dry Forests are located in the northwestern coastal area of Venezuela.

ecoregions.title: Lara-Falcón Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Lara-Falcón Dry Forests lie in northern Venezuela, south of the Paraguana Peninsula, east of the Gulf of Maracaibo, and north of the Andes.

ecoregions.title: Santa Marta Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Santa Marta Montane Forest ecoregion lies in northern Colombia in the extreme northwest of South America.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a982438b-e18a-430c-b6f4-5026ed9eebba/499-Primary forest in Sierra Nevada da Santa Marta-Eco499-CC-Daisy Tarrier-2011.JPG

ecoregions.title: Cordillera de la Costa Montane Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Cordillera de la Costa Montane Forests ecoregion extends 720 km from east to west along the northern coast of Venezuela.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b626e201-da76-4e61-ada3-f367fbeda83f/456 Cordillera La Costa montane forests - Cristobal Alvarado Minic.jpg

ecoregions.title: Catatumbo Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: These Forests exist as four distinct regions within the Catatumbo Valley, and are comprised of isolated mountain, lowlands, Andean foothills, and valleys.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/fcae3668-acc4-4aeb-98d5-dbb359738516/447 Catatumbo moist forests - Parque Nacional Natural Catatumbo Barí.jpg

ecoregions.title: Amazon-Orinoco-Southern Caribbean Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The Amazon-Orinoco-Southern Caribbean Mangrove ecoregion is comprised of seven subecoregions.

children.name: Llanos & Dry Forests (NT22)
children.content:
The Llanos bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, extends from the northern Andes above the Guiana Shield. It consists almost entirely of open, grassy plains called (llanos) with dry tropical forests at the foothills of the Andes. It has two ecoregions – Apure-Villavicencio Dry Forests (520), Llanos (572) – and includes much of the Orinoco and Apure rivers. The total area of this bioregion is nearly 45 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Llanos & Dry Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Llanos
ecoregions.dek: The Llanos ecoregion is an area of extensive plains, covered mainly by savanna vegetation, and of great economic importance for Venezuela and Colombia.

ecoregions.title: Apure-Villavicencio Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Apure-Villavicencio Dry Forests border the eastern Cordillera de Mérida from Venezuela to the Serranía de Macarena in Colombia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/68c2e750-3e99-4524-8e22-fd2965708962/520 Apure-Villavicencio dry forests - Jerzy Andrzej Kucia.jpg

children.name: Guianan Forests & Savanna (NT21)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/9d401fb1-9d7b-4f5c-8210-3cb01d5e608c/465 Guianan lowland moist forests - Rhett Butler.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/73e36c74-b2ce-407b-a506-9c7860c54eb2/570- Kukenan and Roraima tepuis-Gran Sabana-Venezuela-Eco 570-CC-Paolo Cosat Baldi-2010.JPG

children.content:
The Guianan bioregion, located in the Southern America (Neotropical) realm, extends from the eastern edge of the Guiana shield, at the border of Venezuela and Colombia, to the Atlantic coast. It contains the Guiana Highlands with its rocky plateaus that are the source for many waterfalls including the world’s highest, Angel Falls. The bioregion is covered in dense tropical forest and also includes the Guinan savannas, with nine terrestrial ecoregions – Guianan Freshwater Swamp Forests (463), Guianan Highlands Moist Forests (464), Guianan Lowland Moist Forests (465), Guianan Piedmont Moist Forests (466), Orinoco Delta Swamp Forests (488), Pantepui Forests and Shrublands (490), Trinidad and Tobago Moist Forest (510), Trinidad and Tobago Dry Forests (548), Guianan Savanna (570) – as well as significant stands of Amazon-Orinoco-Southern Caribbean Mangroves (611) and Orinoco Wetlands (583). This bioregion is considered one of the most biodiverse in the world with 3000 vertebrate species and over 13,000 plant species, two-fifths of which are endemic. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 106 million hectares, not including adjacent marine areas.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Guianan Forests & Savanna ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Guianan Piedmont Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: A transitional ecoregion between the mountainous Pantepui forests and shrublands and Guianan highland moist forest and surrounding dry forests (Llanos) to the north and rain forests (Amazon Basin) to the south.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/17a15f15-128d-42bf-8ad2-629942ed3cf9/466 Guianan piedmont moist forests - D Olson_resized.jpg

ecoregions.title: Orinoco Wetlands
ecoregions.dek: The ecoregion is located to the north of the Orinoco River Delta, the second largest river in the Neotropics, in eastern Venezuela.

ecoregions.title: Guianan Savanna
ecoregions.dek: The Gran Sabana patch is recognized as an important plant refuge and dispersal center, with several reported endemic species.

ecoregions.title: Trinidad and Tobago Dry Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers a small portion of land in the northwest of Trinidad and the very northern end of Tobago.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/3ffb309a-8143-419b-9fae-bb151c7edbcd/548 Trinidad and Tobago dry forest - FB Lucas.JPG

ecoregions.title: Trinidad and Tobago Moist Forest
ecoregions.dek: This moist forest ecoregion comprises approximately 90% of the land area of the archipelagic state of Trinidad and Tobago.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/33e3eca3-3045-4588-92e0-a15fc51b95e9/510 Trinidad and Tobago moist forest - mconnors_resized.jpg

ecoregions.title: Pantepui Forests and Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: The landscape of Pantepui Forests & Shrublands ecoregion perforate an extensive matrix of highland savannas and rain forests across southern Venezuela, Guayana, Suriname, and Brazil.

ecoregions.title: Orinoco Delta Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occurs in a continuous expanse of flooded forests and wetlands, occurring from the southern reaches of the Paria Peninsula in northern Venezuela.

ecoregions.title: Guianan Lowland Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: This region is located on the northeastern coast of South America. The Amazon basin lies to the south and the Orinoco borders on the west.

ecoregions.title: Guianan Highlands Moist Forests
ecoregions.dek: Situated in southeastern Venezuela in northern South America, the Guayanan Highlands Most Forests ecoregion is an elevational "island" surrounded by llanos and lowland forest.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/653cfd91-38d3-4e15-9fec-4a9d3174d4ef/464 Guianan Highlands moist forests - Paolo Costa Baldi.jpg

ecoregions.title: Guianan Freshwater Swamp Forests
ecoregions.dek: This Swamp Forests ecoregion extends as a narrow, near-coastal strip across all of northern Suriname, from the Courantyne River along the Guyanan border to the Maroni River along the French Guianan border.

ecoregions.title: Amazon-Orinoco-Southern Caribbean Mangroves
ecoregions.dek: The Amazon-Orinoco-Southern Caribbean Mangrove ecoregion is comprised of seven subecoregions.

children.name: Northern Sahara Deserts, Savannas & Marshes (PA24)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/d600d176-7180-40be-99ca-2aaee867b9ad/787- forests to the top of the Caldera de Taburiente-CC-Tony Hisgett-2011_resized.jpg

children.content:
The Northern Sahara Deserts, Savannas & Marshes bioregion is located in the North Africa subrealm and contains six terrestrial ecoregions—Nile Delta Flooded Savanna (744), Canary Islands Dry Woodlands and Forests (787), East Sahara Desert (822), North Saharan Xeric Steppe and Woodland (833), Saharan Atlantic Coastal Desert (839), West Sahara Desert (845)—along with the Saharan Halophytics (745) totaling over 404 million hectares of land area.

Learn more about each of the Northern Sahara Deserts, Savannas & Marshes ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: West Sahara Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is a largely barren landscape, speckled sparingly with oases and transient green spaces which only appear after rare rainfall.

ecoregions.title: Saharan Atlantic Coastal Desert
ecoregions.dek: A vibrant marine ecosystem is juxtaposed with arid desert plateaus in this spectacular stretch of coastline between Western Sahara and Mauritania that forms this ecoregion.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5034a658-ef19-4acd-912f-183d98aac855/839 Saharan Atlantic coastal desert - JC Brito.jpg

ecoregions.title: North Saharan Xeric Steppe and Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends right across North Africa, including parts of Western Sahara, Morocco, the northern edge of Mauritania, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya, and Egypt.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/edbfa3c6-de62-466a-ac5f-1a33c2cae47a/833 North Saharan Xeric Steppe and Woodland - JC Brito_resized.jpg

ecoregions.title: East Sahara Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the central Sahara Desert.

ecoregions.title: Canary Islands Dry Woodlands and Forests
ecoregions.dek: The Canary Archipelago is a group of volcanic islands and rock islets located in the Atlantic Ocean, 115 km from the northwest coast of Africa.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/0481dda9-76e3-493a-8731-14b541c95129/787 Canary Islands dry woodlands and forests - nike159.jpg

ecoregions.title: Saharan Halophytic
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion cover a number of saline depressions scattered across northern Africa.

ecoregions.title: Nile Delta Flooded Savanna
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends along the Nile River from the Aswan High Dam 1,100 km downstream to the mouth of the Nile, and includes the delta in the North, which is about 175 km long and 260 km wide, opening to the Mediterranean sea.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/63ad79a2-2e62-4b57-a139-7ed9e6d4fbfa/744 Banana plantation on the Nile Delta-CC-2014_resized.jpg

children.name: Southern Sahara Deserts & Mountain Woodlands (PA25)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b815d7b7-9537-45ed-9fe1-0c0f863ed1a0/842 South Sahara Desert Luca Galuzzi cc.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/173c56f7-f274-40fb-a4d2-ffd465b34aa3/823 East Saharan montane xeric woodlands - Desertman.jpg

children.content:
The Southern Sahara Deserts & Mountain Woodlands bioregion is located in the Southern Eurasia realm (southern Palearctic) and contains four ecoregions –  East Saharan Montane Xeric Woodlands (823), South Sahara Desert (842), Tibesti-Jebel Uweinat Montane Xeric Woodlands (844), West Saharan Montane Xeric Woodlands (846) – totaling approximately 329 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Southern Sahara Deserts & Mountain Woodlands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: West Saharan Montane Xeric Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: Mountain ranges such as Ahaggar, Tibesti, and Aïr rise up around the West Sahara Desert, notably in the south.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/3a58f4f3-8f49-4efd-8ed8-f2b09cffb74a/846 West Saharan montane xeric woodlands - Jacqueline Macou.jpg

ecoregions.title: Tibesti-Jebel Uweinat Montane Xeric Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses two mountainous areas rising from the central Sahara Desert: Tibesti and the smaller Jebel Uweinat region.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/d5defaa1-2140-4927-b5b6-65d76674c8a1/844 Tibesti-Jebel Uweinat montane xeric woodlands - Michael Kerling.jpg

ecoregions.title: South Sahara Desert
ecoregions.dek: The South Sahara Desert ecoregion crosses the African continent from the southern corner of Western Sahara and the northern half of Mauritania, to the northern part of Mali, southern Algeria, northern Niger, Chad, Sudan, and southeastern Egypt.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b815d7b7-9537-45ed-9fe1-0c0f863ed1a0/842 South Sahara Desert Luca Galuzzi cc.jpg

ecoregions.title: East Saharan Montane Xeric Woodlands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is restricted to three specific locations: the Massif de l’Ennedi and Massif du Kapka in northeastern Chad and the nearby Jebel Marra in western Sudan

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/173c56f7-f274-40fb-a4d2-ffd465b34aa3/823 East Saharan montane xeric woodlands - Desertman.jpg

children.name: South Mediterranean Mixed Woodlands & Forests (PA23)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2f751cef-b434-4457-af46-3050f584526a/701 Mediterranean conifer and mixed forests - JC Brito.jpg

children.content:
The South Mediterranean Mixed Woodlands & Forests bioregion is located in the Southern Eurasia realm (southern Palearctic) and contains five ecoregions – Mediterranean Conifer and Mixed Forests (701), Mediterranean High Atlas Juniper Steppe (758), Mediterranean Acacia-Argania Dry Woodlands and Succulent Thickets (796), Mediterranean Dry Woodlands and Steppe (797), Mediterranean Woodlands and Forests (798) – totaling approximately 78 million hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the South Mediterranean Mixed Woodlands & Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Mediterranean Woodlands and Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the coastal plains, lowlands, and mid-elevations of northern Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia plus an isolated portion on the Cyrenaic Peninsular of Libya (Jabel al Akdar).

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/79fa05d8-6d02-4ac4-84b3-e6e214c5370c/798 Mediterranean woodlands and forests - JC Brito.jpg

ecoregions.title: Mediterranean Dry Woodlands and Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches from eastern Morocco, across northern Algeria to the Mediterranean coast of Tunisia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/860580a0-752e-464f-afd1-b6dddbdb73f5/797 Mediterranean dry woodlands and steppe - El Golli Mohamed.jpg

ecoregions.title: Mediterranean Acacia-Argania Dry Woodlands and Succulent Thickets
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion mainly sits within Morocco and the two easternmost Canary Islands.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5301b205-ab0d-4435-9106-0d62faa6f964/796 Mediterranean Acacia-Argania dry woodlands and succulent thickets - JC Brito_resized.jpg

ecoregions.title: Mediterranean High Atlas Juniper Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is limited to areas of the High Atlas Mountains in Morocco above an altitude of 1,628 m.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/72d4a0a6-fa89-4a26-b2a9-5584e04d1959/758 Mediterranean High Atlas juniper steppe - Wilfried Santer.jpg

ecoregions.title: Mediterranean Conifer and Mixed Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion comprises relict stands of fir and pine forest in the humid, medium to high elevations of major mountain massifs in North Africa, and in the southernmost mountains of Cádiz and Málaga in Spain.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2f751cef-b434-4457-af46-3050f584526a/701 Mediterranean conifer and mixed forests - JC Brito.jpg

children.name: Madeira Evergreen Island (PA22)
children.content:
The Madeira Evergreen Island bioregion is located in the Southern Eurasia realm (southern Palearctic) and contains one single ecoregion – Madeira Evergreen Forests (668) – totaling approximately 82 thousand hectares of land area.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Southern Eurasia. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about the Madeira Evergreen Island ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Madeira Evergreen Forests
ecoregions.dek: Madeira is an archipelago of four islands in the Atlantic Ocean, about 560 km west of Morocco and 978 km southwest of Lisbon.

children.name: Red Sea, Arabian Deserts & Salt Marshes (PA26)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/32b01d76-229c-4c8b-b107-c7392e42004a/Sandstone plateau, Hisma Desert – NEOM, Saudi Arabia | The NEOM Nature Reserve region neom-Iogsh4Cbdjs-unsplash.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/fe3bab11-d9c9-4f9c-b0d0-a9650269cec1/840 South Arabian plains and plateau desert - Eckhard Pecher.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5913bcc4-de53-4861-9525-5fc1fd8d45ff/821 East Arabian fog shrublands and sand desert - Andries Oudshoorn.jpg

children.content:
The Red Sea, Arabian Deserts & Salt Marshes bioregion is part of the Greater Arabian Peninsula subrealm located in the Southern Eurasia realm (southern Palearctic). It contains 15 ecoregions—Al-Hajar Foothill Xeric Woodlands and Shrublands (722), Al-Hajar Montane Woodlands and Shrublands (723), Syrian Xeric Grasslands and Shrublands (739), Tigris-Euphrates Alluvial Salt Marsh (747), Arabian Desert (809), Arabian Sand Desert (810), Arabian-Persian Gulf Coastal Plain Desert (811), East Arabian Fog Shrublands and Sand Desert (821), Mesopotamian Shrub Desert (830), North Arabian Desert (831), North Arabian Highland Shrublands (832), Red Sea Coastal Desert (836), Red Sea-Arabian Desert Shrublands (837) South Arabian Plains and Plateau Desert (840), Red Sea Mangroves (115)—totaling approximately 333 million hectares of land area.

Learn more about each of the Red Sea, Arabian Deserts & Salt Marshes ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: South Arabian Plains and Plateau Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion largely lies within Oman and Yemen, although it includes a small section in the United Arab Emirates in the East.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/fe3bab11-d9c9-4f9c-b0d0-a9650269cec1/840 South Arabian plains and plateau desert - Eckhard Pecher.jpg

ecoregions.title: Red Sea-Arabian Desert Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses a great diversity of habitats, stretching from southwest Yemen to just north of the Dead Sea in Jordan with sections of Saudi Arabia, Israel, Palestine, and Egypt.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/84b9c2f7-fe24-4299-a5f6-c088680d386a/837 Red Sea-Arabian Desert shrublands - ZSL KKWRC.jpg

ecoregions.title: Red Sea Coastal Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion extends south from the Gulf of Suez, encompassing most of Egypt’s Red Sea coast and approximately half of Sudan’s coastline.

ecoregions.title: North Arabian Highland Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: This discontinuous ecoregion is situated in Saudi Arabia’s western Ha’il region. It encompasses the Shammar mountain range and surrounding patches of lowland gravel desert.

ecoregions.title: North Arabian Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches across much of Jordan, northern Saudi Arabia and into Iraq’s western desert.

ecoregions.title: Mesopotamian Shrub Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses most of the Syrian Desert, also known as Badiyat ash Sham, stretching across East Jordan, southern Syria and western Iraq towards the foothills of the Zagros Mountains.

ecoregions.title: East Arabian Fog Shrublands and Sand Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion has a highly varied landscape, with two disjunct sections: the Wahiba Sands sand-sea in the North and the fossil-rich Huqf area in the South.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5913bcc4-de53-4861-9525-5fc1fd8d45ff/821 East Arabian fog shrublands and sand desert - Andries Oudshoorn.jpg

ecoregions.title: Arabian-Persian Gulf Coastal Plain Desert
ecoregions.dek: This disjointed ecoregion encompasses much of the Arabian Peninsula’s eastern coast, along the Arabian-Persian Gulf and Gulf of Oman, with a section in the Arabian Sea.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/77b02580-3f8a-4847-b57f-311fff9291a5/811 Arabian-Persian Gulf coastal plain desert - hotshoel.jpg

ecoregions.title: Arabian Sand Desert
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses both the major sand deserts—Ad-Dahna, An-Nafud, Al-Jafurah, Rub’ al-Khali—and sand deserts in Saudi Arabia, characterized by high linear and crescent dunes interspersed with gravel and gypsum plains.

ecoregions.title: Arabian Desert
ecoregions.dek: This disjointed ecoregion encompasses large swathes of Egypt’s Sinai Desert, Israel’s Negev Desert, and other areas in Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Kuwait, Iraq, and Iran.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/edbabbc5-b342-4169-a0e7-ca56b6675590/Sandstone plateau, Hisma Desert – NEOM, Saudi Arabia | The NEOM Nature Reserve region 2 neom-39n8YVSn0d4-unsplash.jpg

ecoregions.title: Tigris-Euphrates Alluvial Salt Marsh
ecoregions.dek: Located at the northern end of the Persian Gulf, these wetlands are formed in the deltaic plain of the Euphrates, Tigris, and Karun rivers, which drain Turkey, Syria, Iraq, and the western Zagros mountains of Iran.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/100b836e-2776-4b3a-95fb-912ffdd36781/747 Tigris-Euphrates alluvial salt marsh - Hassan Janali.jpg

ecoregions.title: Syrian Xeric Grasslands and Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion arcs across West Jordan, much of central Syrian Arab Republic, Northern Iraq, and a small area of Southwest Turkey.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b38929b7-21f7-4a39-84ad-6144e561705c/739 Syrian xeric grasslands and shrublands - thorgenmaehler.jpg

ecoregions.title: Al-Hajar Montane Woodlands and Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: Running parallel to Oman’s Batinah coast, the limestone and dark opholite rocks of the Al-Hajar mountains form the largest mountain range in eastern Arabia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/52d6ba96-9d32-4810-aefd-949812ad7e2c/723 Al-Hajar montane woodlands and shrublands - Glyn Barrett.jpg

ecoregions.title: Al-Hajar Foothill Xeric Woodlands and Shrublands
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion surrounds the Al-Hajar Montane Woodlands and Shrublands ecoregion, encompassing the Al-Hajar foothills and lands lying below 1,200 m.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/43a211f9-60e6-4de3-8baf-2552ab8af33f/722 Al-Hajar foothill xeric woodlands and shrublands - Glyn Barrett.jpg

children.name: Far Northern Pacific Coast (NA5)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/68b9c918-3a99-4a9f-87cc-93b394ba88b8/360 Northern Pacific Alaskan Coastal Forests Diego Delso cc.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/32c4d94c-51da-4db0-9f82-ab629fb7323b/360 Northern Pacific Alaskan Coastal Forests Paxson Woelber cc.jpeg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/31d5392a-f585-4e93-a0ed-1110e6f24353/420 Pacific Coastal Mountain Icefields and Tundra cc.jpg

children.content:
The Far Northern Pacific bioregion, located in the Subarctic America (Nearctic) realm, is defined by the coastal forests of the Gulf of Alaska and adjoining tundra south of the Alaska Range, all the way to the Dixon Entrance off the coast of central British Columbia. It consists of two ecoregions – Northern Pacific Alaskan Coastal Forests (360), Pacific Coastal Mountain Icefields and Tundra (420) – and adjacent marine areas. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 17 million hectares, not including icefield areas. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Subarctic America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Far Northern Pacific Coast ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Pacific Coastal Mountain Icefields and Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion parallels the Northern Pacific Alaskan Coastal Forests ecoregion, all the way from its southeastern extent in the Alaska Panhandle and adjacent British Columbia to its western terminus on the Kenai Peninsula along the Gulf of Alaska coast.

ecoregions.title: Northern Pacific Alaskan Coastal Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is one of the wildest and best-protected regions of North America outside of arctic tundra and northern taiga zones.

children.name: Greater Alaska Taiga & Tundra (NA4)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/14a5ed6a-ab2b-4bd0-9f6d-f8e05125cd00/416 Interior Alaska-Yukon Alpine Tundra Beeblebrox cc.jpg

children.content:
The Greater Alaska bioregion, located in the Subarctic America (Nearctic) realm, encompasses most of the Alaska subrealm and is divided in upper and lower halves by the Alaska Range. The upper half is dominated by lowland taiga and coastal tundra along the Bering Sea, consisting of four ecoregions – Interior Alaska-Yukon Lowland Taiga (375), Beringia Lowland Tundra (409), Beringia Upland Tundra (410) Interior Alaska-Yukon Alpine Tundra (416) – and adjacent marine areas. The lower half incorporates the alpine tundra of the Alaska Range, Cook Inlet, the Alaskan Peninsula, and the Aleutian Islands, which define the northernmost reach of the Pacific Ocean. It consists of six ecoregions – Alaska Peninsula Montane Taiga (369), Cook Inlet Taiga (371), Copper Plateau Taiga (372), Ahklun and Kilbuck Upland Tundra (404), Alaska-St. Elias Range Tundra (405), Aleutian Islands Tundra (406) – and adjacent marine areas. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 110 million hectares, not including icefield areas. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Subarctic America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Greater Alaska Taiga & Tundra ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Alaska-St. Elias Range Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion gets its name from the Alaska Range and the Wrangell-St. Elias Range, both of which it encompasses.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/5b0177d0-a7ff-4d05-a99f-4f0651fbe57b/405 Alaska-St. Elias Range tundra - NPS Alaska.jpg

ecoregions.title: Copper Plateau Taiga
ecoregions.dek: The Alaska-St. Elias Range Tundra ecosystem surrounds most of the Copper Plateau Taiga, except the Pacific Coastal Mountains Icefields and Tundra ecoregion forms the southern boundary of the Copper Plateau Taiga.

ecoregions.title: Cook Inlet Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion surrounds the upper portion of Cook Inlet and includes the city of Anchorage, with 291,538 residents (in 2018) the most populous city in Alaska.

ecoregions.title: Interior Alaska-Yukon Alpine Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion consists of a set of disjunct higher-elevation patches of tundra and open forest in a matrix of lowland taiga (the Interior Alaska-Yukon Lowland Taiga ecoregion) across the interior of Alaska, overlapping into southwestern Yukon Territory.

ecoregions.title: Beringia Upland Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occurs in two disjunct blocks: on the Seward Peninsula, where it is the dominant ecoregion, and a smaller area on the western half of St. Lawrence Island in the northern Bering Sea.

ecoregions.title: Beringia Lowland Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion consists of the southwestern Alaska mainland, separated by the higher-elevation Ahklun and Kilbuck Upland Tundra ecoregion and extending down the Alaska Peninsula to Unimak Island.

ecoregions.title: Aleutian Islands Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses the 1,500-km Aleutian chain, which stretches between the Alaska Peninsula and Kamchatka Peninsula in Russia, as well as the Pribilof Islands.

ecoregions.title: Ahklun and Kilbuck Upland Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion consists primarily of the Ahklun and Kilbuck mountain ranges in southwestern Alaska and was formerly considered part of the Beringia Upland Tundra ecoregion.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/9c058ed1-12b5-4a95-97e1-d764fe449993/404 Ahklun and Kilbuck upland tundra - John Morrison.jpg

ecoregions.title: Interior Alaska-Yukon Lowland Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion sprawls across a large area of southern to northern Alaska and neighboring northwestern Yukon Territory.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/bb60fd7e-3447-4d17-b010-e12cfef8d1ba/375 Interior Alaska-Yukon lowland taiga - John Morrison.jpg

ecoregions.title: Alaska Peninsula Montane Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is an area of rugged and picturesque coastline extending from the MacNeil River and the mouth of Cook Inlet in the northeast, down a relatively narrow peninsular to Unimak Island in the southwest, just off the tip of the peninsula.

children.name: North Alaskan Tundra (NA3)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/535f616f-66eb-4e56-9d92-e178f1296c25/407 Arctic coastal tundra - Bob Wick BLM.jpg

children.content:
The northern section of the Alaska subrealm, located in the Subarctic America (Nearctic) realm, is delineated by the Brooks Range. The North Alaskan Tundra bioregion is entirely made up of three tundra ecoregions—Arctic Coastal Tundra (407), Arctic Foothills Tundra (408), Brooks-British Range Tundra (411)—including the adjacent marine areas of the Beaufort and Chukchi seas. The total land area of this bioregion is 34 million hectares. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Subarctic America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the North Alaskan Tundra ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Brooks-British Range tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion consists of the Western Brooks Range in Alaska, the lower-elevation Anaktuvuk Pass in Alaska, and the higher Eastern Brooks Range in Alaska, Yukon Territory, and a small part of extreme northwestern Northwest Territories.

ecoregions.title: Arctic Foothills Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion, for most of its extent, lies between the Arctic Coastal Tundra ecoregion to the north and the Brooks-British Range Tundra ecoregion to the south.

ecoregions.title: Arctic Coastal Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion forms most of the northern coastline of Alaska.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/535f616f-66eb-4e56-9d92-e178f1296c25/407 Arctic coastal tundra - Bob Wick BLM.jpg

children.name: Canadian Tundra (NA2)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a547055b-55cc-4d1a-8b06-f06869ba99e8/415 Davis Highlands Tundra Ansgar Walk cc2.jpg

children.content:
The Canadian Tundra bioregion, located in the Subarctic America (Nearctic) realm, encompasses the entirety of the Canadian Arctic Archipelago and the northernmost lands of the North American continent. It is entirely made up of tundra with five ecoregions—Canadian High Arctic Tundra (412), Canadian Low Arctic Tundra (413), Canadian Middle Arctic Tundra (414), Davis Highlands Tundra (415), Torngat Mountain Tundra (421)—including adjacent marine areas. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 260 million hectares. 

Learn more about each of the Canadian Tundra ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Torngat Mountain Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This peninsular ecoregion lies to the north of the Eastern Canadian Shield Taiga ecoregion and projects into the sea where the Atlantic Ocean (Labrador Sea) meets the Arctic Ocean (Ungava Bay).

ecoregions.title: Davis Highlands Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies the rugged mountain chain along the eastern coast of Baffin Island, Nunavut, and the relatively narrow coastal plain adjacent to Davis Strait.

ecoregions.title: Canadian Middle Arctic Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies between the Canadian High Arctic Tundra to the north and the Canadian Low Arctic Tundra to the south and is ecologically transitional between these two ecoregions.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/bc00b623-ba48-4d1f-94b5-0da1b58c8139/414 Canadian Middle Arctic Tundra - Sebastian Kasten.JPG

ecoregions.title: Canadian Low Arctic Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is the largest ecoregion in Northern America Realm and stretches as a continuous swath across northern Northwest Territories and Nunavut to Hudson Bay.

ecoregions.title: Canadian High Arctic Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses most of the northern Arctic archipelago, from much of Baffin Island, Somerset, and Prince of Wales Islands in the south, through all islands northward to the most northern island in Canada, Ellesmere Island.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b224dbed-f142-40a6-adb5-cd492af15b9b/412 Canadian High Arctic tundra - Paul Gierszewski_resized.jpg

children.name: Canadian Shield & Coastal Taiga-Forests (NA9)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/21a81091-9664-41f1-bccb-1444f39859bd/370 Central Canadian Shield Forests Hans-Jürgen Hübner cc.jpeg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/a88ac2b4-12a9-4536-b640-a534bf96f9f8/382 Southern Hudson Bay Taiga Ansgar Walk CC.jpg

children.content:
The Canadian Shield bioregion, located in the Canadian Boreal Forests subrealm in the Subarctic America (Nearctic) realm, consists of the great boreal forests spanning across North America, from the Northwest Territories to the Atlantic Ocean. It consists of six ecoregions – Central Canadian Shield Forests (370), Eastern Canadian Boreal Forests (373), Eastern Canadian Shield Taiga (374), Midwest Canadian Shield Forests (377), Northern Canadian Shield Taiga (379), Southern Hudson Bay Taiga (382) – and includes the marine areas of James Bay, Labrador Sea, and the Gulf of St. Lawrence. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 325 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Subarctic America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Canadian Shield & Coastal Taiga-Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Midwest Canadian Shield Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is an immense area stretching from the north shore of Lake Superior in Ontario northwestward through western Ontario and central Manitoba to the south shore of Lake Athabasca in northern Saskatchewan and Alberta.

ecoregions.title: Eastern Canadian Boreal Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes much of eastern Quebec, the southern part of Labrador, and the entire island of Newfoundland.

ecoregions.title: Central Canadian Shield Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes much of boreal northern Quebec and Ontario, north of the temperate-boreal transition forests, south of the taiga, and west to include the northeastern shore of Lake Superior.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/d73d36ec-643c-4555-940f-0a3a1c072380/370 Central Canadian Shield forests - Robert F Beltran.jpg

ecoregions.title: Southern Hudson Bay Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses the Hudson Bay Lowland(s), the most extensive wetland complex in North America and the third largest on Earth.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/70632768-afc3-489a-90e5-fd0b5d278ef5/382 Southern Hudson Bay taiga - Reed Noss.jpg

ecoregions.title: Northern Canadian Shield Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion stretches from the eastern shore of Great Bear Lake, southeastward through the eastern half of Great Slave Lake, through the northeastern corner of Alberta, across northern Saskatchewan and the north shore of Lake Athabasca and eastward to southern Nunavut.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/59809435-5800-4a30-b42c-3dc1fe19f5ee/379 Northern Canadian Shield taiga - Paul Gierszewski.JPG

ecoregions.title: Eastern Canadian Shield Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This immense ecoregion stretches from Hudson and James Bays of the Arctic Ocean east to the Labrador Sea of the Atlantic Ocean and north to the southern portion of Ungava Bay of the Arctic Ocean.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/0b568a31-233e-4f23-9dd9-81ae52710024/374 Eastern Canadian Shield taiga - Paul Gierszewski.JPG

children.name: Mid-Canada Boreal Plains & Foothill Forests (NA8)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/6c07fa19-ce92-4c24-81bc-ae39df0e6b1f/341 Alberta-British Columbia Foothills Forests As2020sa cc.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f029c9c0-06da-40ca-8c95-f9fa39634795/376 Mid-Canada Boreal Plains Forests Image credit courtesy ofPeupleloup.jpg

children.content:
The Mid-Canada Boreal bioregion, located in the Subarctic America (Nearctic) realm, is defined predominantly by the plains and foothill forests lying between the Northern Rockies to the west and the Canadian Shield forests to the east. It consists of two ecoregions – Alberta-British Columbia Foothills Forests (345), Mid-Canada Boreal Plains Forests (376) – and includes Lake Winnipeg with one of the largest watersheds in Canada. The total area of this bioregion is approximately 69 million hectares.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Subarctic America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Mid-Canada Boreal Plains & Foothill Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Mid-Canada Boreal Plains Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion spans a large region of Canada, from just south of Wood Buffalo National Park in Alberta southeastward to just north of Winnipeg, Manitoba, encompassing Lake Winnipeg.

ecoregions.title: Alberta-British Columbia Foothills Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is an ecotone or transitional region between the Rocky Mountains to the west and the Mid-Canada Boreal Plains to the east, but also between the Boreal Forests/Taiga biome to the north and the Temperate Conifer Forests biome to the south.

children.name: Northwest Canadian Taiga, Lakes, & Wetlands (NA7)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/b8974411-bec5-48c9-97a9-b76de9e1e70c/381 Northwest Territories Taiga Daniel Case cc.jpg

children.content:
The Northwest Canadian Taiga bioregion, located in the west of the Canadian Boreal subrealm in the Subarctic America (Nearctic) realm, is the region lying between the Greater Yukon to the west and the Canadian Shield to the east, covering roughly half of the Northwest Territories in Canada. It consists of two large ecoregions – Muskwa-Slave Lake Taiga (378), Northwest Territories Taiga (381) – and includes Great Bear Lake, one of the largest lakes in North America, along with many wetlands.

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Subarctic America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Northwest Canadian Taiga, Lakes, & Wetlands ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Northwest Territories Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is the northern extension of the generally flat Interior Plains of Canada, which include the boreal plains and prairie ecoregions to the south.

ecoregions.title: Muskwa-Slave Lake Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion contains the Wood Buffalo National Park, the largest national park in Canada and the second largest national park in the world.

children.name: Greater Yukon (NA6)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/87ad718e-42f5-44fd-9812-dae6def0334e/419 Ogilvie-MacKenzie Alpine Tundra Paul Gierszewski cc.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f4ad7b03-9764-4ae2-899a-124b80d117d8/380 Northern Cordillera Forests paul Gierszewski cc2.jpg

children.content:
The Greater Yukon bioregion, located in the Subarctic America (Nearctic) realm, lies within the mountainous cordilleran region of western North American in the far west of the Canadian Boreal subrealm, defined by a large central plateau surrounded by some of the world’s highest mountains. This region is the source of the Yukon River, which flows west across Alaska, and is dominated by boreal forest with tundra in the north. It includes three ecoregions – Northern Cordillera Forests (380), Watson Highlands Taiga (383), and Ogilvie-MacKenzie Alpine Tundra (419). The total area of this bioregion is approximately 71 million hectares. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Subarctic America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Greater Yukon ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Watson Highlands Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion includes a large part of the Yukon Plateau and other highlands, ranging from the southwestern edge of Northwest Territories in the east, westward across northern British Columbia and a larger area of southern Yukon Territory, almost to Alaska.

ecoregions.title: Northern Cordillera Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses the northern extent of the Rocky Mountains (what Canadians call the “Northern Rockies”) and the northern Coast Mountains, as well as some smaller ranges and the Stikine Plateau.

ecoregions.title: Ogilvie-Mackenzie Alpine Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion encompasses the Ogilvie and Wernecke Mountains in the north, the Backbone Ranges, the Canyon Ranges, the Selwyn Mountains, and the eastern and southern Mackenzie Range.

children.name: Greenland (NA1)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/ed9f91e3-c3d1-45f7-b131-d7a4d8959722/417 Kalaallit Nunaat Arctic steppe - Morton Kilsholm.jpg
86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/35166b7c-f7af-413e-bcdf-3ad116d13c66/418 Kalaallit Nunaat High Arctic tundra - Jerzy Strzelecki resized.jpeg

children.content:
Greenland, located in the Subarctic America (Nearctic) realm, is the world’s largest island, and this bioregion consists entirely of ice-covered land, coastal tundra, and sea ice with two ecoregions – Kalaallit Nunaat Arctic Steppe [1] and Kalaallit Nunaat High Arctic Tundra [2] – including adjacent marine areas. The total land area of this bioregion is approximately 217 million hectares, about one-quarter the size of Australia. Of that, approximately 47.5 million is tundra. 

One Earth is dedicated to mobilizing philanthropic capital to protect the ecosystems and peoples of Subarctic America. Visit the Project Marketplace to explore projects in this realm that need your support. Learn more about each of the Greenland ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Kalaallit Nunaat High Arctic Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is the most northern land on the planet. Only the most cold-hardy plants and animals are able to survive in this forbidding area.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/bd6c3edd-7810-4705-9833-656ed3244531/418 Kalaallit Nunaat High Arctic Tundra Rita Willaert cc resized.jpeg

ecoregions.title: Kalaallit Nunaat Arctic Steppe
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion occupies the southwestern coast of Greenland, across Baffin Bay from Canada’s (Nunavut) Baffin Island, and the southern two-thirds of eastern Greenland, west and north of Iceland.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/ed9f91e3-c3d1-45f7-b131-d7a4d8959722/417 Kalaallit Nunaat Arctic steppe - Morton Kilsholm.jpg

children.name: Ural Mountains & West Eurasian Taiga Forests (PA8)

images.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/617ff4ef-82e9-4c99-83c4-fdf8390f94ad/719-Basegi Nature Reserve in the Urals-CC-Расторгуев Максим-2011_resized.jpg

children.content:
The Ural Mountains & West Eurasian Taiga Forests Bioregion is part of the Scandinavia & West Boreal Forests subrealm located in the Subarctic Eurasia realm (northern Palearctic) and contains two ecoregions—Scandinavian and Russian Taiga (717), Urals Montane Forest and Taiga (719)—totaling more than 233 million hectares of land area. 

Learn more about each of the Ural Mountains & West Eurasian Taiga Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Urals Montane Forest and Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is centered on the Ural Mountains, a 2,000 km range that runs north-south through the Russian Federation, from the Arctic Ocean to the Ural River.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/ab75af22-8313-4853-a789-20fb2e3abf27/719 Urals montane forest and taiga - Sergeu Berezin.jpg

ecoregions.title: Scandinavian and Russian Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This is the largest ecoregion in Europe, stretching across Norway, Sweden, Finland, and into the northern part of Russia.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/cfba640c-92d2-428c-b93a-90a992434228/717 Scandinavian and Russian taiga - Jacqueline Macou.jpg

children.name: Scandinavian Birch & Coastal Conifer Forests (PA3)
children.content:
The Scandinavian Birch & Coastal Conifer Forests bioregion is located in the Subarctic Eurasia realm (northern Palearctic) and contains two ecoregions—Scandinavian Coastal Conifer Forests (708), Scandinavian Montane Birch Forest and Grasslands (780)—totaling more than 26 million hectares of land area.

Learn more about each of the Scandinavian Birch & Coastal Conifer Forests ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Scandinavian Montane Birch Forest and Grasslands
ecoregions.dek: The Southern part of this ecoregion is situated in Norway’s central highlands and the Northern part follows the Scandinavian mountains across Norway and Sweden, and touches the northern tip of Finland.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/c31f16fe-8ff7-4a65-aa9d-45b6ee6e3cdc/780 Scandinavian Montane Birch forest and grasslands - Arto Marttinen.jpg

ecoregions.title: Scandinavian Coastal Conifer Forests
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion follows the western Norwegian coast from Flekkefjord to Senja.

children.name: Iceland (PA2)
children.content:
The Iceland bioregion is part of the Scandinavia & West Boreal Forests subrealm located in the Subarctic Eurasia realm (northern Palearctic) and contains one single ecoregion—Boreal Birch Forests and Alpine Tundra (711)—totaling approximately nine million hectares of land area. 

Learn more about the Iceland ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Iceland Boreal Birch Forests and Alpine Tundra
ecoregions.dek: Iceland is the second largest island in the North Atlantic Ocean with its northern edge situated just south of the Arctic Circle.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/52a390a6-35ed-49bf-9868-cfafa13a5848/711 Iceland boreal birch forests and alpine tundra -David Mark.jpg

children.name: Greater Eurasian Tundra (PA4)
children.content:
The Greater Eurasian Tundra bioregion is located in the Subarctic Eurasia realm (northern Palearctic) and contains six ecoregions—Kola Peninsula Tundra (774), Northeast Siberian Coastal Tundra (775), Northwest Russian-Novaya Zemlya Tundra (776), Novosibirsk Islands Arctic Desert (777), Taimyr-Central Siberian Tundra (781), Yamal-Gydan Tundra (784)—totaling more than 197 million hectares of land area.

Learn more about each of the Greater Eurasian Tundra ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Yamal-Gydan Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion lies in the middle of Russia’s arctic coast, to the south of the Kara Sea.

ecoregions.title: Taimyr-Central Siberian Tundra
ecoregions.dek: The northernmost continental land in the world, this ecoregion is a vast area of pristine polar desert, mountain and lowland tundra, rich wetlands and larch forests.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/7bf9165b-eded-44e8-997d-a73f4883c1d7/781 Taimyr-Central Siberian tundra - Фаге Алексей Николаевич.jpg

ecoregions.title: Novosibirsk Islands Arctic Desert
ecoregions.dek: The Novosibirsk archipelago is found off the north coast of eastern Siberia, dividing the Laptev and East Siberian Seas.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/2d93f88b-b138-49f3-aec2-2dee2a5cea59/777 Novosibirsk Islands Arctic desert - Ansgar Walk.jpg

ecoregions.title: Northwest Russian-Novaya Zemlya Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion spans 1,000 km of the North Coast of European Russia stretching from the White Sea-bound Kanin Peninsula in the West, to the Yugorsky Peninsula in the East.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/350300a6-0251-471c-a953-e13fab22bc9e/776 Northwest Russian-Novaya Zemlya tundra - Ansgar Walk.jpg

ecoregions.title: Northeast Siberian Coastal Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers northeastern Sakha, from Sytygan-Tala Bay to the Kolyma river delta.

image.path: 86ce9525-f5f2-4e97-81ba-54e8ce933da7/dev/f79d39ac-9780-494c-8753-8dfb18c3fbc2/775 Northeast Siberian coastal tundra - John Lamoreux.jpg

ecoregions.title: Kola Peninsula Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This tundra stretches across the Northern shore of the Russian Federation’s Kola Peninsula, reaching into the northeasternmost tip of Norway.

children.name: Russian Arctic Desert Islands (PA1)
children.content:
The Russian Arctic bioregion is part of the Palearctic Tundra subrealm located in the Subarctic Eurasia realm (northern Palearctic) and contains one single ecoregion—Russian Arctic Tundra (778)—totaling more than 16 million hectares of land area.  

Learn more about the Russian Arctic Desert Islands ecoregion below.

ecoregions.title: Russian Arctic Desert
ecoregions.dek: Four major archipelagos lie within this region of the High Arctic.

children.name: Sea of Okhotsk Coastal Taiga, Meadows & Tundra (PA6)
children.content:
The Sea of Okhotsk Coastal Taiga, Meadows & Tundra bioregion is part of the Sea of Okhotsk & Bearing Tundra/Taiga subrealm located in the Subarctic Eurasia realm (northern Palearctic) and contains five ecoregions—Kamchatka Taiga (712), Kamchatka-Kurile Meadows and Sparse Forests (713), Okhotsk-Manchurian Taiga (715), Sakhalin Island Taiga (716), Kamchatka Tundra (773)—totaling more than 75 million hectares of land area. 

Learn more about each of the Sea of Okhotsk Coastal Taiga, Meadows & Tundra ecoregions below.

ecoregions.title: Kamchatka Tundra
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers two mountain ranges — the Sredinny mountains running down the center of the peninsula, and the more dissected Vostochniy range on the eastern side, with over 20 active volcanoes.

ecoregions.title: Sakhalin Island Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion covers the majority of Sakhalin, a 948 km-long island separating the Sea of Okhotsk from the Sea of Japan in the far east of Russia.

ecoregions.title: Okhotsk-Manchurian Taiga
ecoregions.dek: This ecoregion is dominated by mountains and shaped by the Amur river. Reindeer and Siberian musk deer forage on lichen found in the forests of Dahurian larch and Yeddo spruce.

ecoregions.title: Kamchatka-Kurile Meadows and Sparse Forests
